story:
Looking Back 20 Years . . .

October 16, 1996 marks 20 years ago that I held the very first audition for the Kendra Kimbrough Dance Ensemble (KKDE). It was in the Oak Street location of San Francisco Dance Center and it was full of amazing dancers ready and willing to support my vision. 

Fast forward nearly ten years and you’ll discover the Black Choreographers Festival. Founded in 2005 with the African and African-American Performing Arts Coalition (AAAPAC), the Black Choreographers Festival: Here & Now strives to increase the visibility of African-American dance by showcasing the ingenuity and uniqueness of African and African-American dance artists. 

These are the limbs of K★STAR★PRODUCTIONS,
and boy are they tired!

Since 1996, KKDE has performed and taught workshops throughout the Bay area and beyond. By sharing our movement we are challenging stereotypes and amplifying social issues while making art accessible to everyone. Whether teaching, creating, or presenting, we are constantly working to cultivate spaces that inspire, inform, and evolve us and our communities.

The annual Black Choreographers Festival: Here & Now has featured artists across generations - from Donald McKayle and Jawole Willa Jo Zollar to Chloe Arnold and Delina Brooks. BCF also hosts two professional development programs, the Artist Mentoring Program for emerging artists, and the Technical Training Program for young artists (ages 17-25). These artists are the foundation of our community and it is an honor to support them in as many ways as we can.

“From the beginning BCF turned a wide-angle lens on African American choreography...over the last decade they have presented almost 80 choreographers.”
- San Francisco Bay Guardian (2/5/2014)

I am forever grateful to everyone who continues to show up to propel these dreams into forward motion. I honestly can't believe 20 years have passed, but there’s so much more we want to do!

What are we dreaming of?

SPACE

We’re visioning a home for K★STAR★PRODUCTIONS to offer continuous production and programming. This space would support the creation, cultivation and performance of new works by KKDE. BCF’s artist development programs would also reside here. And we would offer Master Classes for everyone plus Arts Administration workshops and symposiums to support the continued evolution of our choreographers, performers, and supporters.

INFRASTRUCTURE

We are working towards becoming a 501(c)(3) which will open the door for even more support pathways. We will be cultivating a team that supports more efficient operations. This team will manage the limbs of the organization allowing me to create, vision, and strategize ways to continue sharing our movement. With a stronger infrastructure that is not solely reliant on me, our reach can grow beyond our wildest dreams.

GROWTH

As we solidify our framework, both inside and out, we are looking to stretch our limbs even further. We have plans to share the BCF model with other cities like Sacramento, Los Angeles, New York, and Chicago. KKDE will continue to expand its educational programming by teaching and choreographing for local pre-professional youth groups, performing in local schools and colleges, and offering immersive lec-dems that bridge cultures and support creative exchange.

How will we get there?

It should come as no surprise that our work has already begin. First and foremost, we MUST celebrate our 20th anniversary in style! You may have already seen us advertising our 20th Anniversary Concert. We’ve got twenty dancers returning to the stage, live accompaniment led by Afro Bloco former Ile Aiye drummer Julio Remelexo, AND two choreographic world premieres. 

We also recently received a grant from the California Arts Council's Cultural Pathways program to support strategic planning and sustainability. As we invest in our development, we want to grow smart and stay true to who we are along the way. We will work towards fundraising strategies that invite donors like you to support our work continuously while continuing our relationships with institutions such as the Zellerbach Family Foundation and East Bay Community Foundation, among others. 

Where does your support go?

At this pivotal moment, your donation will support the success of our 20th Anniversary Concert including stipends for the choreographer and artists. It is imperative to us that these artists know we value them and that they are compensated for their high caliber contributions to this performance.

Your contribution will also lay the foundation for us to: 

  • complete our 501c(3) status, 
  • continue the strategic planning process that will allow us to get clear about our identity and vision our legacy,
  • continue to employ and compensate KKDE dancers and collaborators,
  • and continue to grow and expand BCF so that African-American choreographers across the country can see and support each other’s work.

Now more than ever we need strategy, infrastructure, & resources. Your support brings us all this and more!

This campaign is a first step towards twenty more years of performances, workshops, and professional development for our artists and community members.

 

Thank you for supporting our sparkle and sustaining our shine!

 

About K★STAR★PRODUCTIONS

Formed in October 1996 by Director, Kendra Kimbrough Barnes, K★STAR★PRODUCTIONS (fiscally sponsored by Dimensions Dance Theater) serves as a performing arts presenting organization for the Black Choreographers Festival: Here & Now and the Kendra Kimbrough Dance Ensemble (KKDE). 

Our mission is to fearlessly cultivate a diverse environment that inspires, informs, and supports the evolution of the arts through relationship building, mentoring, exploration and presentation. We work to make culture exchange accessible to the community at large with a focus on African American constituents. This goal is attained by forming alliances, traveling, producing concerts, workshops & master classes, hosting public symposiums, and providing professional development information to new forming dance companies.

Campaign video by Eli Jacobs-Fantauzzi of www.FistUp.Tv.

We also recently received a grant from the California Arts Council's Cultural Pathways program to support strategic planning and sustainability. We will work towards fundraising strategies that invite donors like you to support our work continuously while continuing our relationships with institutions such as the Zellerbach Family Foundation and East Bay Community Foundation, among others. 

Where does your support go?
At this pivotal moment, your donation will support the success of our 20th Anniversary Concert including stipends for the choreographer and artists. It is imperative to us that these artists know we value them and that they are compensated for their high caliber contributions to this performance.
Your contribution will also lay the foundation for us to: 

complete our 501c(3) status, 
continue the strategic planning process that will allow us to get clear about our identity and vision our legacy,
continue to employ and compensate KKDE dancers and collaborators,
and continue to grow and expand BCF so that African-American choreographers across the country can see and support each other’s work.

Now more than ever we need strategy, infrastructure, & resources. Your support brings us all this and more!
This campaign is a first step towards twenty more years of performances, workshops, and professional development for our artists and community members.
 Thank you for supporting our sparkle and sustaining our shine! 
About K★STAR★PRODUCTIONS
Formed in October 1996 by Director, Kendra Kimbrough Barnes, K★STAR★PRODUCTIONS (fiscally sponsored by Dimensions Dance Theater) serves as a performing arts presenting organization for the Black Choreographers Festival: Here & Now and the Kendra Kimbrough Dance Ensemble (KKDE). 
Our mission is to fearlessly cultivate a diverse environment that inspires, informs, and supports the evolution of the arts through relationship building, mentoring, exploration and presentation. We work to make culture exchange accessible to the community at large with a focus on African American constituents. This goal is attained by forming alliances, traveling, producing concerts, workshops & master classes, hosting public symposiums, and providing professional development information to new forming dance companies.
Campaign video by Eli Jacobs-Fantauzzi of www.FistUp.Tv.

story:
9 to 5 Productions is a budding, membership-based New York theater production company dedicated to providing working professionals and other 9 to 5-ers with an opportunity to perform. We staged our first production back in May of 2016, which was well received and celebrated throughout our growing community. Not only did we hit our goal in our Kickstarter campaign but we exceeded it. That enabled us to start working on our second production — “Little Shop of Horrors” — but we need your help once more!

Our very talented cast and crew are working hard on this demanding piece, and we would love your support.

These funds are going to production essentials: show rights, costuming, make-up, equipment (such as Audrey II), rehearsal spaces, and our performance venue. Should we exceed our goal, some of these funds will be put to our next performance.

Our campaign ends Oct. 31 at the stroke of midnight (when you actually want to turn into a pumpkin!).

Shows: 8 p.m. Nov. 3–5

Buy tickets here: http://9to5lsoh.bpt.me

We are so grateful for your support, and we can’t wait to share this incredible production with you!

story:
The power of “bonus time”

When people are brought to the edge of death and back again, an incredible thing happens: they often see the days and years afterward as a gift—“bonus time” to use for living life more fully. That’s a powerful response. Now imagine if it could be evoked through a surprisingly entertaining theatrical performance. That’s the idea behind Near Death Experience.

How we get there

Without our fascination with death, much of our popular entertainment wouldn’t exist (think of all the films built around blowing things up and throwing fictional bodies everywhere). But off the screen, most of us find it a difficult subject to address, let alone to accept and respond to in a meaningful way.

Near Death Experience uses the tools of humor, magical and psychic performance, and interactive theatre to bring audience members into a conversation about mortality that’s never threatening and actually kind of fun. They’re brought gradually closer and closer to the subject until, by the show’s climax, they have the opportunity to feel personally involved in a theatrical Near Death Experience that might leave them positively transformed.

Even the location helps

Since bringing people closer to the subject of death is the whole point, even some of our performance locations are part of the show: every element of Near Death Experience is designed to work on the premises of actual funeral homes! This charges performances with site-specific excitement that begins with the audience’s very act of crossing the threshold into the show space.

(Safely) heart-stopping climax

The climax of the show involves the entire audience living vicariously through me as I go through— per the promise in the show’s title—a Near Death Experience. As a lifelong student of magical and psychic performance with particular emphasis on its darker areas (hence my performance character’s title of Necromancer), I’m uniquely suited to performing feats that seem to skirt the edges of our mortal limits before returning myself and my audience to safe ground.

Cemetery Resolution books

Part of the show involves the use of custom-printed props: books which are handled by members of the audience. Depicting a virtual cemetery stroll with the Necromancer, the books are filled with original photographs which, in addition to being beautiful on their own, are captioned with meaningful text suggesting the kind of resolutions one might make when surrounded by reminders of life’s brevity—resolutions for taking advantage of the “bonus time” we all have.

After the show, these books will be available to audience members, to extend contemplation of their Near Death Experience. Through this Indiegogo campaign, they are also available under "Perks" in advance of the show, to keep for yourself or to give as gifts (you'll have to use your own best judgment as to who would be pleased to receive such a thing from you).

Rooted in interactive theatre success

Near Death Experience as an interactive theatre piece didn’t just come out of the blue. Over the past 15 years, I’ve been writing, producing, and performing a series of successful interactive and magical theatre shows dealing with serious subjects in entertaining ways.

The Houdini Seance (2001) brought audience members into contact with the spirit of the late magician as well as personal spirits of their own, within a theatrical reconstruction of a traditional Victorian séance. This solo show ran every Halloween for 13 years. “Here’s your chance to have an old-school, creepy Halloween.” Red Eye Chicago

Supernatural Chicago (2004) ran every week for 10 straight years—making it one of the longest-running solo shows in the city's history—as it immersed audience members in sometimes-unsettling historical stories of the paranormal. Site-specific, it drew some of its power from its setting within a reputedly haunted landmark building. “Is it real? Or isn’t it?” Chicago Tribune

Palace of the Occult (2015) transported audience members to the 1933 Berlin grand opening of the titular performance salon, where they were treated as the personal guests of Erik Jan Hanussen, a Jewish psychic performer struggling to survive during the rise of the Nazis. “Highly recommended—The fascinating true story related by the trickster is enough to leave us spellbound.” Windy City Times

Near Death Experience carries my work a major step further. Not only does it blend interactive, site-specific theatre with magic and psychic entertainment to tell stories and touch emotions, it actually has the potential to inspire audience members to pursue more fulfilling lives. How often does theatre get to do that?

Coming to you in Fall 2017

The initial wave of performances will be in the fall of 2017 at sites in Chicago, New York, and Los Angeles. Exact dates, times, and locations will be announced in September though emails sent directly to our Indiegogo benefactors, so you won't miss the Near Death Experience near you! (Details will also be posted in the press and on the show website, neardeathx.com.) 

Be part of this

Over the years, I’ve learned how to get shows up and running without a lot of capital. But some money is still needed. Custom props need to be paid for. So does travel and advertising (since zero press means zero audience).

Your donation toward our goal of $15,000 would help us put together enough starter money to mount our initial run. (For a more traditional show, that would barely cover theatre rental!) Even if we don’t hit our entire goal through Indiegogo, we could get close enough to generate buzz and inspire other sources to kick in.

Goodies for you

Any amount would help, of course, but since souvenirs are fun, here’s a peek at some of the incentives (see the “Perks” section for the full list):

$50 Book—Before the show even opens, get an advance autographed copy of the Near Death Experience book, Cemetery Resolutions. Lovely photos, inspiring text, messy signature: it’s a trifecta.

$125 Script—Get an autographed, stapled (unbound) working copy of the Near Death Experience show script. Imagine the eBay value of this when the show wins the Tony for Best Fun-And-Interactive Show About Death.

$300 Contributor Package—Get your name on the Contributors page of the show’s official website (neardeathx.com), and also receive the Script/Book/CD Combo. That'll impress your next date, for sure.

It’s not all about money

If you have a personal, inside contact at a funeral home or theatre space in Chicago, New York or Los Angeles who would be interested in hosting a performance or two, you could be a Necromantic Venue Facilitator. That is one sexy title, so drop a note to neil@necromancerevents.com with your info and theirs. If it turns into a booking, you’ll get your name in the printed program and the right to put that little conversation starter on your resume.

Even if you don't know anybody in the funeral or theatre worlds, you can still help by telling all your friends about this breakthrough show in person, by phone, and through your favorite social media. Indiegogo has some handy sharing tools, so feel free to use those too!

Let’s help make a difference in people’s lives—by giving them a Near Death Experience.

story:
Break it Down Now

Here's our breakdown of expenses involved in taking this show to the Fringe:

£2700  Accommodation for 9 people, 9 nights

£2700  Venue Fees

£1000  Licensing Fees

£500    Travel to and From Edinburgh

£300    Fringe Registration

£100     Costumes/props

£100     Advertising (Printing flyers, posters, and programs)

£100     Insurance

TOTAL £6,600 

What We Need

Here's what we've raised so far and what we have left to raise:
£2000 Birmingham City University
£1350   Individual fundraising by cast members
£900    Indiegogo Donations
£325     Fundraising Show
TOTAL £4,575 
REMAINING £2,025

Why We Need Your Help

We've paid for as many of the expenses as we could with fundraising money, however, the remaining £2,025 has come out of our pockets. As recent graduates living off of student salaries, we need as much of our money back as we can get. Many generous donations have helped us get where we are now and start paying back the money we've poured into this project. We care about this project enough to put our own money into it with the faith that some of it will get reimbursed, but we could use a bit more help.

The Show

Our company is unique in its make-up: we are all students or recent graduates who are working on this project solely for the love of musical theatre. Godspell is a challenging show that presents age-old stories, but we are presenting them in a nuanced way. 

Our Stakes

This project is coming straight from the heart and our producing team, cast, and crew, has already put our blood, sweat, tears and funds into it. Your donation will help us feel secure during our time in Edinburgh so that we can focus on putting on the best show possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute (or you can!) please consider sharing our campaign with your friends and family. We can't do this without your help, and given that our company stretches across the pond, we hope our impact and donors can too!

story:
What we have ...

  • An amazing cast, creative team, and crew
  • A beautiful transformative space
  • Pristine sound

What we need...

  • Lighting - Our lighting plan is beautiful and quite complex. It is integral to the execution of our vision.  In order to travel through our intended multiverse experience, light will have a huge part in assisting the narrative. Throughout the various incarnations our characters explore, while jumping seamlessly through all possible outcomes, light will act as a third character guiding our senses through all jumps.
  • Set- Clay Rodery returns to impart his genius and give the space a sense of awe and the feel of being nowhere and everywhere at the same time.
  • Space-  This unique  performance will take place in a former knitting factory/butchery/underground artist gallery that has been reimagined as a multi-purpose raw space called the Artery @464 Seneca Avenue in Brooklyn, New York. The Artery transforms into the multiverse venue of our production and we must cover enough to keep the lights on during our time there.

 

The Impact

 

  • Constellations encapsulates the world of physics and emulsifies it with heartbreak, love, betrayal, life, death; endless possibilities that explore how inevitably fraught and imperfect communication is, even with those closest to you.
  • After our last production, the response to the work was loud, emotive, and wildly positive. It inspired us to get to take the initiative,  creating a new world to invite our amazing patrons into.
  • We were only able to pull it all off due to a successful fundraising campaign that 95% of our audience participated in - this is your opportunity to weave yourselves into our timeline.
  • At Ebb & Flow, we aim to curate theatrical experiences that foster visceral connections between the audience and the actor. Reimagining works to challenge the conventional relationship between performer and audience takes huge risks from both parties. The former, relinquishes the ability to hide and disengage from the audience, they are in plain sight. Always. The latter, must acknowledge the possibility of both physical and emotional discomfort and willingly enter the fray.

What you get...

  • A choice from a bevy of amazing and satisfying perks that elevate your experience. The more you are able to contribute, proportionally affects the higher levels of emotional and visual impact you will experience.
  • Karma points and the ability to say you had a hand in bringing to life an incredibly unique theatrical experience.

Risks & Challenges

Putting up a  theatre piece of any type is difficult - fraught with unexpected obstacles and unforeseen circumstances. And putting up an experimental, immersive piece as an independent new theatre company doubles down on that! Luckily, the MOST IMPORTANT THING we have going for us, is the team we've assembled; one that's brimming with talent and expertise in creating intimate, impassioned bespoke experiences.   

  • Chelsey Ng (Marianne/Founder) is the founder of Ebb&Flow Productions and will be playing Marianne in  'Constellations' a play by Nick Payne. After assuming the role of director with 'Danny and the Deep Blue Sea' she is excited to be exploring the cosmos on stage. Hailing from the sunny island of Singapore where she could be found touring with Brazilian percussion group Bloco Singapura, she is now more likely found on another vibrant island, Manhattan, in the Manderley Bar slinking about the halls of the McKittrick Hotel (home of 'Sleep No More')

  • Alejandro Garcia (Director/Light Design) is thrilled to make his directorial debut at Ebb & Flow. As a performer, he has the pleasure to dance under the instruction of Robert Battle, Seàn Curran, and the NYCB. Behind the scenes, he has enjoyed adventures following pop stars on the road and art directing and coordinating at dusty desert art festivals. As a New York native, he brings with him a rich complexity of a multitude of mediums.

  • Clay Rodery (Production Designer) is the Production Designer of Ebb & Flow, having previously worked on Danny and the Deep Blue Sea.  He is a graduate of the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and the School of the Visual Arts, New York (2010).  His illustrations have appeared in the New York Times, The Atlantic, National Geographic, as well as television titles such as Game of Thrones and The Knick.  After dark, he works with the costume designers of Punchdrunk's Sleep No More at the McKittrick Hotel, creating all sorts of mischief long past the witching hour. 

  • Andrés Montejo (Roland)is a NewYork-based, Costa Rican actor. He is thrilled to embark on Ebb&Flow’s production of Constellations by Nick Payne. Following his Off-Broadway debut as Don John in Much Ado About Nothing, he is ready to take on the challenge of bringing Roland to life. Andres is the founder of The Affordable Masterclass Project , designed to give the actor accessible tools to heighten their craft.  

  • Zachary Wendeln (Stage Manager/AD/Light Design) is thrilled to jump on board his first production with Ebb&Flow.  A native Midwesterner, Zach moved to New York to pursue his passion for immersive and site-integrated theatre.  For his honors thesis at the University of Notre Dame, he wrote, directed, designed, and produced an original immersive piece, Field Below, an adaptation of the myth of Persephone staged at the historic Birdsell Mansion in downtown South Bend, IN.  He spent the last two summers working on site-specific Shakespeare productions through the Notre Dame Shakespeare Festival's Young Company, as assistant stage manager (The Merry Wives of Windsor, 2014) and assistant director (Love's Labor's Lost, 2015).  Last autumn, he served as assistant stage manager on HEROMONSTER, the latest devised theatre piece from WePlayers, a forerunner in immersive, site-integrated theatre based in the Bay Area.  Currently, Zach serves on the crew at Sleep No More.  

  • Jamie Amadruto (Sound Master) is  dedicated to creating works of sound and music.  She wishes to transmit others, through sound, into a unique world of emotion, movement and thought in Ebb&Flow's production of Constellations. She brings with her a creative soul, an open mind, and an unwavering attention to fine detail. To listen to some of her personal productions, click the link https://soundcloud.com/jamieamadruto

 

  • The brain child of Photographer Boon Chian Ong & Creative Director Liz Cummings and the home of Philosity Photography, The Artery has been lovingly restored with the intention to support new and developing artists and we are very excited to be partnering with Ebb & Flow in their production of Constellations.

    Located 2 blocks from the heart of Bushwick ,The Artery was once home to a turn of the century knitting factory and has transcended into a multi-disciplined space in the center of a great emerging art scene. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Even if you can't contribute with a monetary donation - there's TONS of other ways to be a supporter of CONSTELLATIONS!
  • Share the hashtags - #CONSTELLATIONSBK, #EBB+FLOWBK
  • ...on Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/EbbandFlowProductions
  • ...on Instagram - @flow_ebb 
  • Tell your friends - especially the ones with some cash to spend on the arts! 
  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
  • And you can use the Indiegogo share tools to do all that and more...

Behind the scenes, he has enjoyed adventures following pop stars on the road and art directing and coordinating at dusty desert art festivals. As a New York native, he brings with him a rich complexity of a multitude of mediums.


Clay Rodery (Production Designer) is the Production Designer of Ebb & Flow, having previously worked on Danny and the Deep Blue Sea.  He is a graduate of the School of the Art Institute of Chicago and the School of the Visual Arts, New York (2010).  His illustrations have appeared in the New York Times, The Atlantic, National Geographic, as well as television titles such as Game of Thrones and The Knick.  After dark, he works with the costume designers of Punchdrunk's Sleep No More at the McKittrick Hotel, creating all sorts of mischief long past the witching hour. 


Andrés Montejo (Roland)is a NewYork-based, Costa Rican actor. He is thrilled to embark on Ebb&Flow’s production of Constellations by Nick Payne. Following his Off-Broadway debut as Don John in Much Ado About Nothing, he is ready to take on the challenge of bringing Roland to life. Andres is the founder of The Affordable Masterclass Project , designed to give the actor accessible tools to heighten their craft.  


Zachary Wendeln (Stage Manager/AD/Light Design) is thrilled to jump on board his first production with Ebb&Flow.  A native Midwesterner, Zach moved to New York to pursue his passion for immersive and site-integrated theatre.  For his honors thesis at the University of Notre Dame, he wrote, directed, designed, and produced an original immersive piece, Field Below, an adaptation of the myth of Persephone staged at the historic Birdsell Mansion in downtown South Bend, IN.  He spent the last two summers working on site-specific Shakespeare productions through the Notre Dame Shakespeare Festival's Young Company, as assistant stage manager (The Merry Wives of Windsor, 2014) and assistant director (Love's Labor's Lost, 2015).  Last autumn, he served as assistant stage manager on HEROMONSTER, the latest devised theatre piece from WePlayers, a forerunner in immersive, site-integrated theatre based in the Bay Area.  Currently, Zach serves on the crew at Sleep No More.  


Jamie Amadruto (Sound Master) is  dedicated to creating works of sound and music.  She wishes to transmit others, through sound, into a unique world of emotion, movement and thought in Ebb&Flow's production of Constellations. She brings with her a creative soul, an open mind, and an unwavering attention to fine detail. To listen to some of her personal productions, click the link https://soundcloud.com/jamieamadruto



 

The brain child of Photographer Boon Chian Ong & Creative Director Liz Cummings and the home of Philosity Photography, The Artery has been lovingly restored with the intention to support new and developing artists and we are very excited to be partnering with Ebb & Flow in their production of Constellations.Located 2 blocks from the heart of Bushwick ,The Artery was once home to a turn of the century knitting factory and has transcended into a multi-disciplined space in the center of a great emerging art scene. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute with a monetary donation - there's TONS of other ways to be a supporter of CONSTELLATIONS!
Share the hashtags - #CONSTELLATIONSBK, #EBB+FLOWBK
...on Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/EbbandFlowProductions

...on Instagram - @flow_ebb 
Tell your friends - especially the ones with some cash to spend on the arts! 
Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign!
And you can use the Indiegogo share tools to do all that and more...

story:
Hi it's me again, Mary Ellen Ashley...

With "The Eve of Beltane " we not only address the pending social problems of the day but we present solutions unlike any other show by using dance, design and music in very unique ways .

We are listed with the National New Play Network - here you will find the script, music, reviews and podcasts:https://newplayexchange.org/plays/62876/eve-bel...

Thank you again for coming along on this exciting journey with us. For your contribution at this rudimentary phase of the "Eve of Beltane", please know that you will be offered initial consideration as  first investors. Together we can bring to light the power of theatre that speaks to us all in a time when need it most, thus raising the bar to strengthen culture.

story:
Dear Friends,

For the past 4 years, we have been developing (researching, composing, writing, workshopping) a brand new opera-theatre work based on the life of legendary dancer and femme fatale Mata Hari. In many ways, this is the biggest undertaking of our careers yet, because of the size of the piece and our vision for this work. With the support of the HERE Artist Residency Program, we’ve grown the piece from an idea to a full production, and in January 2017, the piece will have its world premiere in PROTOTYPE, the premier global festival of opera-theatre and music-theatre in New York City, co-produced by HERE and Beth Morrison Projects.

Now is the time when you can ensure the project’s success!

On September 17, 2016, We will walk the length of Broadway in Manhattan to raise the final $14,000 of the production’s budget, which will allow us to compensate all of the artists involved in the creation of this work at an appropriate level. This is not your ordinary fundraising campaign, where we simply ask for your support—we are asking you to sponsor a section of the walk. From the northern most point of Manhattan, Broadway Bridge at West 220th Street, to the southern tip at Battery Park, Broadway encompasses 14 miles and 280 blocks. With your partnership, we will walk that length as a sign of our commitment to this project and our collaborators.

We hope you’ll be a part of this effort!

Our Project

Mata Hari, a world premiere opera, is inspired by the legendary and controversial female mystic dancer who was executed for espionage during World War I. Created by director/librettist Paul Peers and composer Matt Marks, this original work disrupts the traditional operatic form through a layering of physical theater, unconventional instrumentation, found texts, and highly manipulated video design. Born Margaretha Geertruida Zelle, part of the Frisian minority of the Netherlands in 1876, Mata Hari concocted a new life for herself after years of being dominated by an oppressive husband by becoming a renowned mystic dancer. Her career as a dancer simultaneously made her infamous, as both a great artist—promoting female self-determination and liberation—and as a whore and eventual traitor. Set during Mata Hari’s final months of life in prison in Paris, Mata Hari tells the story of a woman who finds herself ostracized, made a scapegoat, and executed by a moralistic society dominated by men.

The Artists

Cast: Tina Mitchell, Mary MacKenzie, Jeff Gavett, Daniel Neer, Joshua Jeremiah, Steve Hrycelak and Michael Marcotte.

Instrumental Ensemble: Mila Henry, James Moore, Helen Yee, Kamala Sankaram.

Creative Team: Neal Wilkinson (Set), Oana Botez (Costume), Lucrecia Briceno (Lighting), David Jonathan Palmer (Projection) and Isaac Jones (Sound Engineer).

Choreographer: Anabella Lenzu

Stage Manager: Aislinn Curry

Conductor: David Bloom

Composer Matt Marks

Director/Librettist: Paul Peers

PROTOTYPE 2017

We are extremely excited to be included in PROTOTYPE 2017. This is the fifth installment of this annual festival of visionary opera-theatre and music-theatre works by pioneering contemporary artists from New York City and around the world. The festival is the only one of its kind in the United States – presenting original genre-bending works by both emerging and career artists. PROTOTYPE occurs for two weeks in January during national and international conferences of presenters. This allows presenters and directors from around the world to see the work and ideally bring it to their own venues, extending the life and reach of a work like Mata Hari and furthering the careers of artists like us.

The Festival has provoked the New York Times to call it “invaluable…vibrantly theatrical, genre-blurring, unusual in its techniques, eclectic in its musical style and politically charged” and Time Out New York noted that “HERE and Beth Morrison Projects prove that thrilling opera continues to bloom.”

The ability to create ambitious works of opera-theatre like Mata Hari remains a long-term creative and career goal of many up-and-coming individuals working in the field. However, the successful creation of these complex and challenging art forms is a difficult goal to achieve: projects like this are costly in both time and resources. This is an important step in our careers—to not only mount this work, but be included in PROTOTYPE and produce this work at such a high level.

The walk will point out the needs of not only our project, but also the challenges of artists around New York City, as they struggle to pay bills and create work in our expensive, but enormously culturally influential city. This walk will also be a celebration of everything we have done so far to bring this project to life and the last few months and steps of work to be done, leading up to the January premiere.

The various levels of giving are listed. We hope you’ll join our effort by donating, spreading the word, joining us on the walk on September 17 (virtually or in-person), and coming to see the show in January.

**Make a gift of any size before September 7th and you'll be entered in a draw to win a private boat cruise on the Hudson River!

(The first five Donors who give $1,008 or more are automatically eligible for this perk.)**

Thank you for your belief in Mata Hari!

story:
"Girls don't like metal." -some idiot

NOT TRUE.

Sign of the Beast Burlesque is perhaps the most well known and unique burlesque troupe in Portland Oregon. We've been producing and performing in full length cabaret style shows featuring incredible performers and heavy metal music since 2010, when troupe was formed by local legend "Miss Metal Portland" Vera Mysteria. Since then, co-producers Rocket and Hai Fleisch have taken the troupe to new heights, making the show more epic every year.  So far we've had some incredible performances:  babes bathing in giant goblets of blood, high flying aerial artist witches, murderous mermaids, and a tiny naked woman riding a giant stuffed tiger, just to name a few. 

In 2016, we wanted to share our love of metal and performance art with a larger audience and a more diverse group of performers. We cranked up the volume on our favorite Slayer record, thought long and hard about how we could achieve this goal.....and the idea for the first ever Metalesque Fest was born! The fest incorporates three days of badass performances, live metal music from local bands, an air guitar contest, workshops, and networking events.

If you are a believer in the power of burlesque has to change lives and you love metal music, this fest is for you! It's rare to see women "take the lead" in the metal music scene, and here is a group of women so in love with the music and it's power that they have produced an entire show (for six years now) dedicated to it! So many women absolutely love metal, and our troupe and guest performers from around the country are ready to rock out! Thank you for helping us make our goal a reality!

How can you help?

...and what do you get?

We put our nose to the rhinestone and had an amazing fundraising show earlier in 2016. Although it helped us raise a good deal of money, we are still in need of more funds to nurture this show into reaching it's full potential. We must pay our performers, musicians, and staff for the countless hours of work, love and practice they have put in to make this fest a reality. In addition, we have venue fees and transportation costs. This is where you come in! Your contributions help us to facilitate the behind the scenes costs associated with Metalesque Fest.

In return, we have some amazing Sign of the Beast Burlesque merch and VIP perks we'd like to offer you to say THANK YOU!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can contribute financially, AWESOME! If you are unable to at this time, please consider using the "share" feature here on indiegogo to help us spread the word about our campaign! We would really appreciate it...thank you!

Find us on Facebook here:  facebook.com/signofthebeastpdx

Find us on Instagram: @signofthebeastburlesque #signofthebeastburlesque #metalesquefest

Find us on Twitter:  @SOTBBurlesque

...and please check out our WEBSITE for more video and images at: SIGNOFTHEBEASTBURLESQUE.COM

Thank you so much for helping out!

story:
Who We Are:

Since its founding in 1998, Innervation Dance Cooperative has been finding ways to meld the art forms of theater and dance. The spirit of Innervation Dance Cooperative is one of artistic diversity and cohesive energy. Each dancer and choreographer has a unique background, allowing the company to incorporate multiple disciplines of dance and theater through the combined artistic vision of each member. One of our greatest strengths is the eclectic creative aesthetic produced by encouraging any and all company members to contribute to the creative output of IDC. IDC company members range from dancers fresh out of college, to veterans who have been part of the Chicago dance community for decades. Individuals at both ends of that spectrum and everywhere in between bring unique perspectives to the table.

To date, we have fostered the creativity of over 120 choreographers in the Chicago Dance Community!  Innervation Dance Cooperative is currently also an Artist in Residence at Links Hall and a verified 501(c)(3) non-profit that brings educational outreach to Chicago area schools.

Why This Show Is Different:

This show is something completely new for IDC!  We are breaking the fourth wall, creating our own stage space, and making use of materials in a way that we have never done before.  We are also covering subject matter that is near and dear to many of our hearts which makes this show that much more special to us as a company. While we are using "Through the Looking Glass" as our source material, much of the story-line and characterization has been lovingly created from scratch by members of our Artistic Cooperative.  We are meeting with mental health professionals to make sure our dancers are portraying an accurate representation of the characters we are creating. We are also creating an environment where the audience is very much involved in the show, you are no longer just a spectator.  This show will be the culmination of not only months of hard work in rehearsal but months of long, hard research and introspection on the part of the company as well.

What Your Funds Will Go To:

Venue and Rehearsal Costs

Props, Set, and Costuming

Equipment for a multimedia based performance (projectors, LEDS)

Compensation for our Designers (sound, lighting, etc), Dance and Fight Choreographers, and Dancers

Printing of Promotional Materials (posters, programs, etc)

Fostering of Educational Outreach to the community (workshops, school performances, etc)

Perks and Ticket Information:

Please make sure to check out all the perks we are offering!  There may also be a special perk for any donations over $300.  We aren't telling though! Please follow us on Facebook to stay up to date on show times, dates, and tickets.  Our show is currently set to run March 9-11 2017 at Links Hall.

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/innervationdancecooper...

Other Ways You Can Help:

We know that monetary donations are not always possible.  Here are some of the other ways that you can help IDC on this journey:

Donations of services such as costume making, volunteering at events, promotions

In Kind Donations such as gift cards, goods, or catering for events

Getting the word out by sharing and giving us shout outs on Social Media platforms and through word of mouth

Instagram: innervationdanceco

Twitter: innervationdanceco

IDC would like to thank any and all of our sponsors for everything you do.  We could not do this without you!

story:
Short Summary

YETi was founded in 2015 in order to give young people the opportunity to independently operate a functioning theatre company.

Youth are often represented as naive, sensitive, and incapable, but we believe that, when given opportunities, young people can achieve anything. 

With your contributions, our company will be able to continue in the future and provide arts and financial education for youth.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal this season is $2500. This money will be used to keep our company up and running in the future.

If you donate, you can receive gifts such as, a signed program, free tickets, or a backstage tour on opening night!

Any an all money we get, will be used to make our show the best it can be!

The Impact

Little by little, each play we present helps bring diverse opportunities to theatre. 

For the past two years, we've had very successful plays that have been great hits.

We're a group of youth who understand our impact on theatre, and the impact on our audience.

Risks & Challenges

Disclaimer: Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead contains mature content including strong language, drug and alcohol use, and suggestive material.

Audience age recommendation: 14+.

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Help spread the word about our company and our show or follow us on social media!

Use Indiegogo share tools!

story:
The Story

After Lincoln's assassination, very soon after, the government and the press conspired to tie up the loose strings surrounding the guilty, declare the case neatly solved and the villains all executed.

Nearly 40 years after the official version of the death of Lincoln's assassin, an alternate history emerged! A man claiming to be John Wilkes Booth made a deathbed confession. The "Curse of Booth" tells that story. Part mystery, part adventure, part romance. But is it the Truth?

This is the story of the handsome, acclaimed young actor John Wilkes Booth; loved by many woman, living in high society. What could have led him to throw his glamorous life away and commit  his horrendous crime? Who was really behind it. Someone else was shot in the barn! How did he escape ..... no one could kill him. He outlived everyone and died by his own hand in 1903.

But is it the truth?

The Impact

The story, as we tell it, is inspired by the 1908 book by Finis Bates and there is evidence, even beyond what we present. There is the agreement among the descendants of the large Booth family and of descendants of John Wilkes himself.

What we present exposes as mythology what passes for history and topples idols from their enshrined pedestals.

What We Need

We work-shopped at Tisch. We showcased at The Player's Club. Thanks to the response we're creating the multimedia show.

The medium and the message fit perfectly. The action takes place between the time Booth completes his will and his suicide. Booth reviews his life and the audience shares his experience  through projections that emerge on stage as they flash through his mind.

I am  as inspired by the artistic challenge of mixing of live performer and projections as I have been by the subject matter, the script and actors. We need YOUR help to bring this next phase to fruition.

We're looking to raise $40,000 All funds raised here will go toward filming, editing, and creating a fully mobile stage production that can be mounted in any theater.

What Else?

Please help us get the message out there! Visit our Facebook page and pass along our Indiegogo campaign and get the word out about this exciting, moving and mind-challenging play!

Facebook Page: The-Curse-of-Booth
story_txt:
The Story
After Lincoln's assassination, very soon after, the government and the press conspired to tie up the loose strings surrounding the guilty, declare the case neatly solved and the villains all executed.
Nearly 40 years after the official version of the death of Lincoln's assassin, an alternate history emerged! A man claiming to be John Wilkes Booth made a deathbed confession. The "Curse of Booth" tells that story. Part mystery, part adventure, part romance. But is it the Truth?
This is the story of the handsome, acclaimed young actor John Wilkes Booth; loved by many woman, living in high society. What could have led him to throw his glamorous life away and commit  his horrendous crime? Who was really behind it. Someone else was shot in the barn! How did he escape ..... no one could kill him. He outlived everyone and died by his own hand in 1903.
But is it the truth?
The Impact
The story, as we tell it, is inspired by the 1908 book by Finis Bates and there is evidence, even beyond what we present. There is the agreement among the descendants of the large Booth family and of descendants of John Wilkes himself.
What we present exposes as mythology what passes for history and topples idols from their enshrined pedestals.
What We Need
We work-shopped at Tisch. We showcased at The Player's Club. Thanks to the response we're creating the multimedia show.
The medium and the message fit perfectly. The action takes place between the time Booth completes his will and his suicide. Booth reviews his life and the audience shares his experience  through projections that emerge on stage as they flash through his mind.
I am  as inspired by the artistic challenge of mixing of live performer and projections as I have been by the subject matter, the script and actors. We need YOUR help to bring this next phase to fruition.
We're looking to raise $40,000 All funds raised here will go toward filming, editing, and creating a fully mobile stage production that can be mounted in any theater.
What Else?
Please help us get the message out there! Visit our Facebook page and pass along our Indiegogo campaign and get the word out about this exciting, moving and mind-challenging play!
Facebook Page: The-Curse-of-Booth

story:
"You don't have to be that Jewish, to love Not That Jewish....I encourage you all to see this show." ~ Msgr. Kieran Harrington, WOR Radio, iHeart Radio

"Endearing, witty and quick. You only stop laughing long enough to cry. Piper turns laughter and tears into a memorable theater experience."  
~ Huffington Post

“A very moving comedy. The poignant themes will resonate with a wide audience of theatergoers. This deeply personal story, simultaneously evokes laughter and tears from the audience. Whether you are 'that Jewish' or not, this energetic one-woman autobiographical show is one that can be enjoyed by all and will likely resonate with audiences of all cultures and religions. We loved it!” ~ Irene S. Levine, More Time Travel blog

___________________________

LAUGH IN THE FACE OF THE DARK STUFF

Emmy Award-winner, Monica Piper stars in "Not That Jewish," the story of a girl in search of her place in a community that is often to quick to judge. With humor and compassion, Monica goes from "Not That Jewish" to finding her Jewish heart. And what is it to have a Jewish heart? Compassion, Deeds, Humor, and Acceptance. In these trying times, shouldn't everyone be looking to find their Jewish heart?

Reminiscent of Billy Crystal's 700 Sundays with a peppering of Neil Simon's Lost In Yonkers, Not That Jewish is 90 lightning fast minutes of funny, moving, intimate and inspirational theater.

 

The Impact

Your donation will give community centers in the New York metropolitan area an opportunity to offer free tickets to community members who have suffered from these hate crimes, inviting them to laugh, to cry, to heal. Centers will be able to invite members of their community, both Jewish and not, to an evening in the theatre, that both entertains and educates.Centers may also use tickets to enhance awareness, promote tolerance, and support education through the arts. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share the link to this page on your social media!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

 

More information on the show at NotThatJewish.com

___________________________

"Honest & Touching" ~ Fran Drescher

"Monica Piper has made me laugh for years. Go see her new show!“ 
~ Rosie O’Donnell

"Certified 100% hilarious!" ~ Roseanne Barr

story:
THE FACE BEHIND THE PROJECT

 

I am Sonia González, founder of Teatro Naku, poet and a passionate of life. For 35 years I have been working in the puppet theater. I am the scriptwriter, director and producer of Diary of a Plastic BAG.

 

TEATRO NAKU 

 

Teatro Naku is a theatre group dedicated to the puppet theater since 1989, with headquarters in Caracas-Venezuela. We are dedicated to putting together puppet shows for children and adults. We build our dolls and impart our knowledge to professionals, actors and teachers. We are a new example of cultural self-management designing creative and innovative strategies.

 

 

AWARDS

We have acted in different international scenarios in countries of America, Asia and Europe, receiving important awards, among them:

  • Scenario Award (1991, Italy)
  • Stregagatto (1995, Italy)
  • Jury’s Special Award, Festival of Cannes (2002, France)
  • Harlequin of Gold of Nancy (2002, France)
  • Best Dramaturgy for Puppets Award (2009, Czech Republic)
  • Best Group of Puppets Award (2009, Czech Republic)
  • Best Work of Puppets Theatre Municipal Award (1995, 1999, 2000 and 2002, Venezuela)
  • National Children's Theater Special Award (2003, Venezuela).

 

To see more of Teatro Naku, visit:  http://teatronaku.com

 

DIARY OF A PLASTIC BAG

 

 

This work recreates the life of a plastic bag in a desolate land without human life, in search of answers to its existential questions. With apocalyptic tone, it is a story of survival and hope in the midst of the most difficult and bleak reality.

The Plastic BAG (a teenager about 14 years old) is narrating her story with a typewriter that displays her writing on a screen. The work does not have language barriers, it can be translated without difficulty, as both the dialogues and the narratives unfold to be read in the bottom of the screen.

The use of the resource of scenographic videos complements the history and places in time and space with dreamlike landscapes that awaken the imagination of the spectator. Poetic images, stunning, beautiful and desolate landscapes, real objects that acquire their own life and scenes that by their mixture of drama, humor and music contrast each other.

It is a very cinematic affine with the genres of fiction and science fiction, to make the most of the few resources.

 

CREATION PROCESS

Before writing the script for Diary of a Plastic BAG, I needed an intense six months process of experimentation and improvisation with different plastic materials and the work of object-body harmonization of Naku Theater. The scenes are woven as the work of experimentation is decanted, in a search for synthesis, respecting as far as possible the freshness of unconscious results. And only in the final stage of the assembly do I have a script as a result.

Progressively include the audiovisual elements (music, dubbing, play of lights and shadows, chroma key, video projections) that will give atmosphere and voice to the plastic bag and the rest of the characters.

It adds to the work of experimentation, the creation of a new language, the language of plastic bags that will be subtitled live for the viewer.

 

 

TEAM

Script, direction and production: Sonia González

Original music and sound mix: Jacky Schreiber

Manipulation of puppets: Andrea Nacary Hernández / Gryselt Parra

 

Voices

Plastic BAG: Andreína Faría

Dog: Joe Justiniano

Charming prince: Fernando Azpúrua

Bags on the tree: Mara Alejandra Pacheco, Andrea Nacary Hernández, Gryselt Parra

Hat Man: Gabriel Agüero

Tramp and Shaman: Carlos Sánchez Torrealba

 

Video edition: Tomás Alberto González

Animation: René Alex

Render chroma key: Frans Tabares

Lighting: Enrique Blein

Lighting Design: Sonia González

Scenographer: Pedro Antonio Tortello

 

Promotioinal material design: Alejandro Sotillet

Promotional video edition: Alliot Chacón

Promotional video recording: Ida Febres

 

Crowdfunding and social media; Kenia Conde

 

FIRST SAMPLE

In October 2016, Diary of a Plastic BAG was presented for the first time to the public with a sample of a few minutes of the history that was still under construction.

The public reception was incredible!

It was very satisfying for us since the good reviews allowed us to get a room to present us a season in 2017 and also we could discover the resources that we still needed to finish giving shape to the world of our Plastic BAG.


This was an unprecedented opportunity: to present part of a work in process of creation, so we took the opportunity to deepen the impressions of the public through a survey at the end of the show. The results were very useful for the creative process and improve the quality of the show.

In spite of the critical situation of our country (Venezuela) we are very fortunate to be able to present "Diary of a plastic bag" in a small theater of Caracas called La caja de fósforos, from April 15 to May 7, Saturdays And Sundays at 3pm.

 http://lacajadefosforos.com.ve/


But we do not want the project to die there!

 

SUPPORT OUR PLASTIC BAG!

We need $ 4,000 to reward the effort of the team of collaborators, people who with effort and sacrifice have worked for more than five months in this project putting all their heart in it, despite being in a country which situation leaves us very little space for creation and art.

With this money we can also invest in the audiovisual record and promotion of the work to be able to travel with her nationally and internationally.

Here the detailed budget of these requirements:

 

 

We know the potential of our work and we want Plastic BAG to fly high, raise her voice and reach many other places in the world! This is where your participation begins! With your help we are sure that we can make that Diary of a Plastic BAG can be known by many more people of different languages ​​and nationalities, becoming part of our movement of hope. It is our way of putting a grain of sand to change the world. We believe that we can change the world by doing what we love and that you can do it too!

story:
Burlesque is a socially conscious piece of theatre with the fundamental goal of creating dialogue. Numerous students, whether they have been involved with the production or have simply seen the show in previous years, have come to Lipstick Theatre to express their gratitude and excitement that such a unique, challenging, envelope-pushing, and body positive show is done each year on campus. We are proud of all the wonderful dialogue that continues to spread across campus each year surrounding our production, and we are especially humbled to create a space for marginalized voices that have always existed to celebrate their beautifully complex identities. Lipstick Theatre and everyone involved with Burlesque is committed to creating a safe space for all students regardless of gender presentation, sexual orientation, socioeconomic background, ethnicity, religion, race, or political leanings at NU. This is what makes Burlesque such a unique and vital event for our campus.

Burlesque is growing exponentially as it has become an annual communal experience on Northwestern’s campus. However, in order to continue to support its all-inclusive nature, we need financial assistance to ensure and maintain the safe space we have created for this large cast. Burlesque has come to signify something bigger than Lipstick Theatre can grasp, and we need your help to fulfill its mission of creating thought-provoking dialogue and celebrating identity expression.

story:
Who I am and What the Campaign Is

Introducing myself and my background:

Hi, I’m Cynthia Clay, the artistic director of Storycrafter Studio. I’ve been on international TV as a Shakespeare expert because I passed the Turing Test. I made people think I was a computer program on Shakespeare. I direct, act, and write plays. I received early training from my mother who had trained at the Goodman under David Itkin who worked with Stanislavsky. I also received a degree in theater from Brandeis University (with Latin honors), attended the National Theater Institute at the O’Neil Center, and received an MFA in acting from the University of Georgia. Oh, my dad was also in the theater. He was a director and professor of theater. He and his best friend Daniel Krempel wrote the internationally acclaimed book on theater, The Theatrical Image.

My campaign and why it's important to me:

I love theater, so I opened a theater where I can direct plays by local playwrights, and write plays specifically for the incredible talent that is here in South Florida. Something I’ve really been wanting to do is a Spanish Language play. Miami is a bi-lingual city and I want to welcome everyone to Storycrafter Studio. I also dedicated to gender parity. For those of you unaware it, most plays (more than 75%) are written and directed by men. In the world of music, they tried an experiment. They had the musicians play behind a screen so that they would be accepted into the symphonies based on their playing, not whether they were men or not. From symphonies being filled with more than 75% men it went to 50% men, %50 women. Clearly before that experiment, many of the best musicians were not included in symphonies. The same is true for the theater.

The magnitude of what contributors will help me achieve:

Actors have to brave Miami traffic, sometimes for more than an hour to get to rehearsals and performances. If I had funding, I could pay the actors better, so they would have more than gas money for their artistry and I could attract more actors. If I had funding, I could do more advertising to grow our appreciative audience. If I had funding, everybody would be talking about and going to Storycrafter Studio.

What We Need & What You Get

How much funding we need and where it's going:

Rent is $1350.00/month and each show needs two months for auditions, rehearsal, and performance. Utilities are $100/month in the winter, and more in the summer (we are in Miami!).  Even doing minimalist sets, the sets, lights, costumes, props  all cost $1000/show. I pay the actors and the stage manager for each show, so I need a minimum of $1500.00/show. So for just two shows with casts of four, I need $10000.00

story:
OUR MISSION

Inspirata Theatre Company was first conceived as the brainchild of artistic director Danielle Guy.  Danielle grew up on stage in various capacities, first as a ballerina, and eventually as an actress. She spent her summers training with America’s top Shakespeare company, and after tasting every aspect of theatrical production — from ushering to costuming to performing tech — she fell in love with the idea of directing.  In the winter of 2016, the concept for Inspirata came to her. Although she nurtured this dream for months, it wasn’t until that summer that she met the people who now make up the family that is Inspirata.  Through a journey of midnight meetings, copious amounts of coffee, and piles of paper, they established a plan for their flagship production of William Shakespeare’s Titus Andronicus. 

 

At this point in time, the arts are more important to local communities than ever.  Because of this, we as a company believe it is our duty to produce shows which reflect current events the society at large.  We believe that Titus provides an honest commentary which can be applied to the chaotic nature of our current political life and non-stop media coverage.  Titus will allow us to fully explore the idea of artistic relevance and the role of the social audience in a world forever in conflict with itself and each other. 

 

OUR FUNDRAISER

 

In preparation for this flagship production we are co-launching our annual community fundraiser. This year’s fundraiser will be Halloween in Spring, or “Blood Ball: Spring Samhain ‘17.” The ball will be held in Shepherdstown, West Virginia and will include music, raffle prizes, a presentation on the upcoming production, food and drink, and a costume competition.  Proceeds will fund startup and production costs for Inspirata Theatre Co. and all additional production costs for Titus.

 

As a brand new company, we cannot do any of this without your help.  We at Inspirata have so much to offer our local artistic community.  All we need is a little jump in order to breathe life, through art, back into you!

 

THE COST

$2,000 - Renting the space

$1,000 - Paying performers for Blood Ball/Unexpected Expenses

$315 - Corporation fees

$753 - Estimated Errors & Omissions Insurance for our 1st year

$400 - Advertizing/Blood Ball

$300 - Costumes/Props/Blood

$232 - Incidentals (extension cords, gaffe tape, fire extinguishers)

 

We have just a small window of time to raise these funds.  This campaign only lasts until May 15th to raise funds for Blood Ball and our inaugural production.  We know, it’s a little crazy!  But what is theater without high stakes?  If we are not able to reach our goal, the show must go on!  Unfortunately that means we might cut some of our ideas for advertising, or delaying our digital theatre program, but we shall always look towards the future for those things.

 

 

OUR IMPACT

 

When studying theater, students are taught to ask, “Why this play now?” This is a vital question which determines whether a play is “worth” doing within a season.  In light of that model, as a donor, you must ask “why this company now?”  There are millions of different organizations, all relevant and important and worthy of your support.  Why should you chose us instead of them?

 

Here is our three tiered answer:

 

Local Community:  It is our belief that as a company, our job is to support and reach the needs of the community around us.  For our production of Titus, Inspirata will donate 10% of each performance’s box office proceeds to a different local charity or non-profit.  By doing so, our impact will not end after our last performance, but continue by aiding those in need, as you have done for us.

 

Unified Communities:  As a company comprised of members from PA, MD, VA, and WV, our company is able to touch each community specifically to meet their needs.  Whether it is leading workshops for a school’s English class, providing manual labor to build a set for another community theater, or hosting one of our productions as a special performance, we are excited to help spread the joy of the arts as far as we are possibly able.

 

Digital Communities:  One of the long term goals Inspirata has developed is for a digital theater program, which shall be realized in the flagship production of Titus Andronicus.  Through use of Facebook Live, live streaming, and youtube, it is our aim to create a digital library which may be viewed and enjoyed by those who may not typically make it to a physical performance.

 

Why should you give to Inspirata Theatre Company?  In summary: When you give to Inspirata, you give to many.

 

THE PERKS

We're excited to give back to the community, but we're also ready to give out some awesome incentives to our donors right now! Here are some of the items you can receive if you decide to support Inspirata today:

 

Even if you can only donate $5 (or just spread the word about our campaign) we will be thankful, but a donation of $10 will get you an Inspirata Theatre Company sticker!

 

We can't wait to put together some swag bags to send out to anyone who donates $30 or more!

 

If you donate $50 to our fundraiser you get a free ticket to the flagship production you're helping fund!

 

As part of our $75 Tribune Perk you will also get a ticket to Blood Ball and drink tickets, we'd love to have you come party with us!

 

If you donate $100 we won't be able to thank you enough but let us start by giving you the General Perk! We hope that at Blood Ball those raffle tickets serve you well and you win something great!

 

With a $150 donation you are a true friend of local theatre so enjoy our Queen Perk! You get to rep Inspirata swag, see our shows for free, party with us at Blood Ball, become a company member, and attend our special premiere event! Inspirata Theatre Company Membership (usually costs $25- but for you is included with your donation!) means that you'll get advance notice about special events and ticket sales, insider info about the company, and be invited to attend an annual company meeting.

 

For a $200 donation you become an official producer of the show! That means that you will be listed in the program, and you'll receive some program ad space to give a shoutout or dedication to a local person or business.

If you want to go above and beyond to help us out then a donation of $225+ will get you all of the Emperor Perks stated above, PLUS you will get a special invite to our first rehearsal! Get the very first sneak peek by watching the entire cast read through the play for the first time and discuss the company's artistic vision for the show!

And if you are an exceptionally giving person and would like to donate $500+ dollars we will be forever grateful! You will not only receive all of the Emperor Perks AND an invitation to the first rehearsal - we will name our first scholarship after you! 10% of the proceeds from Titus ticket sales will go towards establishing Inspirata Theatre Company's first arts scholarship. One of our company goals is to establish several annual scholarships that local young people interested in the arts may be able to apply for. Causes the scholarships may be applied to would be: assisting worthy individuals with tuition for theatre camps or courses, supplying financial aid to students looking to study theatre in college, funding local school theatre classes or special productions, bringing a performing troupe into the community for educational purposes, etc. and we would love to name our initial scholarship after an arts patron as generous as you!

 

OUR UPDATES

We're so excited to have you join us in this journey to produce our first show - please stay in touch via social media and looking out for our campaign updates! You can expect to find out more about Blood Ball, Titus Andronicus, our artistic vision, the members of our company, Inspirata's future goals, and what progress we're making very soon. Thank you for supporting the arts!
story_txt: OUR MISSIONInspirata Theatre Company was first conceived as the brainchild of artistic director Danielle Guy.  Danielle grew up on stage in various capacities, first as a ballerina, and eventually as an actress. She spent her summers training with America’s top Shakespeare company, and after tasting every aspect of theatrical production — from ushering to costuming to performing tech — she fell in love with the idea of directing.  In the winter of 2016, the concept for Inspirata came to her. Although she nurtured this dream for months, it wasn’t until that summer that she met the people who now make up the family that is Inspirata.  Through a journey of midnight meetings, copious amounts of coffee, and piles of paper, they established a plan for their flagship production of William Shakespeare’s Titus Andronicus.  At this point in time, the arts are more important to local communities than ever.  Because of this, we as a company believe it is our duty to produce shows which reflect current events the society at large.  We believe that Titus provides an honest commentary which can be applied to the chaotic nature of our current political life and non-stop media coverage.  Titus will allow us to fully explore the idea of artistic relevance and the role of the social audience in a world forever in conflict with itself and each other.  OUR FUNDRAISER In preparation for this flagship production we are co-launching our annual community fundraiser. This year’s fundraiser will be Halloween in Spring, or “Blood Ball: Spring Samhain ‘17.” The ball will be held in Shepherdstown, West Virginia and will include music, raffle prizes, a presentation on the upcoming production, food and drink, and a costume competition.  Proceeds will fund startup and production costs for Inspirata Theatre Co. and all additional production costs for Titus. As a brand new company, we cannot do any of this without your help.  We at Inspirata have so much to offer our local artistic community.  All we need is a little jump in order to breathe life, through art, back into you! THE COST$2,000 - Renting the space$1,000 - Paying performers for Blood Ball/Unexpected Expenses$315 - Corporation fees$753 - Estimated Errors & Omissions Insurance for our 1st year$400 - Advertizing/Blood Ball$300 - Costumes/Props/Blood$232 - Incidentals (extension cords, gaffe tape, fire extinguishers) We have just a small window of time to raise these funds.  This campaign only lasts until May 15th to raise funds for Blood Ball and our inaugural production.  We know, it’s a little crazy!  But what is theater without high stakes?  If we are not able to reach our goal, the show must go on!  Unfortunately that means we might cut some of our ideas for advertising, or delaying our digital theatre program, but we shall always look towards the future for those things.  OUR IMPACT When studying theater, students are taught to ask, “Why this play now?” This is a vital question which determines whether a play is “worth” doing within a season.  In light of that model, as a donor, you must ask “why this company now?”  There are millions of different organizations, all relevant and important and worthy of your support.  Why should you chose us instead of them? Here is our three tiered answer: Local Community:  It is our belief that as a company, our job is to support and reach the needs of the community around us.  For our production of Titus, Inspirata will donate 10% of each performance’s box office proceeds to a different local charity or non-profit.  By doing so, our impact will not end after our last performance, but continue by aiding those in need, as you have done for us. Unified Communities:  As a company comprised of members from PA, MD, VA, and WV, our company is able to touch each community specifically to meet their needs.  Whether it is leading workshops for a school’s English class, providing manual labor to build a set for another community theater, or hosting one of our productions as a special performance, we are excited to help spread the joy of the arts as far as we are possibly able. Digital Communities:  One of the long term goals Inspirata has developed is for a digital theater program, which shall be realized in the flagship production of Titus Andronicus.  Through use of Facebook Live, live streaming, and youtube, it is our aim to create a digital library which may be viewed and enjoyed by those who may not typically make it to a physical performance. Why should you give to Inspirata Theatre Company?  In summary: When you give to Inspirata, you give to many. THE PERKSWe're excited to give back to the community, but we're also ready to give out some awesome incentives to our donors right now! Here are some of the items you can receive if you decide to support Inspirata today: Even if you can only donate $5 (or just spread the word about our campaign) we will be thankful, but a donation of $10 will get you an Inspirata Theatre Company sticker! We can't wait to put together some swag bags to send out to anyone who donates $30 or more! If you donate $50 to our fundraiser you get a free ticket to the flagship production you're helping fund! As part of our $75 Tribune Perk you will also get a ticket to Blood Ball and drink tickets, we'd love to have you come party with us! If you donate $100 we won't be able to thank you enough but let us start by giving you the General Perk! We hope that at Blood Ball those raffle tickets serve you well and you win something great! With a $150 donation you are a true friend of local theatre so enjoy our Queen Perk! You get to rep Inspirata swag, see our shows for free, party with us at Blood Ball, become a company member, and attend our special premiere event! Inspirata Theatre Company Membership (usually costs $25- but for you is included with your donation!) means that you'll get advance notice about special events and ticket sales, insider info about the company, and be invited to attend an annual company meeting. For a $200 donation you become an official producer of the show! That means that you will be listed in the program, and you'll receive some program ad space to give a shoutout or dedication to a local person or business.If you want to go above and beyond to help us out then a donation of $225+ will get you all of the Emperor Perks stated above, PLUS you will get a special invite to our first rehearsal! Get the very first sneak peek by watching the entire cast read through the play for the first time and discuss the company's artistic vision for the show!And if you are an exceptionally giving person and would like to donate $500+ dollars we will be forever grateful! You will not only receive all of the Emperor Perks AND an invitation to the first rehearsal - we will name our first scholarship after you! 10% of the proceeds from Titus ticket sales will go towards establishing Inspirata Theatre Company's first arts scholarship. One of our company goals is to establish several annual scholarships that local young people interested in the arts may be able to apply for. Causes the scholarships may be applied to would be: assisting worthy individuals with tuition for theatre camps or courses, supplying financial aid to students looking to study theatre in college, funding local school theatre classes or special productions, bringing a performing troupe into the community for educational purposes, etc. and we would love to name our initial scholarship after an arts patron as generous as you! OUR UPDATESWe're so excited to have you join us in this journey to produce our first show - please stay in touch via social media and looking out for our campaign updates! You can expect to find out more about Blood Ball, Titus Andronicus, our artistic vision, the members of our company, Inspirata's future goals, and what progress we're making very soon. Thank you for supporting the arts!

story:
Short Summary

We are Melissa Ortiz, Cassandra Ambe and David Kayser, founders of Cadame Co. - a team of artists who strive to produce artwork in multiple mediums, including immersive theater performance, music, film, and handcrafted visual art. We are presenting our work, The Rise and Fall of Dracula at the Hollywood Fringe Festival 2017. 

It is an original script that fuses contemporary dance, reimagined myths, and original music to tell a story of Power, Belief, and Companionship.

Show Dates:
Saturday, June 3rd  - 8:00pm
Friday, June 9th - 8:30pm
Thursday, June 15th - 10:00pm
Sunday, June 18th - 5:30pm
Saturday, June 24th - 11:30pm

What We Need & What You Get

We Need:

Fringe Registration Fees

Venue Fees

Marketing

Costumes

Specialty Lighting/Props

And blood - because it is a vampire story, after all.

What You Get:

$1 - High five when we see you!

$10 - Shout out on Facebook plus previous perks.

$25 - Character study poem from Dracula plus previous perks.

$50 - Cast signed poster plus previous perks.

$100 - Digital download of original music by David Kayser plus previous perks.

$250 - Framed sheet music of Dracula’s theme plus previous perks.

$500 - Signed copy of script plus previous perks.

$1,000 - Dracula’s cape, used in production of the play, plus previous perks.

 

The Impact

We are offering a fresh perspective on a classic story with a focus on ethnic diversity and gender equality. This production focuses on the female perspective; with a female writer, director, choreographers, and a diverse cast. The Rise and Fall of Dracula brings a unique take on an age old tale. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially to the campaign we would welcome anyone to join our street team to promote the show. For more information please contact info@cadamecompany.com
