story:
The 24 Hour What The...?

What is the 24 Hour Musical? We produce a full-scale musical in 24 hours.

"But how? and why? and how?"

Here's the how:

 

Pick a show (done!)

Hold auditions... without telling anyone what the show is

Cast the show... without telling anyone what their roles are

Release a shortlist of 10 shows, 10 days from the performance

Remove a show from the list each day until...

Bring the musical theatre community of Greater Brisbane together for 24 hours of mayhem and mirth!

Have a fancy dinner and ANNOUNCE THE SHOW

24 HOURS LATER, THE CURTAIN GOES UP!

Take all the profit we made from ticket sales and donations on the night, and give it away to local charities in need. Which charities? That's going to be up to you.

Go home and sleeeeeeeep...

And here's the why:

Because we can. Because it's a challenge. Because it's a project to build and strengthen community. Because working together is AWESOME. Because we can raise money for good causes. Because why not?! Because it will be the experience of a lifetime! Because all the reasons you could possible come up with!!

Everyone involved will have their own reasons for wanting to be part of this exciting (slightly crazy) project, these are just a few of ours - what's yours?

 

What We Need...

Our starting goal is $4,800 to cover the performance rights, venue hire and insurance for this event. These are the essentials to confirm that the project can go ahead.

Any funds raised beyond that will go toward production costs - i.e. costumes, sets, props, technical equipment and possibly even special effects and bonuses (see our stretch goals below)!

Essentially, the more funds we can raise before we start, the better we can make the production; and furthermore, the less costs we need to cover with ticket sales, the more potential we have to raise community donations on the night.

STRETCH GOALS:  Once we hit our campaign goal, here's what else happens when we raise even more funds*:

$6,000 - we provide free programs to the audience

$10,000 - we waive the production fee for participants

$12,500 - we provide a supper for the audience following the performance

$15,000 - we add an impressive "special effect" to the production

$17,500 - we produce a 24 Hour Musical documentary

 

...& What You Get

Most of our Perks include tickets to the show, starting at $24. Whether you think you'll use them yourself or pass them on to friends (for instance, if you're cast in the show!) investing in pre-purchasing tickets through the perk helps to ensure the project has enough support to go ahead. 

Some perks (starting at $48) include VIP tickets - here and now is the only way to get your hands on VIP passes! VIPs get priority seating meaning not only do they get the best seats in the house, but they are allowed into the theatre 30mins before curtain, when last minute rehearsals may still be going on!

For those who want to be even more involved, check out the higher level perks that include joining us for the announcement dinner, sitting in on rehearsals or even being touted as the Producer!

Q: What if I want to audition or volunteer to work on the project? Why would I select a perk that includes tickets I might not be able to use?   A: The perks are all fully transferable - if you select a perk with tickets or special access and then you are cast in the show, you can pass those tickets on to family or friends to use. Remember, your contribution is funding the project in the first place, and if we don't reach our goal it may not go ahead!

 

What Your Contribution Means To Us

By helping to fund this project, you become part of our local theatre community. We hope that an annual event like this can become a great networking opportunity for the many growing and flourishing companies in the greater Brisbane area.

And... the more money we raise before we start, then the more we can raise on the night for our charitable causes! Everyone who attends will be able to nominate where project profits are donated by 'donating' their ticket stub to either of our selected charitable causes. 

 

What If We Don't Make It???

If the campaign doesn't reach the goal, then we thank you for your generous contributions and put them toward covering as many of the costs as we can.

We recognise that some things may not go to plan, even so, we will do everything within (and slightly beyond!) our power to ensure the project goes ahead.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute to the campaign right now, if you want to be involved in any way - audition, volunteer as crew, front-of-house or support team - we would love to hear from you.

Visit our website: https://24hourmusical.wordpress.com/  to sign up to the mailing list (click on the Oprah meme!) or register specifically to receive more info about Auditions or Volunteering when it becomes available.

story:
Romantika is a theatre, performance, and visual arts company based in London. We aim to create unique, visually striking and international performance work that reflects our current time.

 

We currently have two productions: The Crossing Place and What Lies Beneath. The next step for Romantika involves the Edinburgh fringe festival, as well as a number of other domestic and international fringe festivals throughout Europe. Our destinations include:  

The Space, London from the 6th to the 10th of June
Théâtre de Ménilmontant, Paris at the Dreams Before Dawn Festival
Upperchurch Summerhall at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival
The Monkey house at Zoo venues at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival
We also hope to visit Birmingham, Manchester and the countries involved with the Nordic Fringe Festival 

This step requires a lot time and money. Your support would help us to take both shows to as many people as possible and further the company at a crucial stage in our development!

More info about the shows:

The Crossing Place

"Three strangers meet in the middle of nowhere, in a Crossing Place far from the communications network of civilisation. In their meeting, seemingly with nothing in common, their only means of communication slowly but surely begins to break down until nothing is left"

Through violent physical theatre, the spoken poetry of Tranströmer and the music of Franz Schubert, the piece explores what it is to be alone and scared in a world that leaves us wanting. The Crossing Place stages Tranströmer's writing in a way we believe hasn’t been done before. We’re excited to take the piece to as many people as possible!

The piece was first devised by Romantika in Tallinn, Estonia. It has since been performed at Rose Bruford College in London and the Västmanlands Teater in Sweden.

 

What Lies Beneath

“She’s gone, leaving no answers that can satisfy. He finds himself in the stillness of nature, hoping perhaps that he can make things clear. Descending into madness brought on by hypothermia, a man confronts memories of friends and family in a series of non-linear and increasingly surreal flashbacks."

In Romantika's latest production, the company takes the audience on a surreal and humorous journey, exploring men's reluctance to express their emotions, with specific focus on grief in western society. Juxtaposing comedy with tragedy, and realism with surrealism, the production involves elements of visual and physical theatre, live Scandinavian folk music, and a set and lighting design inspired by the Northern Lapland landscapes.

story:
I have been singing all my life. I got the performing bug when I was in junior high and it continued through high school. I studied  acting and directing at California State University, Long Beach and then moved to NYC to study musical theatre at the American Musical and Dramatic Academy. Over the years, I've been fortunate to enjoy a career, both performing and teaching, as well as meet and marry my husband and raise our beautiful daughter.  

I have always followed the philosophy that if you make your own work, you are never out of work. I wanted to take that a step further.

It all started when...

my roles of mother and teacher inspired a newfound passion to explore how families and relationships, specifically the mother role, are examined and portrayed in the arts. "Time To Fly" is a phrase I often use when my students are preparing to graduate or take the next step in their careers. It is also something I think about when I see my family and friends on the verge of a new chapter in their lives and how much courage it takes to spread our wings and fly towards the unknown with an open heart and an open mind.

My mission in starting Time To Fly Productions LLC is to mount theatrical productions, concerts and solo work and provide opportunities for new and established artists that inspire, nurture, challenge, amaze, educate and empower both the artist and audience.

I also believe in giving back to the community and helping organizations that serve it. Therefore, a portion of the proceeds for each show that my company produces will be donated to a charity that directly relates to the theme of the show.

I chose "Next To Normal" for my company's first production because I remember the effect the show had on me when I first saw it. I was a new mother who had a complicated pregnancy and the subject touched me deeply. My understanding of mental health was minimal and it made me want to explore and learn more about it. Needless to say, the light was beginning to shine brightly and I knew it was a show and role I wanted to investigate further and bring to an audience who may not have had the chance to see the original production. 

In the past few years, I have been affected personally by those who have suffered from some mental health condition. I am hopeful that by bringing this show back it can help bring some light to the darkness in which so many people live.

Our fundraising goal is $7,000. These funds will go to rehearsals and performances, production requirements and to compensate the creative team, actors, musicians and management for their work and dedication in bringing this story back. The funds will go directly to these and any additional contributions will go towards the company's next production. 

If you are unable to contribute financially, we still would welcome and appreciate your support by getting the word out about this campaign and helping both Time To Fly Productions and "Next To Normal" take flight.

Needless to say, the light was beginning to shine brightly and I knew it was a show and role I wanted to investigate further and bring to an audience who may not have had the chance to see the original production. In the past few years, I have been affected personally by those who have suffered from some mental health condition. I am hopeful that by bringing this show back it can help bring some light to the darkness in which so many people live.Our fundraising goal is $7,000. These funds will go to rehearsals and performances, production requirements and to compensate the creative team, actors, musicians and management for their work and dedication in bringing this story back. The funds will go directly to these and any additional contributions will go towards the company's next production. If you are unable to contribute financially, we still would welcome and appreciate your support by getting the word out about this campaign and helping both Time To Fly Productions and "Next To Normal" take flight.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
I was selected to receive a green card from the DV-Green Card lottery!!! While this is such an exciting honor, there are a lot of expenses involved and I need your help.

I come from an island in the Mediterranean Sea called Cyprus and I have always dreamt of being a dancer in the USA, a passion of mine that started from a young age.

In 2013 I was able to make my dream a reality! I was accepted into the American Musical and Dramatic Academy, a college in NYC to study Dance Theater. My journey was challenging and it felt like a roller coaster with many ups and downs, I learnt so many valuable lessons about myself as a performer and also as a person. It was so hard being away from family but their constant love and support kept me going.

After graduating successfully from college and hustling for a couple of months in New York, I moved to Las Vegas to accept a contract in the show Jubilee. It was one of the best decisions I have ever made! I was able to survive financially by doing what I love plus save money to go towards the lawyer and immigration fees in order to get a new work visa.

My first 1 year working visa has recently expired and I have not been able to work since June. My work visa has been PENDING for almost 6 months. I feel STUCK.  It has been one of the toughest times for me, I am not even sure how I am surviving financially because I still need to pay rent and afford to live. All my savings have gone towards the working visa, costing me about $6000.

Although everything seems to be so difficult and almost impossible, I just received some unexpected, amazing news! I won the DV-Green Card Lottery out of millions of applicants! This means I'll be able to get a Green Card, become a permanent resident and continue to pursue this crazy dream of mine!

How do i feel? Overwhelmed and deeply grateful after everything that has happened to me.

So now I have to go through a large process, pay more fees to the lawyer and make sure everything is finalized so I don't miss out on this very exciting opportunity. I will also need to fly back home to Cyprus and have an interview at the embassy which all adds up to quite a lot of money.

I'm not asking you to donate much, every little bit helps and I appreciate anything you can give :) your generosity means EVERYTHING to me. 

A dancer from Cyprus who is following his heart and passion.

:)

story:
The project

Rencontres/Encounters (R/E) is an engaged, intercultural theatre initiative that is heading towards  public performances from January 20th-23rd 2016. 
We are looking for funds to support the rental of our space, the realization of our design, and to be able to offer tickets on a Pay What You Can basis.

Photo: David Ward

Who are we?

R/E believes that another person’s perspective can be better understood (though never even close to fully understood) through storytelling, dialogue, and through performance of oneself, and of another. New ways of seeing ourselves and others are illuminated, making visible both the real and perceived boundaries that prevent relationship and community between people of different immigration statuses, racializations, sexualities, gender identities, classes, faiths, abilities and other intersecting factors.

R/E's work asks:

 What Are the Differences That Matter?
What Are We Not Talking About?

Encounters will be joined in performance with our partners at RECAA (Respecting Elders, Communities Against Abuse), who will join us in our public performance. 

Photo: David Ward

               

Photos: Saul Garcia Lopez

Where your donation will go

We are looking for funds to cover production costs - these are:

  • Absorbing the cost of tickets to make all tickets Pay What You Can
  • Rental of the MAI gallery, our fantastic venue
  • Materials for set and costume design 
  • Equipment rental including speakers and projectors
Our perks include signed posters, program mentions, and personal songs sung over the phone! Additionally you can live happily knowing that you are supporting original new work!

Photo: David Ward 

The Impact

The project leading up to this public performance spans more than 5 years. In supporting this public performance you are making the work more accessible (by making the tickets PWYC) and helping realize a cohesive design that will support the work. This project has a significant role in creating and strengthening intergenerational community ties, including our partnership with RECAA. Support for the public performance will support RECAA's involvement in the public performance. R/E aims to offer possibilities for transformation in understanding of others and otherness in a range of community contexts.

Photo: David Ward

Other Ways You Can Help!

If you don't have cash to spare, you can still support Rencontres/Encounters through other ways!

  • Share this fundraiser! 
  • Attend the show!
  • Promote the show!

Photo: David Ward

We are grateful for all of the support you are able to offer as we embark on our production journey :)

story:
Produce a Circus in NYC!!!

Circo de la Luna will cost $43,000 total to create total.  (Ticket sales will contribute to this number).  

We must raise $16,000 by the end of February to cover pre-show expenses for marketing, stage design and architectural photography to further the cultural experience for the audience.  

To make a tax-deductible donation,  please click here for our Fractured Atlas link:  

https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=13711

Donations made on this indiegogo site are not tax deductible, but all of the perks mentioned here will be honored on the Fractured Atlas site - just send an email to info@circodelaluna.com to tell us which perk you have chosen.

“Circo de la Luna” - is very exciting to me, an aerialist with 20 years of performance experience around the globe creating evenings for numerous of special events -  because I have created it for my own tastes, with my very favorite performers, creatives, and production team. It will be staged over two nights April 21 and 22 (with one invitation-only dress rehearsal on April 20) in the city at Baruch Rose Nagelburg Theater on 25th and Lexington Ave. 

Circo de la Luna is a hybrid circus charged with wonderful Flamenco and Latin music, starring the flamenco dancer Sonia Olla accompanied by Ismael Fernandez!  The aerial choreography is created by Sonia Olla and Ballet Hispanico choreographer, Pedro Ruiz.  Mark Lonergan (Parallel Exit and Big Apple Circus) has signed on as Director.  Acts will include comedy by Mark Gindick (Wingman and Big Apple Circus), Boleadoras by AJ Silver (Hungarian National Circus), Aerial Lyra by Sarah Sophie Flicker (Citizen’s Band), and Contortion by Olga Karmansky (Pippin original cast) and Anna Venezelos (former Cirque du Soleil). Circo de la Luna celebrates the love of foreign neighbors, culture, music and dance - especially Flamenco! It is an attempt to rise above the usual NYC variety show formed out of necessity due to lack of time and funds and to be able to bond a unique performance troupe with the ultimate luxury of time to rehearse, shine and polish! You can learn more about the project at www.circodelaluna.com. 

What We Need & What You Get


We need 16,000 by the end of February to cover pre-show costs including theater payment, set pieces, marketing and pr, rehearsal and photography for our videographer to use in the acts as backdrops for New York, Spain and Cuba.  

You will get a phenomenal show that will leave you energized and dancing out of Baruch Theater!  Buying a ticket through our indiegogo will save you a $7 ticket processing fee on ticket web, and if you donate or choose the full-price premier seating option, you will be helping a student or artist see the show at an affordable rate.  

Ever wonder what it takes to put on a little show in NYC?  Of course, the show must go on no matter what level is reached, but check out this example of the costs of an off off Broadway show that includes production:

Example of what a minimal NYC show costs from bare minimum to creation:

$7000:  We will have secured the THEATER and you will be escorted by Baruch's ushers to a seat in a quiet dark room for two hours.  You are free to meditate, take a nap or use your iPhone, but the reception is pretty bad.  

$12,550:  We can add LIGHT, SOUND and VIDEO.  I can dj and put some vacation slides in the projector, and a stage manager can select audience volunteers to give random speeches and poetry readings.  

$19,050 WE HAVE GROUND PERFORMERS TO ENTERTAIN YOU - HOORAY!

$23,550 AERIALISTS AND RIGGERS CAN BE ADDED to create the typical variety show you see in NYC.

$34,450  We can hire DIRECTOR, CHOREOGRAPHER and add SET DESIGN. We can buy INSURANCE. The performers will have direction, and a stage to interact on!  A SHOW IS BORN!!  We are no longer a bare-boned variety night.

$43,450  Our photographer/videographer can take architectural photos in Spain and Cuba to add to the set design, we can pay for operating expenses like flyers, water and coffee, we can rent rehearsal space, we can do PR.  We might even be able to get an intern or two to help with marketing so I could get some sleep!

Everyone is accepting less than their normal rates.  Flights will be paid for mainly with donated miles.  People are sleeping on couches and doing rehearsals for little or nothing.  Musicians will be paid out of pocket for rehearsals.  This is actually a really good bargain for a NYC show of this caliber!

The Impact

We want to move you!!  We could cover the entire cost of Circo de la Luna with ticket sales if we were to sell tickets starting at $105, but we want the show to be accessible to all budgets, with tickets ranging from $35 to $75, and further discounts for special groups. 

  • This is your opportunity to become a producer for an energetic and unique combination of circus, dance and latin music that will move you like no other!
  • For over 15 years I have enjoyed putting shows together for corporate events for companies like Armani Exchange, Herbalife, Nikon, Microstrategy, Gen Art, Liberty Science Museum, Susan G Komen, Miller - the list goes on.  Finally I am putting together my own dream and pulling you into my world!
  • I am offering full transparency to all producers who donate on this page.  I am happy to offer up our budget and expenditures at any point.  

Risks & Challenges

  • This show will go on no matter what $ Goal is reached.  If we pass our goal we will be able to cover indiegogo and paypal fees, add a smoke machine, offer a little celebration to our donors and perhaps have traveling crew stay in a hotel instead of a couch.
  • This is a super cast and very experienced production crew.  We all believe in this project and are committed to making it blow your minds no matter what challenges we face along the way.  

Other Ways You Can Help

  • We understand that not everyone is in the position to become a circus producer.  You can also help by sharing this indigogo campaign using the share tools on the site with others who are interested, like our fb page, spread the word about the show, and check out our website www.circodelaluna.com

story:
The Vision

We are Emily Maghanoy and Jessilee Windhaus, performing artists and directors of the sketch comedy ensemble That Plus Chips. We are Sacramento residents committed to supporting the creativity of small performing arts groups. We believe that art is what connects and expands us. A seven-year old friend of ours said it best after listening to her first musical, "it fills the spaces in my heart". 

Many small performing arts groups struggle to find available space in appropriately-sized performance and practice venues. Our goal is to create a performance and practice space that is professional, organized and financially accessible for smaller community theater groups. Empire Arts Collective will combine the power of the sharing economy to remove the barriers to entry for small groups and creatives beginning their journey.

Our dream is to create a physical space where small groups of people can create art that fills the spaces in our hearts.

What We Need & What You Get ;)

We've created  a top-notch business plan to ensure that, in the long run, Empire Arts Collective will be financially supported by the groups that use its facilities, but we need some help to get started. We've estimated that we'll need $75,000 to start up. This amount includes funds to build the interior of the space and to cover the first year's expenses (rent, utilities, insurance, etc.)

Everyone who helps and contributes to build Empire Arts Collective will be joining a long history of patrons of the arts whose contribution is as vital as the performers and creatives working there. You will be the protagonists of Empire Art Collective's story! We want to make sure, though, that you get a little something extra, so we're working with our sketch group That Plus Chips to provide some special perks to contributors.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not ready or able to contribute financially? There are tons of other ways to help out!

1. Help us get the word out! Make some noise within your groups of friends, family, and contacts.

2. Share it on social media. Time to bust out the share button and your best emojis!

3. Can you build stuff, paint stuff, write contracts, etc? We'll need lots of pro-bono support as well. Contact us at www.empireartscollective.com to tell us how you'd like to contribute!

story:
FROM THE PLAYWRIGHT...

Ok, Take 2 of "From Where I Sit".  Standby... and ACTION!!

Hi, I’m Bill Vila. You might not know me, but you will. I want to tell you about a wonderful new play I wrote about the work I do - as a long-haul, over-the-road bus driver. Now before you go "so what?" let me ask you this:

How many TV shows, movies or plays depicting work of policemen, firemen, doctors, even plumbers and prostitutes have you seen? I bet quite a few. 

Can you say the same about a bus driver (and NO, Ralph Kramden does not count)?  Well, that’s where I come in.

Look, I'm pretty sure the only times you think of (or hear about) bus drivers are when “we’re late,” an accident or when someone gets hit, to name a few. I want to shift the tide of negativity (which rains upon us regularly) and bring to your attention how we view our work and dare I say our passion - for driving a bus.  There’s a lot of us worldwide who LOVE driving a bus, but our stories are not being told. I propose to change that by sharing with you some of my antics and to dispel the notion that 

“Lookie here, lookie here, I got the job ‘cause I can steer”

was the motivation for doing this work.

People, if I had the money to do this production the way I’ve envisioned it, this would have been done YEARS ago, but instead of hoping I’ll hit the lottery or book a national network TV commercial, I need YOUR help to make it happen and since life doesn’t exist in a vacuum, it’s time for the driver to ask passengers for help.

I have an EXCEL chart detailing all the financial specifics for the FIRST STEP and will gladly make it available as a PDF to you upon request.

All of our perks will acknowledge your contribution with a profound THANK YOU in our program, ‘cause let's face it: if you don’t “pay the fare,” there’s no bus.  Now, that said, the deeper you contribute, the more you’ll (and we’ll) get out of it.

You like music? We have a theme song we’ll provide (written by the playwright - me) as a CD (or equivalent). We have free tickets to the mounted Showcase (and tickets for Opening Night!), as well as an opportunity to hang at the OPENING NIGHT PARTY, if you so desire.

My producer (EMP Theatricals) is committed to mounting this production ‘cause simply put, she gets me – "it has to be done!" – SO, if we’re unable to reach our time-sensitive goals now, we’ll launch another campaign, and another, and another, UNTIL we reach the FIRST STOP.  A new bus of the type I drive usually weighs around 50,000 pounds standing still and EMPTY.  I’m asking YOU to help push it up a hill – the hill being the inaugural performance of "From Where I Sit." And from where I sit, with your help, we'll keep the wheels turning.

Thank you all in advance for your contributions and for spreading the word!

Oh, btw, THANKS to Jim Murphy of Saddle River Tours for the use of their bus for this pitch.  Jimmy, YOU ROCK!!!!!
story_txt:
FROM
THE PLAYWRIGHT...
Ok, Take 2 of "From Where I Sit".  Standby... and ACTION!!Hi,
I’m Bill Vila. You might not know me, but you will. I want to tell you about a
wonderful new play I wrote about the work I do - as a long-haul, over-the-road
bus driver. Now before you go "so what?" let me ask you this:
How
many TV shows, movies or plays depicting work of policemen, firemen,
doctors, even plumbers and prostitutes have you seen? I bet quite a
few. 
Can
you say the same about a bus driver (and NO, Ralph Kramden does not
count)?  Well, that’s where I come in.
Look,
I'm pretty sure the only times you think of (or hear about) bus drivers are
when “we’re late,” an accident or when someone gets hit, to name a few. I want
to shift the tide of negativity (which rains upon us regularly) and bring to
your attention how we view our work and dare I say our passion - for driving a
bus.  There’s a lot of us worldwide who LOVE driving a bus, but our
stories are not being told. I propose to change that by sharing with you some
of my antics and to dispel the notion that 
“Lookie here, lookie here, I got the job
‘cause I can steer”
was
the motivation for doing this work.
People,
if I had the money to do this production the way I’ve envisioned it, this would
have been done YEARS ago, but instead of hoping I’ll hit the lottery or book a
national network TV commercial, I need YOUR help to make it
happen and since life doesn’t exist in a vacuum, it’s time for the driver to
ask passengers for help.
I
have an EXCEL chart detailing all the financial specifics for the FIRST STEP
and will gladly make it available as a PDF to you upon request.
All
of our perks will acknowledge your contribution with a profound THANK YOU in
our program, ‘cause let's face it: if you don’t “pay the fare,” there’s no bus.
 Now, that said, the deeper you contribute, the more you’ll (and
we’ll) get out of it.
You
like music? We have a theme song we’ll provide (written by the playwright - me)
as a CD (or equivalent). We have free tickets to the mounted
Showcase (and tickets for Opening Night!), as well as an opportunity to hang at
the OPENING NIGHT PARTY, if you so desire.
My
producer (EMP Theatricals) is committed to mounting this production ‘cause
simply put, she gets me – "it has to be done!" – SO, if we’re unable
to reach our time-sensitive goals now, we’ll launch another campaign, and
another, and another, UNTIL we reach the FIRST STOP.  A new bus of the
type I drive usually weighs around 50,000 pounds standing still and
EMPTY.  I’m asking YOU to help push it up a hill – the hill being the
inaugural performance of "From Where I Sit." And from where I sit,
with your help, we'll keep the wheels turning.

Thank you all in advance for your contributions and for spreading the word!Oh, btw, THANKS to Jim Murphy of Saddle River Tours for the use of their bus for this pitch.  Jimmy, YOU ROCK!!!!!

story:
Here we go! 

The Ask: Arden Winant and Genée Coreno lead Wirehead Collective’s third official production, Descendants of the Chalice. This is a devised and feminist performance inspired by Judy Chicago’s The Dinner Party. 

We need your help to raise $6,000 dollars to: cover the rehearsal rental costs and production expenses and pay our performers 

What is DOTC anyway? Descendants of the Chalice uses The Dinner Party by Judy Chicago, Heritage Panels, and Heritage Floor as the initial source material to generate movement, text, rituals, and media content about these 39 powerful women and their potent legacy. Our all female ensemble and artistic team will devise a massive-millennial-ceremony to celebrate the accomplishments and herstories we’ve inherited from the women. 

We have selected 9 out of Judy’s original 39 for Descendants of the Chalice. These women include Kali, Hateshepsut,Theodora, Boadecia, Petronilla de Meath, Elizabeth R, Sacajawea, Mary Wollstonecraft,and Sojourner Truth. Never fear! The remaining thirty women will be represented and influence the piece!  

Workshop Details: The initial 12-day development workshop of DOTC will take place from January 18-29, 2016 in New York City.  At the culmination of this development workshop we will hold an early process showing. Not only will DOTC undergo an intense process of research, experimentation, and creation (devising) over the twelve days but, all of our designers will be in the room with us  sketching, constructing, building, scoring, and testing out their initial artistic impulses with the ensemble.

Project Goals: Our goal is to use Descendants of the Chalice to educate our audience. They will leave the theater with the ability to tell the story of each woman. It will use the past to explore and draw comparisons to our experience as women in 2015/2016 (aka NOW). Dialoguing the past and present in this way, we will illuminate the pervasive institutional and political oppression we see and feel today. The Dinner Party represents women from different cultural and racial backgrounds and we are committed to representing each woman accordingly.

What is Wirehead Collective? Wirehead Collective is an ensemble of lawless and unapologetic feminist-artists who implement performance, installation and media interventions defined by in-yer-face aesthetics & disruptive techniques to instigate social evolution and reform. Learn more about us here: http://www.wireheadcollective.org/

So, here we are, raising awareness, raising women, raising kane, and most importantly raising money to cover the costs of this ambitious workshop! Help us! Support art and the advancement of women in history and women artists making herstory.

PS check out our blog: https://descendantsofthechalice.wordpress.com

story:
Short Summary

Hello!  I'm Stefany Cambra, the founder of Proper Hijinx Productions.  We're a small independent theatre company in Dallas, Texas looking to stir up the best kind of trouble with compelling contemporary works.  I've been producing shows for about five years now, and got Proper Hijinx started up the summer of this year with a production of Two Rooms by Lee Blessing.  In 2016, we will be producing our first three show season and we're starting with a figurative (and quite possibly literal) bang by producing Eric Coble's The Dead Guy.

My passion for theatre arose at an early age- as a child, I foresaw a bright future as a famous actor, but as I continued to grow, my interests developed beyond being on the stage and I explored other offstage roles, such as stage management, prop and costume design, writing, and directing.  It was in directing that I discovered my truest passion.  I love getting my hands dirty in the art of storytelling, bringing together all of the elements of a production to make an impact on our audience and, ultimately, our community.  

Before I lose your attention, I want to express why this campaign is so important.  There's already a lot of theater going on in Dallas; perhaps you're wondering if we really need "yet another" show to go see produced by "yet another" theatre company.  The short answer is YES.  Proper Hijinx isn't putting on "yet another" production of Noises Off- we're focusing on compelling, risky works that pertain to issues we currently face in modern day society.  We're looking to make a true impact to our community through our work, producing shows that will entertain our audience while simultaneously getting them to talk about things that matter.

But to do so, we need some help.  We're still getting off the ground and right now funding is coming from little ol' me.  I happily throw every cent I earn into Proper Hijinx and our production of The Dead Guy by Eric Coble, but I'm asking for help so I can really make this production be all that it can.  There's a lot of technology needed for this show, a lot of set pieces, and a hell of a lot of costumes- and Disneyland prostitutes are not cheap you guys!  The money you donate to this production won't just be helping us put on a show, you'll be helping us exist.

What We Need & What You Get

We're looking to raise at least $2500 to put towards our first production of our first full season.  This money won't pay for all of our production costs that are tied into the show (this show will cost us about $8000 total), but it will help alleviate the financial burden.  So!  What will your donation be going towards?

-Costumes, set pieces, and props.  We've got 12 characters to clothe and about as many locations to create in our set.  And props?  Don't even get me started.  There's props for days.  Video games, dining ware, basketballs, blood...you name it, we have to have it.

-Paying the cast and production team.  Now, as a theatrician, I firmly believe in paying those involved.  I don't take a paycheck out the productions I produce because it's a labor of love- but I want my designers, actors, and stage hands to get paid for their time and energy. For many, theatre isn't just a hobby, it's a job.  And when you put in work, you should get a paycheck.  I will never ask my production team to volunteer their time because I recognize the value of their work.

-Publicity.  In order to get people to come see our finished product that you're generously helping us to create, we've got to spend some on photos. posters, and web design.  We need to be able to print programs to talk about our awesome production team of designers and actors and promote the rest of our season!  And believe it or not, paper and printing gets mega expensive real quick.  By putting down a little of the green paper, you'll be helping us paper the city to promote Dead Guy!

Now I bet you're wondering what you'll get out of it for throwing down some generosity and giving us the bucks to make this happen.  The more you donate, the better the perks become with some examples being: 

-Have your name listed in the program as a donor

-Free tickets to The Dead Guy peformance of your choice

-Proper Hijinx Swag: water bottles, t-shirts, we even have flasks, yo. 

So what happens if we don't reach our entire goal?  The money will still go into the production, but we'll have to beg, borrow, and steal our way into affording what isn't covered. And if we reach beyond our goal?  Then we're going to be bringing an awesome production of The Dead Guy to the DFW area and have some money to donate to our next productions in 2016- we've got two more shows to produce after this one, and those will cost money too.  

The Impact

The Dead Guy by Eric Coble is a dark comedy that reflects on our country's addiction to thrilling, twisted reality television.  And it places the following question front and center: what is the value of a human life?

In a year when we have had more mass shootings than days, it seems to be a pretty valid question to ask.  We see people fighting for their religion, fighting for their beliefs, and quite likely fighting just to fight.  Violence begets violence and everyday it seems we are losing another life to it.  So what value do these human lives have?  Can one life make a difference?  And will our community stand idly by and allow someone to die?  The Dead Guy is a more timely piece to do now than ever, because it's not just a satire on reality television, but a reflection on our current state of humanity.

We at Proper Hijinx want to create a conversation on the value of human life through a compelling production of The Dead Guy, and would love your help to make our vision come to fruition.

Other Ways You Can Help

So maybe right now you can't afford to toss a couple bucks our way, but that doesn't mean you can't be of help!  Share our indiegogo page and ask for donations on our behalf!  Promote our events and like our Facebook page!  Helping us get the word out is just as helpful and truly appreciated.
We can also always use volunteers.  Want to donate a little of your time to help paint set pieces or usher for us?  Email properhijinx@gmail.com and we would be more than happy to have volunteers join us on this endeavor.

story:
OUBLIETTE

I was born for something more.

The five children of the noble king know the end of the war is imminent. The snow has begun to settle on the conspirators who sought to depose their family. They can hear singing from the city nearby. Yet they still hide in their palace, awaiting word of an armistice.

Among them is Oubliette.

The king’s eldest daughter, she is to be married. An elaborate affair in a cathedral tall, to be witnessed by the eyes of the kingdom. As they watch, they will forget the shadows of war. They will feel no hunger, remember no pain.

But just how easy is it to forget?

About Powder & Ink

Powder & Ink are a new theatre company founded by Arts University Bournemouth graduate Chloe Hatherley. Her passion for the artistry of the past inspires her to write original works that seek to invigorate the dedication to aesthetic beauty that the French nobility possessed in the 17th and 18th centuries. Beauty of language, emotion, society life, fashion, architecture and music.

But what is past without a future? Powder & Ink seek to fuse their historical aspirations with modern ideals and themes, of diversity, technology, revolution and empowerment, to create reflective and resonant work. And they aim to truly discover- is it possible to extract beauty from an often-ugly history?

About the Writer/Director

Chloe Hatherley trained at the Arts University Bournemouth, graduating with a First-Class degree in Acting in 2017. She was the recipient of the Paul Elliot Prize for Acting. She loves working with heightened text, particularly Shakespeare, and her work is always created with the dramatic flair so often found in classical theatre in mind. Last year, she wrote, choreographed and composed the music for a short piece entitled 'Nymphea', a faerie tale in verse that explored what a female dominated performance art, such as the geisha in Japan, would have been like had one developed in Britain in the 19th century.

This performance can be found at this link: https://vimeo.com/221577824

In the future, she seeks to not only act, write, direct and produce theatre, but also transfer those skills into filmmaking.

What We Need

The theatre fees have already been paid, funded by the director's monetary prize that she received upon graduating from university.

However, the Camden Fringe Festival requires a £99 registration fee to be included in their marketing, and this needs to be raised!

Actors!

Our primary cost is actors! The play requires a cast of five, four of whom are yet to be sourced. Your donations will cover their travel expenses, and hopefully we can raise enough to also give them a flat fee payment for their time! This is a profit share venture, but a set fee would be an excellent bonus for any young actor!

Production Design!

Our secondary cost is the production design! We will need to source costumes, props and furniture, both purchasing and hiring, and so these costs need to be covered. This is a period piece, and we would love to make it as visually exciting and representative as possible!

Industry Invites, Marketing and Licencing!

This is a showcase opportunity for young unrepresented actors, so we would like to put aside some of the money to purchase tickets for a few select industry professionals, who may help advance our careers.

Marketing and printing will require some funding- flyers and posters need to be distributed in order for us to have the largest audience we can get!

We may require a music licence and so we have budgeted this in. If this is not the case, any money raised for this will be split between actor's fees and production design fees.

What You Get

Hopefully, we've put together a wonderful selection of perks for you if you donate! Each tier is named after a character in the piece, or a character mentioned in the piece!

The perks across the various tiers are:

  • A social media shout out!
  • Your name written on 'The Constitution' which is a vital prop within the piece
  • A special acknowledgement in our programme
  • A weekly video update emailed to you
  • A limited edition poster signed by the cast
  • A copy of the play signed by the cast
  • A unique poem written just for you
  • An invitation to an exclusive after show drinks reception
  • 2 tickets for you and a friend to attend the show
  • Credit as a producer of the show

Risks & Challenges

The theatre has already been booked for five performances and the contract signed, so there is very little risk of the project falling through.

This is our debut production, which in itself is a challenge, but we are confident that we can pull it off. We have a wonderful network of support to help us through!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter, and be sure to follow us on there too!

https://www.facebook.com/powderandink/

https://twitter.com/powder_ink

Unrestricted View

UNRESTRICTED VIEW are the company based at the Hen and Chickens Theatre, and this production is kindly being supported by them. Check out their website at:

www.unrestrictedview.co.uk

story:
Starring:

Chance Gabriel Rodriguez, Sarah Quane Smyth, Caren Skibell, Gamal ElSawah, Meagan Stevenson, Gary Kozak, Jacquelyn Claire De Villiers & Bill Meoni

Directed by: Toni Salisbury
Stage Manager: Kaitria Resetar
Lighting Designer: Maxwell A. Waters
Costume Designer: Alexandra Fokine

 

Short Summary

Hello, my name is Jillian Stevens and I am a born and raised New Yorker, writer, actor, certified 500-hr RYT, wellness advocate, a dreamer and a believer. I am endlessly inspired by those who let their inner light guide them; those who listen to the tiny voice inside- even when it can barely be described as a whisper- and let it linger; and those who stand up and celebrate what their hearts beat for; putting their passions before their hesitations!

-As some of you may or may not know, I have created an Indiegogo campaign because I seek to raise funds to stage an original Full-Length play I have written, entitled: The Ones Upstairs, to be performed as a part of Theater for the New City's 'Dream up Festival 2018!' this August (Artistic Director, Crystal Field)!  

-Because I am a fierce advocate of paying my actors and crew for their supreme work, it is important that I strive to raise the money they so deserve!  That is where your help comes in:

-During a time of much political unrest, it is my objective to allow the audience to share a communal sigh of relief, embarking on a brief departure into the world of Theatre. Because it is my highest goal to leave a smile and a feeling of joy wherever I may go in this life, I wish to stage this piece of work and bring this vision to life!

 

What We Need & What You Get

I seek to raise a flexible goal of $4,000. All money raised will go toward the cost of the set, costumes,  and actor/crew stipend.

Every penny helps in the funding of this production and is greatly appreciated. I am immensely thankful to those involved with the production and to those who wish to make any donation,  large,  or small!

*If you donate $15 or more, you will receive a personalized & handwritten 'Thank You' letter sent to your home address!

**Since this is a flexible goal,  if we do not meet our $4,000 goal,  that is okay! The show must go on and any sum you care to donate is deeply appreciated!

 

The Impact

As a dedicated producer and actor that seeks to deliver work of the highest caliber,  it is my goal to reach this $4,000 sum to bring you the absolute best version of this world premiere piece of Theatre!

Having worked on countless productions in NYC, I have a deep understanding of the elements it takes to put up a stellar production. Thus, a budget of $4,000 will help make this goal possible. 

This project was merely a dream for me at one point: I began writing 2 scenes of the play 5 years ago,  and put it aside until this past year,  when I was moved to finish the piece.  In fully realizing my vision,  this dream,  any and all funds will greatly aid in making this dream into the reality I envision. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Though staging any production is a large task,  I know that  with the help of my fellow friends and colleagues, I can reach this goal.  Because of my strong community, I am positive we will overcome any and all foreseeable hurdles encountered in this process!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot contribute,  I would greatly appreciate you spreading the word and sharing the indiegogo link for this campaign. 

My friends,  mentors and colleagues have led me to this very point.  For that,  I continue to bow with gratitude to you all and the immense inspiration I have been blessed to be surrounded by. 

Thank you so much!

Jillian
story_txt: Starring:Chance Gabriel Rodriguez, Sarah Quane Smyth, Caren Skibell, Gamal ElSawah, Meagan Stevenson, Gary Kozak, Jacquelyn Claire De Villiers & Bill MeoniDirected by: Toni SalisburyStage Manager: Kaitria ResetarLighting Designer: Maxwell A. story:
ABOUT:

Susan Glynn and Lanny Fox have been working and developing this musical for just under a year. Both have written, directed, and performed in numerous projects around Chicago, working at both The Annoyance and The Second City to name a few. 

They are extremely excited for audiences to catch this cooky and campy musical parody. This production includes stellar singing and dancing and focuses on inclusivity and gender fluidity. You will definitely see a few men in dresses and women with facial hair! Set in the year 1999, an insecure time in America when our saxophone playing president was facing impeachment charges and we were all in a panic about Y2K. A time when Warheads were sour candies, our music was boybands, and our cell phones were pagers.

At Johnathan Taylor Thomas High, the Pink Pussies and the T Bones run the school. But that's all about to change when new student Sheila joins the crew to challenge the head of the Pussies, Rude Betsy, while The T Bones are torn apart by a secret crush. Who will survive the new Millennium and who will be left behind in 99?

This musical will be playing on Saturdays at the The Annoyance for 10 weeks, 8/25-10/27, starting at 8pm.

WHY SUPPORT US?

We are very passionate about paying everyone involved with making this production a reality. Actors and creatives should be compensated for their hard work and dedication! We have been given a small budget but that does not include compensation for our actors and designers. 

Paying all 15 of our actors, costume designers, musical director, and choreographers is a HUGE priority to us and we hope you can help!

WHAT WE'RE OFFERING: If you donate a minimum of $10, you will receive 1 complimentary ticket to one of our first two performances, taking place on 8/25 and 9/1 at 8pm.

The money that we raise on this page will go directly back to our actors and creatives who have helped make this project a reality. 

Seems like a win win right? You donate at least $10 to this page, get a ticket to this awesome production and 100% of the proceeds go directly back to the actors and creatives! AND you save $10 as tickets for the rest of the run will be $20!!

We are grateful for all of your support and can't wait to see you at the show!!

story:
Photo by Francesca Chudnoff of Nyda Kwasowsky performing at New Blue Dance Festival  

'What Exists Here.' celebrates supportive, calming and joyful movement performed by 7 female bodies. It is an hourlong work to be shared between the performers and audiences at The Collective Space from November 15-18th, 2018 in order to highlight positive ways to live independently while sharing space and energy with others. It displays pride and acceptance for oneself and one's surroundings and it feels good to perform or witness. Rehearsals continue until November 2018 at Broadway Arts Centre and are enriched by the proximity to the West Toronto Railpath. The performance will take place in a constructed environment referencing a safe, comfortable oasis, somewhere I would consider ideal for living.

The Ins and Outs:

This project spans 13 months with 10 artists (dance, music and visual). We must rely on more than just ticket sales to cover the costs of paying each individual along with the cost of production.

What your donation covers:

136 hours of PAID in studio rehearsal (50-80 Hours per dancer, 7 dancers)

8 hours of PAID tech rehearsal

4 PAID performances at The Collective Space (Plus cost of renting the space)

2 Hour Nature Walk and Sound Recording, 10 hours of PAID Sound Design

10 Hours of Set Design and Construction

Promotion and Advertising Costs

Costumes (budget of $35 per dancer)

Snacks and Supplies for Artists and Audiences during the performances. THERE MUST ALWAYS BE FOOD.

Other Ways People Are Currently Donating:

Studio Space for Rehearsals, Projector Rental for Performances, Graphic Design for T-shirts,  Sending word of mouth invitations to friends and family. 
 

TO SAY THANKS:

We would love to provide everyone who donates $20 or more with an online link to the performances, I especially hope those far away from Ontario can still feel included in this work. 

There will also be public / internet thank you's to all who donate.

Hand Written Cards for those who donate $50 of more.

T-shirts for those who donate $100 or more.

And Tickets to the show for those who donate $500 or more!

Photo by Francesca Chudnoff of Nyda Kwasowsky performing at New Blue Dance Festival  

SO! Right Now, regardless if you are able to donate tangibly or simply energetically, I want to thank you for your interest in the work, for helping me reach my artistic goals in peaceful, uplifting and physical presentations of dance, for embracing kindness, and for making space within yourself to be on this page right now.

story:
Killer Concept

Picture this: John Wick, Jason Bourne, Leon and Arya Stark working in an office...

Obviously, due to licensing, we can't put that on stage for you! However our show Hitman Inc. will be just as compelling, with our equally dark characters exploring the modern world of work.

Ask yourself: Do I want to see a bunch of deadly contract killers forced by legislation to work in an office while attempting to find, who amongst them, is the rogue assassin?

If the answer is yes?


Who are we?

Hi! We’re Kayser and Kobir, the writer/director/producer brothers from The Filim Company (no, it's not a typo, that's our company name!).

We’ve been chipping away with self-funded stage and film projects for the past 16 years in between shooting high-end fancy cinematic weddings!
Telling stories is our thing!

(For more details of our previous work, please visit: http://www.filim.co.uk)

H1TM4N Inc is our most ambitious production yet. Using our film and theatre background, we’re creating a stage-play-TV-Pilot. A live show that is a complete story for the audience, yet also a precursor to a greater world and many more stories. What better way to prove a concept than put it in front of a live audience?

Yes, like our assassins, we too are adjusting to the new world of work, by innovating new ways to put on stage shows and pitch TV & Film projects!

We need you!

Our total budget is £13k.
We've self funded £5k already via investments and contributions through friends, family and clients, plus potential ad revenue from our brochure advertising.

But this year, our production is bigger! With a larger cast and crew; a custom built set; costumes; props and lighting effects!

We need a further £8k from you and we have 30 days to reach this goal!

Below is the breakdown:

We have always strived for fair pay for our team. They give so much of their time, energy and spirit, in return the least we can do is pay a decent wage - unfortunately this is one of the greatest challenges, but hopefully with your help we can get closer to this, most important goal!

The Impact

We need your help to realise this project and your involvement to break the mould in this big budget 'Netflix’ and ‘West-End/Broadway’ dominated world.

Our themes are bold, mainstream and crowd pleasing, yet guerrilla in style and innovation. Crowdfunding was always a good fit for us as we’ve been unofficially doing it for years within our network of friends, family and clients. (See our Theatre Angels video below)


Now we have a project that can connect with a larger network of new likeminded people so here we are, talking to you!

We work hard to make our shows accessible to non-theatre goers and theatre veterans alike and we’ve been fortunate enough to have a strong fan base over a wide demographic.

Plus! Making theatre affordable is very important to us, so your pledge helps us keep the ticket prices down!

Over the past 16 years we’ve put on plays around tough subjects with a deft touch while still entertaining. Hitman Inc, though a dark comedy, looks at the terraforming world of work; the gig economy and zero hour contracts. Our stories reflect our experiences and how running a small business is murder!

The further impact of Hitman Inc., is it's potential on the small screen. Through this live performance we'll show distributors that not only is it a viable concept, but there is already an audience and it's not simply a bunch of likes online. We'll have video testimonials to back it up!

But before all that, we want to make a great live show - who knows, maybe it'll end up being a episodic stage series - That'd be new!

The Risks & Rewards

What happens if we don’t get the funds? Well, the show must go on! Albeit it’ll have to be a very lean show, a couple of desks for the set, food will consist of legumes and potatoes, the actors will bring in their own clothes soiled in ketchup and we’ll have to use water guns as weapons… (!)

But on a serious note, we've always taken pride in giving our contributors and investors bang for their buck. Not only does your money help towards fairer pay for our team, it also translates to higher production value on stage. Whatever the amount, we always push to create a show that our investors and contributors are proud of and they've always come back to invest - something reflected by our constant output of work the past decade.

We also work hard to create a legacy for each of our show, so as a contributor, you're investing in more than just four nights of a play!
Not only do we have great marketing material, in the guise of trailers, leaflets and posters. We also create glossy full colour brochures, video testimonials from the audience, professional photos and videos of the show and fun behind the scene documentaries of the experience. So if anyone wants to know what you contributed to, you'll have plenty to impress them with!

Basically, if we were contract killers working in the agency, we'd kill it!
(please check our videos above to see examples as well as visit our vimeo.com/filim and youtube.com/filim channels to see much much more!)

Teamwork

They say you don’t need a million followers to be successful, just a thousand fans championing you. Big brands like Apple have used this ethos to success.

We have no wish to become Apple and don’t expect a thousand die hard fans (yet!)

We want to connect with you! Yes, we need your pledge, but equally, we want you to join us on this exciting new adventure.

This is a stage play / TV pilot, we want to involve an international audience and to this effect we’ve got perks for everyone, regardless of whether you’re in the UK or not. We really believe this is something special and want you to be able to say:
“I was there when it started!”

And for those of you who are unable to pledge, we have an even bigger task for you:

We need your help to spread the word of our campaign and show like wildfire! Tag us when you do and we’ll make sure we thank each and every one of you!

If you work for a living, this'll kill YOU!

Thank You
Kayser & Kobir

We need your help to spread the word of our campaign and show like wildfire! Tag us when you do and we’ll make sure we thank each and every one of you!
If you work for a living, this'll kill YOU!
Thank YouKayser & Kobir

story:
Short Summary

Hi,

We are a group of 5 artists from Egypt (Zizo, Bassem, Mohamed) and England (Tom, Charlie).

For the past 2 years we've been developing a theatre project, 'Possession / al Ghiwaya'. It explores what it means to go and live your life in the desert, in total silence and isolation. We are exploring what it means to devote yourself to a spiritual cause. 

Collaborations between UK and Egyptian theatre artists are rare. We are making our project in Egypt because it is based on an Egyptian social and religious movement 1700 years ago, when people started fleeing to the desert to live isolated lives, in order to escape persecution from the Roman Empire. Finding many parallels in the contemporary world, we are committed to bringing this story to life and sharing it with audiences. 

Our work has been recognised and we have been invited to perform at Downtown Cairo International Arts Festival (D-Caf) in 2018. Your contribution would help us complete and present the show, and bring our work back from the desert to share with public audiences. 

 

What We Need

 

To date, our rehearsals  have been supported by the British Council Egypt, Egyptian theatre company 'el Warsha', Sihel Island Culture Centre, and New Hermopolis. But to complete our show and present it publicly, we need your help.

We are looking to raise £7000. This will go towards payment of creatives, paying for a small amount of physical props on stage, accommodation, and towards travel so that we can work together. 

By contributing, you get to make an entire theatre production happen, and bring experiences from the hypnotic Egyptian desert to the public stage.

While we appreciate that the production will premiere in Egypt, we also really want to bring our story to international audiences, both in Europe and the Middle East. By premiering in a Cairo international theatre festival we have a chance to reach these audiences... including you. 

So... while we cannot immediately offer access to the show (if you are supporting from outside of Egypt), we intend to do so in the future.  We will keep donors updated with the show's progress, send images from rehearsal, sound bytes, videos of performance and more. Should the show tour to the donor's country, all donors offering over £100 will be offered a free ticket.  

We appreciate that our offer to donors (perks, etc.) might not be the best in the world. What we can offer is the satisfaction of making a fascinating work of desert theatre and an exciting exploration of spirituality come to life. Without your help it wouldn't be possible. 

 

The Impact

 

Why does our project matter and what are we trying to do? We feel that spirituality and religion is a major cause of conflict and misunderstanding in today's world - especially around divisions between Islam and Christianity. By making a project that analyses and explores diverse spiritual experiences, we aim to create new dialogues that might develop greater compassion and understanding for Otherness.  

The 3 Egyptians in our project all perform with el Warsha,  an internationally-renowned Egyptian theatre company that has presented all over the world.  The two Englishmen in our company create and perform theatre both in the UK and in Europe. Together we bring a wealth of song, music and theatre experience to create a fascinating and compelling show in both Arabic and English language. 

We are a new ensemble of young artists, who enjoy the challenge of making engaging, exciting intercultural work. We work together because we have a passion for making innovative new theatre that excites people. 

 

Challenges

 

On the way to making our project happen over these last 2 years, we have faced many obstacles including the desert heat, a challenging financial climate, the challenge of staying together as an cross-border company. 

We're sure we'll encounter more challenges, but we are so determined to get the show on and make this happen. Even if we don't quite make our funding target, we are determined to make it happen. 

Even if you can't contribute to what we are doing, but you like our story and have time for our journey, please do kindly spread the word to people who you think may be interested or able to help.

Thank you!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Hi,
We are a group of 5 artists from Egypt (Zizo, Bassem, Mohamed) and England (Tom, Charlie).
For the past 2 years we've been developing a theatre project, 'Possession / al Ghiwaya'. It explores what it means to go and live your life in the desert, in total silence and isolation. We are exploring what it means to devote yourself to a spiritual cause. 
Collaborations between UK and Egyptian theatre artists are rare. We are making our project in Egypt because it is based on an Egyptian social and religious movement 1700 years ago, when people started fleeing to the desert to live isolated lives, in order to escape persecution from the Roman Empire. Finding many parallels in the contemporary world, we are committed to bringing this story to life and sharing it with audiences. 
Our work has been recognised and we have been invited to perform at Downtown Cairo International Arts Festival (D-Caf) in 2018. Your contribution would help us complete and present the show, and bring our work back from the desert to share with public audiences. 

 
What We Need
 
To date, our rehearsals  have been supported by the British Council Egypt, Egyptian theatre company 'el Warsha', Sihel Island Culture Centre, and New Hermopolis. But to complete our show and present it publicly, we need your help.
We are looking to raise £7000. This will go towards payment of creatives, paying for a small amount of physical props on stage, accommodation, and towards travel so that we can work together. 
By contributing, you get to make an entire theatre production happen, and bring experiences from the hypnotic Egyptian desert to the public stage.
While we appreciate that the production will premiere in Egypt, we also really want to bring our story to international audiences, both in Europe and the Middle East. By premiering in a Cairo international theatre festival we have a chance to reach these audiences... including you. 
So... while we cannot immediately offer access to the show (if you are supporting from outside of Egypt), we intend to do so in the future.  We will keep donors updated with the show's progress, send images from rehearsal, sound bytes, videos of performance and more. Should the show tour to the donor's country, all donors offering over £100 will be offered a free ticket.  
We appreciate that our offer to donors (perks, etc.) might not be the best in the world. What we can offer is the satisfaction of making a fascinating work of desert theatre and an exciting exploration of spirituality come to life. Without your help it wouldn't be possible. 
 

The Impact
 
Why does our project matter and what are we trying to do? We feel that spirituality and religion is a major cause of conflict and misunderstanding in today's world - especially around divisions between Islam and Christianity. By making a project that analyses and explores diverse spiritual experiences, we aim to create new dialogues that might develop greater compassion and understanding for Otherness.  
The 3 Egyptians in our project all perform with el Warsha,  an internationally-renowned Egyptian theatre company that has presented all over the world.  The two Englishmen in our company create and perform theatre both in the UK and in Europe. Together we bring a wealth of song, music and theatre experience to create a fascinating and compelling show in both Arabic and English language. 
We are a new ensemble of young artists, who enjoy the challenge of making engaging, exciting intercultural work. We work together because we have a passion for making innovative new theatre that excites people. 
 

Challenges
 
On the way to making our project happen over these last 2 years, we have faced many obstacles including the desert heat, a challenging financial climate, the challenge of staying together as an cross-border company. 
We're sure we'll encounter more challenges, but we are so determined to get the show on and make this happen. Even if we don't quite make our funding target, we are determined to make it happen. 
Even if you can't contribute to what we are doing, but you like our story and have time for our journey, please do kindly spread the word to people who you think may be interested or able to help.
Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

YETi was founded in 2015 in order to give young people the opportunity to independently operate a functioning theatre company.

Youth are often represented as naive, sensitive, and incapable, but we believe that, when given opportunities, young people can achieve anything. 

With your contributions, our company will be able to continue in the future and provide arts and financial education for youth, as well as fund our fourth season production of Class Action.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal this season is $2500. This money will be used to keep our company up and running in the future.

If you donate, you can receive gifts such as, a signed program, free tickets, or a backstage tour on opening night!

Any and all money we get will be used to make our show the best it can be!

The Impact

Little by little, each play we present helps bring diverse opportunities to the theatre community. 

For the past three years, we've had successful plays that have received great reviews from our audiences.

We're a group of youth who understands our impact on both community theatre and our audience.

Risks & Challenges

Because we are a relatively new program in the theatre community, we are still somewhat unknown, but with your support and word of mouth, we can expand our audience and spread our message throughout the community. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Maybe you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Help spread the word about our company and our show or follow us on social media!

Don't forget to use Indiegogo share tools!

story:
What is Venture?

Venture Shakespeare is a Theatre Training Company. It’s brand new. And I need your help!

Mission Statement: Through scholarly research and active theatrical collaboration, Venture Shakespeare creates new work inspired by Shakespeare’s canon.

Vision: With education at the helm, we seek to create compelling and meaningful rehearsals for the company and performances for the audience.

Who is Venture? Kirstin Leigh Daniel

I grew up in rural New Hampshire and was lucky enough to have Ms. Nancy Brennan as my high school theatre teacher. She exposed me to new and innovative theatre and instilled a strong work ethic that I have carried through my education and career. The importance and severity of teaching only grew during my time as a student at Emerson College under the tutelage of Dr. Robert Colby and Ms. Bethany Nelson. Teaching is not simply a job but life and death.

Teaching in the public schools was always my path, I come from a long line of teachers and public servants including my brilliant mother who was the first speech pathologist in SAU 24. Teaching high school was one of the most incredible experiences of my life; the relationships that were built out of my time creating theatre with my students and colleagues shaped who I am today. I am forever indebted to those students who showed me how to be the best person I could be.

I believe in a lifelong pursuit of learning and found that the schedule of public school was prohibiting me from gaining new knowledge. So I took a leap and moved to England to study Shakespeare. It was the most difficult decision I have ever made. Throughout my year in Stratford-upon-Avon, I felt a yearning to create my own work... and wanted to do that back home. Home in Asheville. Not everyone has the opportunity to go to art school and there are a lack of resources for my former students to continue honing their craft with professional, ethical and responsible teachers. The creative profession is a place that asks the artist to be vulnerable, to open themselves to a world that is filled with great joy and wonder but also with tragedy and grief. It is my responsibility as an adult in this industry to encourage and cultivate those skills while providing a space where my students are free from objectification, manipulation and abuse of power. In the age of "me too" the sentiment of TIMES UP couldn't be more relevant.

What does Venture want to do?

  • Create a place where working professionals can come and rejuvenate their souls by sharing their crafts with aspiring young adults. Teaching in any capacity can be transformative, for both teacher and student.
  • Provide a place of educational exploration; that is immediate, where skills are honed during the theatrical process rather than compartmentalized. Where collaboration is key and healthy communication skills are gained.
  • Third, that Venture applies a growth mindset. We are in pursuit of creative excellence. Recognizing that through rehearsal and commitment to our craft we grow as artists and as a company.
  • Have a month long intensive training for 18-25 year olds from WNC free of charge. (what I need your help with)
  • And then to build other educational opportunities for students, teachers and schools in my area throughout the year. 

What does Venture need?

Well we need a lot of things to get this company off the ground. But this is what we need to make the first season happen!

$2,000: for rehearsal and performance space

$12,000: Salaries (for me and all of my guest artists)

$6,000: for production elements (Costumes, Sets, Lights and Sound)

$5,000: Business overhead (website, logo packaging, posters, merchandise startup, books and supplies for summer intensive students)

Totalling: $25,000

The Impact?

  • That these students are able to continue their love of theatre and bring great things to their communities.
  • That their new skills will enable them to be cast in shows outside of Venture Shakespeare.
  • That the love of learning is instilled and grows from each day forward.
  • That audiences come and see something new and exciting, that asks big questions and makes people feel.
  • That it raises the level of artistry in Asheville.
  • That people come to Asheville each year to see what these young people create!
  • Because what is more amazing than young people taking a giant risk to expose the human condition!?

Other Ways To Help

If you can't donate, spread the word! TELL EVERYONE YOU KNOW!! (Will you, please.) We're always looking to reach more people with this campaign.

And if you're in Asheville, come talk to me, Kirstin. There are other ways to help if you're local! Venture Shakespeare is about community, so lets build one!

story:
We are Stephanie and Dora – two aspiring artists in the world of theatre and film. We met at The Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute, 2017. There we became friends and scene work buddies. Because we both shared the passion in creating our own work, and not being dictated what show is being put on, we decided to produce and stage our own play.

We instantly connected to a young idealist’s story who thinks that there can be a world in which people not only ask a casual “How are you doing?” from one another and then walk away. No, they stop, listen and care.

She used her voice to raise questions and prevent walls being built, while she eventually discovered the real world and herself. And the main purpose of arts is the very same; discovering, debating and building. We are asking your help to move our world a bit forward by telling her story. Because there are stories that must be told over and over again. And hers is a story just like that.
 

As it is shown in the pie chart below, most of the funding will go to the venue, to The Secret Theatre. Followed by that will come the DPS rights to put on the show in the first place.
 


Promotional materials and our perks (that are uniquely designed for our show and for our sponsors) will take up the last big chunk of the pie.

Last but not least – to put on a show, we need props, equipment, and the occasional coffee.

We know that producing a show in New York always bears with a financial risk. No matter how devoted and passionate you are. We had been lucky enough to work in different productions in the recent times.

Stephanie performed in “Avenue Q”, “Jekyll & Hyde”, and “Midsummer Night’s Dream”, shows from Germany to New York.



Dora has directed “The Motherf**ker with the Hat” last fall (a Marshall Hall Production) and has been producing her own short movies from Italy to New York. 

And that is why we believe that with our extensive artistic experience, strong work ethics and precise planning we are going to overcome any obstacle that may stand in our way.

If you cannot be in New York to watch our show, or do not have the necessary spare change to contribute, please feel free to share our campaign to get the word out.


Thank you! Every little bit of help means a lot to us!


Instagram: @iamrachelnyc
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/iamrachelnyc/

Press release:
https://www.broadwayworld.com/off-off-broadway/...

Graphic design by Dorottya Pálfi  - d.palfi.03@gmail.com
Special thanks to The Lee Strasberg Theatre & Film Institute
