story:
We are Bez Arts Hub!

I'm Sandy Rosen and I am the creative director of Bez Arts Hub in Langley, BC. After 16 years as the owner and director of Dance Barn Studio I've come to love and appreciate the community of Langley, but it has been an enormous concern that there is a lack of live performance venues in our city.

With our work in the arts - our team have been involved extensively in music, dance, photography, media and graphic design - we decided that we needed to go ahead and develop a performance space that could house music concerts, theatre performances, indie film premiers, dance productions and art showings. We have begun the transformation of a strategic commercial space, right in the heart of the Langley retail district. We have reworked the facility into a blackbox theatre, initially installing sprung floors and opening up the room to be an adaptable space for a myriad of diverse arts functions. Our next steps have been to outfit the space with curtains, theatre lighting, a sound system, staging and seating, projection/screen and renovations that will increase our capacity.

In order to do this we have gratefully received a $55,000 grant from Creative BC but it needs to be matched. With the $55,000 that we would raise through Indiegogo (in addition to the Creative BC grant) we will be able to complete the necessary renovations and equipment that will permit us to fully launch our performance venue before the new year!

The Impact

What it will result in is one of Langley's only venues that is solely devoted to live arts performances. And why should Langley care about the arts? Because the arts increases economic development, tourism and social interactions in the community and can even improve cognitive development in children, Yes, art matters!

Our Bez team are artists and mentors to artists for the last 30+ years and we have a passion to see excellence in the arts launched in our community. We have founded our own dance studio; we have taken teams of artists across Canada and around the world; we have recorded numerous albums, produced dance productions and have launched a lifetime of creative work. 

Furthermore, we have interviewed more than 50 artists from many arts genres and most have expressed that they have difficulty finding arts spaces in which to present and perform! We'd love to help them out - wouldn't you?

More than just Bez

Now to keep an arts facility running, we need more than just bookings for performances and presentations, so we have been looking to other partnerships and collaborations. We are already sharing the facility with 2 long-term partners: Dance Barn Studio, which has been in operation for more than 16 years; and Mirror Dance Program (transitioning as Mirror Arts), which has been doing pre-professional arts training for 11 years. Other short-term event partnerships have begun with Long and McQuade and WeMakeStuff as well. In general, the facility will be open for community rentals whenever Bez does not have specific events booked.

How you can help?

So what happens if our goal is not reached? We are thoroughly committed to launching this venue in Langley, so we will still pour what is raised into the transformation of the Bez Arts Hub space and continue to seek out investors and donors who are interested in partnering with us so that we can keep moving forward. BUT we do want to see the funds raised so...

We have set up a collection of perks that would give YOU the opportunity to take in the exceptional performances at Bez Arts Hub first hand. Your support of this project will not only enable more artists to step to the stage right here in Langley, but you will be the beneficiary of those exciting presentations (and the Bez space) yourself! And beyond that, you will be helping to change the arts landscape of this community, especially if you can encourage others to support this cause by passing along this link to your social networks with Indiegogo share tools. Thank you in advance!

story:
"This work should be performed at Carnegie Hall and important concert halls around the world. It should be performed throughout the Latino world and everywhere that influenced this great genius." -- Philip Greenberg, Artistic Director, Kiev Philharmonic

Our country's horrific political scene has been demanding our attention.  Our treatment of migrants escaping bloodshed and violence, the ruthless separation of children from parents -- the choices we make as individuals, as members of a once civil society, could not be more critical.  Which underscores the relevance of That's Not Tango. By sharing the remarkable story of Astor Piazzolla, we remind the world of the contributions of world culture and rebuild a compassionate society. 

Astor Piazzolla's story is the story of the American immigrant.  He moved from Argentina to  the melting pot of New York City's Lower East Side at the age of 3.  He heard Bach played by a professional pianist living in the same tenement.  He heard klezmer from the synagogue next door. He heard jazz in the clubs of Harlem.  And he heard tango from the scratchy records played by his father.

Piazzolla's powerful music, performed live, is a reminder that the immigrant experience often produces art that both transforms and elevates.  The outsider sees, hears and experiences things we take for granted, creating from these impressions art that not only enables new ways of seeing and hearing, but that also illumines the world we think we know. 

With your help, we will bring this important message to audiences. 

Putting on a show of this quality and complexity is expensive.  Even our successful sold-out performances at Joe's Pub and SubCulture left us in the red.  But the incredible response from the audiences and the euphoria we experience whenever we hear or play the music keeps us going.

We've booked eight dates in New York City followed by two in New Orleans.  For this run and every one that follows, we must fund scenic, lighting and costume designers, consult with music rights lawyers, rent rehearsal space, prepare and distribute marketing materials, and pay for travel and accommodations.  Even running this Indiegogo campaign has costs.

This chart breaks down how most of our production dollars are spent.  

Until we can book a sustained tour with longer runs, the show needs to be underwritten. Your support gets us closer.  This summer fundraiser will give us more time and opportunities to put a polished show in front of producers and brokers for larger, future concert venues.

STRETCH GOALS

The $35,000 we are raising from this campaign is just a fraction of our expenses.  With your support, and with every ticket sold, we will continue to fund our productions and marketing efforts until we’re able to bring That’s Not Tango to venues worldwide.    

We will post updates and stretch goals as the campaign progresses.  

Won't you join us in fulfilling this dream?

CLICK HERE TO READ OUR RAVE REVIEWS!

Seven years ago, That's Not Tango (so named because Piazzolla's critics insisted that he was destroying the art form) debuted in a Manhattan dance studio.  Since then, the show has grown into a passionate theatrical experience with sold-out performances in a few concert venues, most notably Joe's Pub in New York. 
 
In the show, actor Lesley Karsten occupies a simple stage with three talented musicians. Together, they bring to life the music and legendary imagination of Piazzolla, a restless spirit who betrayed almost everyone he loved on his way to becoming one of the top composers in the world.  In the end, he asks himself an age-old question: Was the sacrifice worth the art? 
 
The show weaves Piazzolla's personal narrative into the fabric of the music.  We meet him at the end of his life, after a cerebral hemorrhage robs him of the ability to play his beloved bandonéon.  We imagine the inner struggle of a man who – trapped in his body and isolated by silence – fears retribution for his sins.  He knew he was destined to make music, even if it meant neglecting his wife and children.  But how does a man repent for sacrificing the hearts of the people who loved him to give voice to his own? 
 

Piazzolla's life story speaks to all who have ever chased a dream. Help us tell it. 

"The glorious music of Astor Piazzolla tugs at your heart and very soul. The joy of hearing this music with world-class musicians is a very rare treat." -- Philip Greenberg, Artistic Director, Kiev Philharmonic. 

Piazzolla created a revolution called Tango Nuevo.  Tango Nuevo speaks to anyone who has been separated from home, family and friends, even from themselves.  This is the music of exile.

This music -- hauntingly beautiful, often melancholic, always passionate -- is quite simply unforgettable.

The music of That's Not Tango is played live on stage by three world-acclaimed musicians:

  • Nick Danielson, Argentinian-American violinist
  • Brandt Fredriksen, pianist and educator
  • JP Jofre, Argentinian bandoneonist

They perform a dozen works -- some in full, some in part -- ranging from the propulsive, rarely performed Très Minutos con la Realidad to the emotionally complex Adios Nonino, Piazzolla's tribute to his late father. 

Piazzolla's music can change lives. Help us share it.

"The discovery of Piazzolla was like the finding of some exotic and dangerous potency drug that brings with it the double-edged sword of ecstasy and the bitterest of remorse.” -- John Adams, renowned composer

The man who reimagined Tango led a life of brutality, innocence, and the extraordinary. Repeatedly kicked out of school, fraternizing with street hoodlums, he witnessed a harsh violence and arbitrary cruelty growing up on the mean streets of the Lower East Side in the 1920s. 

And yet, diverse musical encounters sparked a fever in him.  Piazzolla  grew up listening to Jewish klezmer, Harlem jazz, and his father's scratched tango records.  He was transfixed by the Bach his neighbor, a protege of Rachmaninoff, played.  He even met Carlos Gardel, the " King of Tango," while living in New York.  His return to Argentina at 17 was the beginning of his  lifelong struggle to integrate all these musical influences and elevate Tango from the dance hall to the concert hall. 

This wild child with no formal training later became one of the most influential composers of the 20th century.  The universality of his music resonates with fans who are just as passionate in Tokyo, Paris and New York as they are in his native Buenos Aires. 

Today, Piazzolla's music is performed by the finest classical and jazz musicians in the world, among them Yo Yo Ma, Gideon Kremer, Emmanuel Ax, Al Di Meola, Gary Burton, and Paquito d'Rivera.

With your help, his story can now share the spotlight with his music. 

For the past seven years, a seasoned creative team has developed and honed the show to get it ready for touring.  Writer-actor-producer Lesley Karsten, writer-director Stephen Wadsworth, story and music consultants Fernando Gonzalez and Kip Hanrahan, musicians Nick Danielson, Brandt Fredriksen, and JP Jofre -- as well as maestro Piazzolla -- have all contributed their best.  A crew of designers, publicists, and marketers have also worked hard to get the production ready. 

We need you on our team, too.

...in celebrating the cross-cultural riches that immigrants bring to our shores.

...in inspiring the irresistible creative force that resides in all of us.

...in telling the compelling story of Astor Piazzolla through the power of live music and theatre.

HOW TO CONTRIBUTE

Select a perk.  At every contribution level, That’s Not Tango thanks you for your support with a list of show-inspired perks for your enjoyment. (Please note that perks do not include any business interests in the show or the company.)

Contribute without a perk.  Click on the pink BACK IT button at the very top of the page. You will be prompted to enter a dollar amount for your contribution. 

(If you have trouble using the Safari browser, please try Chrome.)

Become a producing partner.  If you'd like a bigger role than that of a contributor, please contact us at info@thatsnottango.com

Please invite your friends on Facebook and other social media to join us for our campaign! The transformative music of Piazzolla should be heard and enjoyed by as many people as possible.

Thank you for your support.  You can also visit our website to learn more.
story_txt:
"This work should be performed at Carnegie Hall and important concert halls around the world. It should be performed throughout the Latino world and everywhere that influenced this great genius." -- Philip Greenberg, Artistic Director, Kiev PhilharmonicOur country's horrific political scene has been demanding our attention.  Our treatment of migrants escaping bloodshed and violence, the ruthless separation of children from parents -- the choices we make as individuals, as members of a once civil society, could not be more critical.  Which underscores the relevance of That's Not Tango. By sharing the remarkable story of Astor Piazzolla, we remind the world of the contributions of world culture and rebuild a compassionate society. Astor Piazzolla's story is the story of the American immigrant.  He moved from Argentina to  the melting pot of New York City's Lower East Side at the age of 3.  He heard Bach played by a professional pianist living in the same tenement.  He heard klezmer from the synagogue next door. He heard jazz in the clubs of Harlem.  And he heard tango from the scratchy records played by his father.Piazzolla's powerful music, performed live, is a reminder that the immigrant experience often produces art that both transforms and elevates.  The outsider sees, hears and experiences things we take for granted, creating from these impressions art that not only enables new ways of seeing and hearing, but that also illumines the world we think we know. With your help, we will bring this important message to audiences. Putting on a show of this quality and complexity is expensive.  Even our successful sold-out performances at Joe's Pub and SubCulture left us in the red.  But the incredible response from the audiences and the euphoria we experience whenever we hear or play the music keeps us going.We've booked eight dates in New York City followed by two in New Orleans.  For this run and every one that follows, we must fund scenic, lighting and costume designers, consult with music rights lawyers, rent rehearsal space, prepare and distribute marketing materials, and pay for travel and accommodations.  Even running this Indiegogo campaign has costs.This chart breaks down how most of our production dollars are spent.  Until we can book a sustained tour with longer runs, the show needs to be underwritten. Your support gets us closer.  This summer fundraiser will give us more time and opportunities to put a polished show in front of producers and brokers for larger, future concert venues.STRETCH GOALSThe $35,000 we are raising from this campaign is just a fraction of our expenses.  With your support, and with every ticket sold, we will continue to fund our productions and marketing efforts until we’re able to bring That’s Not Tango to venues worldwide.    We will post updates and stretch goals as the campaign progresses.  Won't you join us in fulfilling this dream?CLICK HERE TO READ OUR RAVE REVIEWS!Seven years ago, That's Not Tango (so named because Piazzolla's critics insisted that he was destroying the art form) debuted in a Manhattan dance studio.  Since then, the show has grown into a passionate theatrical experience with sold-out performances in a few concert venues, most notably Joe's Pub in New York.  In the show, actor Lesley Karsten occupies a simple stage with three talented musicians. Together, they bring to life the music and legendary imagination of Piazzolla, a restless spirit who betrayed almost everyone he loved on his way to becoming one of the top composers in the world.  In the end, he asks himself an age-old question: Was the sacrifice worth the art?  The show weaves Piazzolla's personal narrative into the fabric of the music.  We meet him at the end of his life, after a cerebral hemorrhage robs him of the ability to play his beloved bandonéon.  We imagine the inner struggle of a man who – trapped in his body and isolated by silence – fears retribution for his sins.  He knew he was destined to make music, even if it meant neglecting his wife and children.  But how does a man repent for sacrificing the hearts of the people who loved him to give voice to his own?  Piazzolla's life story speaks to all who have ever chased a dream. Help us tell it. "The glorious music of Astor Piazzolla tugs at your heart and very soul. The joy of hearing this music with world-class musicians is a very rare treat." -- Philip Greenberg, Artistic Director, Kiev Philharmonic. Piazzolla created a revolution called Tango Nuevo.  Tango Nuevo speaks to anyone who has been separated from home, family and friends, even from themselves.  This is the music of exile.This music -- hauntingly beautiful, often melancholic, always passionate -- is quite simply unforgettable.The music of That's Not Tango is played live on stage by three world-acclaimed musicians:

Nick Danielson, Argentinian-American violinist

Brandt Fredriksen, pianist and educator

JP Jofre, Argentinian bandoneonist
They perform a dozen works -- some in full, some in part -- ranging from the propulsive, rarely performed Très Minutos con la Realidad to the emotionally complex Adios Nonino, Piazzolla's tribute to his late father. Piazzolla's music can change lives. Help us share it."The discovery of Piazzolla was like the finding of some exotic and dangerous potency drug that brings with it the double-edged sword of ecstasy and the bitterest of remorse.” -- John Adams, renowned composerThe man who reimagined Tango led a life of brutality, innocence, and the extraordinary. Repeatedly kicked out of school, fraternizing with street hoodlums, he witnessed a harsh violence and arbitrary cruelty growing up on the mean streets of the Lower East Side in the 1920s. And yet, diverse musical encounters sparked a fever in him.  Piazzolla  grew up listening to Jewish klezmer, Harlem jazz, and his father's scratched tango records.  He was transfixed by the Bach his neighbor, a protege of Rachmaninoff, played.  He even met Carlos Gardel, the " King of Tango," while living in New York.  His return to Argentina at 17 was the beginning of his  lifelong struggle to integrate all these musical influences and elevate Tango from the dance hall to the concert hall. This wild child with no formal training later became one of the most influential composers of the 20th century.  The universality of his music resonates with fans who are just as passionate in Tokyo, Paris and New York as they are in his native Buenos Aires. Today, Piazzolla's music is performed by the finest classical and jazz musicians in the world, among them Yo Yo Ma, Gideon Kremer, Emmanuel Ax, Al Di Meola, Gary Burton, and Paquito d'Rivera.With your help, his story can now share the spotlight with his music. For the past seven years, a seasoned creative team has developed and honed the show to get it ready for touring.  Writer-actor-producer Lesley Karsten, writer-director Stephen Wadsworth, story and music consultants Fernando Gonzalez and Kip Hanrahan, musicians Nick Danielson, Brandt Fredriksen, and JP Jofre -- as well as maestro Piazzolla -- have all contributed their best.  A crew of designers, publicists, and marketers have also worked hard to get the production ready. We need you on our team, too....in celebrating the cross-cultural riches that immigrants bring to our shores....in inspiring the irresistible creative force that resides in all of us....in telling the compelling story of Astor Piazzolla through the power of live music and theatre.HOW TO (Please note that perks do not include any business interests in the show or the company.)Contribute without a perk.  Click on the pink BACK IT button at the very top of the page. You will be prompted to enter a dollar amount for your contribution. (If you have trouble using the Safari browser, please try Chrome.)Become a producing partner.  If you'd like a bigger role than that of a contributor, please contact us at info@thatsnottango.comPlease invite your friends on Facebook and other social media to join us for our campaign! story:
The New Acting Company prides itself in providing a fun, safe, diverse and educational home to hundreds of thousands of actors of all ages and their families in Manhattan for the past 15 years.  The reality is that tuition fees and tickets sales only cover a fraction of our annual production cost.  This year our production budget for the Re-Imagined adaptation of “A Midsummer Nights Dream” adapted by Mary Jo Bono falls short by $5,000.

Through your generous donation children ages 10-14 can continue to experience all elements of play production as they work along side professional designers, directors, choreographers and working adult actors in the New York Theater community.  

Created and Founded in 2000 by Producing Artistic Director, Stephen Michael Rondel, The New Acting Company's mission is to use the energy of live performance (both onstage and in class) to promote responsibility, trust, friendship, teamwork and self-esteem in all ages of the community by offering the opportunity to study, rehearse and perform challenging textsin a professional theater environment.  Our professional productions feature classic plays, fairy tales and original adaptations of children’s and adult literature to entertain, engage, enrich and inspire new and future performing artists.  The New Acting Company strives to be a fun, safe and creative place for children, teens and adults preserving and promoting the artistic and cultural life of their community.

A $100 donation buys stage makeup, personal props, or script copies for a cast member. A $250 donation buys new masking, theater seats, and one full costume. A $500 donation buys new lights, sound equipment, partial set pieces or a box of programs.  A $1000 + donation makes you an honorary NAC member with a name plaque displayed in the theater.

Even if we do not reach our goal through this campaign, you can be confident any all all donations will enrich the lives of the all children involved in this production.  Help bring top quality theater arts to the lower east side and support this worthy company and our re-imagined and re-envisioned version of the classic story loved by all.  Don’t forget each level of giving described below has and exciting bonus gift for you.  All donations are completely tax deductible.

story:
Hi! We're the Tom Collective...

 

and we're a new theatre company dedicated to reclaiming womxn's history by putting womxn and queer people in power on the stage, behind the scenes, on the page, and in every aspect of theatre. The founding members (Anya Kopischke, Emma Webster, and Cora Katz) have a strong history of queering historical texts and retelling historical narratives through a nuanced, modern, feminine perspective.

Right now we're devising our first full-length production going up at the Tank in February. This unnamed original performance will recontextualize the female characters of Greek Tragedy through our most modern form of melodrama: reality television. We're interested in how both Greek Tragedy and reality television have defined "strong womxn" and "hysterical womxn" both onstage and in modern society. Our goal is to reclaim these male-written divas of Greek Tragedy and find their stories' relevance through our generation’s humor and style.

 

We just want to PAY some WOMXN...

We're raising $6000 so we can PAY EVERY SINGLE WOMXN WORKING ON THIS PROJECT.

We're funding our other production costs by other means, but we're coming to YOU to support our effort to pay 12 queer and female-identifying artists $500 each for the experience and talent they are bringing to this amazing project. It's so rare to see womxn get paid what they deserve in the arts, and that's why it's our priority to distribute power AND pay equitably.

And it's really quite the team! Not only are we diverse in our experience, but we come from a variety of artistic backgrounds:

Our incredible cast (Salome Dewell, Nadia Diamond , Cora Katz, Anya Kopischke , and Anjali Sundaram) are not only actors but comedians, musicians, and novelists: all industries where we believe the representation of womxn and queer folk is vital. We are excited to have all these voices make their mark in the rehearsal room, not only as performers, but as writers and creators. 

We value intimate collaboration with designers at every point in the devising process, so we are integrating our sound designer (Leonie Bell,) lighting designer (Ebony Burton,) and costume designer (Karin Kopischke) and our set/props designer (Clara Harlow) into our devising rehearsals. We're so excited to work with a team so versed in professional theatre, experimental movement, and installation art. 

Our fearless director (Emma Webster) and dramaturg (Becca Glasbrenner) have been leading us in a process that feels specifically non-patriarchal and authentic to our experience. The only male presence on our team is our amazing Stage Manager (Alex Allen).

These are the people you will be supporting with your donation. They are multi-talented and well-deserving of fair pay. Even if you are unable to attend this performance, your donation will ensure the production of many more (not to mention the sweet swag headed your way for doing your part in supporting female and queer artists, made by members of our team of course.)

 

We are important because...

What makes this project unique is that every cog in the wheel is run by a queer and/or female-identifying individual, and we're really excited about that. We want to continue making work like this and supporting work like this, not only for the product, but for the process of making something important in a safe environment. As individuals, we have a proven track record of MAKING THESE THINGS HAPPEN. We're OBSESSED with womxn's stories and consistently found a way to create them with nothing but a powerful team. We'd like to extend that ambition to helping support more and more artists like us who are passionate about exploring a queer and female experience.

That, of course, won't be easy. New York City is expensive. Making theatre is expensive. We're a new company and it almost impossible to afford making our own work, much less supporting others. If we want to grow as a company and continue fostering work like this, we need the support of a community like you.

 

We accept NON-MONETARY support as well...

If you're interested in our company and looking for other ways to help out or get involved:

  • Share this campaign with loved ones, enemies, frenemies, work friends, your spunky aunt...
  • We're holding a fundraising event on December 16th. If you're interested in attending, volunteering, or donating services and/or items, email us at thetomcollective@gmail.com
  • Come to SEE THE SHOW at the Tank in NYC! February 7th, 8th, and 9th at 7 pm. We don't think you'll be disappointed, but we dont' know you! Come see the show either way and we can talk about it.

Thanks for reading all the way to the bottom! That's the real hero's work ;)

story:
Overview

Imaginary Theatricals is a new nonprofit theater company in Los Angeles that is producing its second production of Douglas Carter Beane's hit comedy, The Little Dog Laughed, March 19 through 22. We are looking to raise $3,500 to be able to pay our artists as much as possible as well as create a stunning production.

Short Summary

Imaginary Theatricals was founded after I was inspired by my youngest son's reaction to the Disneyland Frozen show. When we saw the show, Kristoff was played by an African American actor. I was unsure how Alex, who is Latinx, would respond (he is a stickler for things looking like they did in the movies and once refused to ride the Haunted Mansion ride because Oogie Boogie--typically just a large, naked green monster--was depicted at the end wearing a Santa hat and beard) but he turned to me after the performance and asked me, "Do you think I can play Olaf some day?" 

The mission of Imaginary Theatricals boils down to producing identity-blind (color-blind, gender-blind, sexual-orientation-blind, etc.) theater that is entertaining. Last year we produced our inaugural production of Kander & Ebb's Cabaret with a deeply diverse cast including trans- and gender-fluid-actors. 

Feedback after the show included "I personally believe that my own expectations that come with the idea of 'musical theatre' had to be challenged and checked at the door when I got involved. And I appreciate and value that experience," "I feel like every person was given a safe space to express themselves and make suggestions--I was blown away by how humble Tripp is--its obvious that he wanted to create a piece of art, not just get exactly what he wanted for this project," "I love the concept of Imaginary Theatricals. The energy of the cast was filled with so much love and excitement for theatre which I was truly honored to be a part of."

We are now producing our second production, Douglas Carter Beane's The Little Dog Laughed from March 19 through March 22. The cast is, to our knowledge, the first diverse cast of this production although one character explicitly refers to himself as white and needed to be cast that way. 

What We Need

Our expense projections are as follows:

As you can see, we currently have a deficit budget that we are trying to raise through this campaign.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute (and that's ok!), but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please share our campaign and get the word out about our production and company.
  • If you are in Los Angeles, come to our Play Date readings and participate as a reader!

Find out more about Imaginary Theatricals from www.imaginarytheatricals.com!

story:
When I was five years old I fell in love with the theatre.  From the time I could sit in a chair and focus, I attended every play, musical, or theatrical performance that was available. I sang with my family in piano bars, and I auditioned for every play that had any part that I might possibly be cast; and when nothing materialized I created my own productions. I dressed up, sang, scripted, danced, and performed. My nickname was Tallulah! Did you do that? Did you want to?

I was especially touched by the story The Wizard of Oz. In the story, Dorothy travels down the yellow brick road in search of home. On her journey she meets the scarecrow who shares that he wants a brain. Dorothy and the scarecrow team up and as they head down the road they run into the Tin man who yearns for a heart. The Tin man joins the other two and further down the road they stumble onto a lion. The lion more than anything wants what he lacks, which is courage. Each one is searching for some part of themselves that they believe is missing. They all admit their deficiencies to each other, extend support for their individual missions, and empathize with the challenge presented. They become a team of individuals who all yearn for something, and they hold the possibility that they might somehow actually get what they want.  As they travel down the yellow brick road they encounter adversity, challenges, and obstacles. Through their determination, teamwork, and commitment to get what each of them wants, they overcome all of the challenges and persevere to the end of their journey. They are all very different in appearance; their wishes are all quite diverse; and even though their capabilities vary greatly, they band together, capitalize on their strengths, focus on their common goal of getting to Oz, and support each other in getting their individual wishes fulfilled. This model for living implanted itself into my mind at a very young age. Perhaps The Wizard of Oz means something special to you as well!

In 1974 I set out to create a similar reality for people through our organization. Our Inner Negotiation Workshop came into existence because my subconscious mind held the possibility of diverse individuals aligning towards a common goal, supporting each other in finding the hidden answers to their puzzles.  That was the birth of the Inner Negotiation Workshop, an environment like the yellow brick road, with highly diverse people with various objectives, who through the group process everyone eventually gets what they wanted. Whether they want to find their feelings, stand up for themselves, stop the voices in their brain, claim their truth, believe in miracles, find the courage to say, “No!” or find their way back to connecting with themselves, all things are possible! In The Workshop, Randi, the leader of the workshop, invites each participant to believe, to trust, and to overcome their challenges, then breakthrough the obstacles and find their own answers. The workshop is about making each individual dream come true. The experience is as magical as the Wizard of OZ.

From my earliest beginnings my love for theatre magnetized these themes to me, “Dreams can become reality!” It resonated so deeply in me that I designed my profession around that premise.

A group of highly diverse individuals who are ready, willing, and able to breakthrough their blind spots, coupled with safety, permission, and the belief that dreams become reality is a new recipe for a totally new genre! When personal development merges with musical theatre, it is called, The Workshop Musical, A Dress Rehearsal for Life!

My sister and I hand picked our favorite segments from our Inner Negotiation Workshop; we created scenarios that we witnessed and then wove it together like a patchwork quilt. Beautiful songs started to dance in my head. Characters started to sing when I awakened in the morning. Lyrics flowed, music manifested, and soon we knew that we absolutely had to produce this magical musical.

My self-doubt kept me holding back, arguing for my limitations. Producing this musical has been my workshop for many years. In between our MMS Coach Trainings and our Inner Negotiation Workshops around the world, we eeked out time to recruit talented musicians and singers who would help us record the songs we composed. Each person played their part and then moved on. When we were introduced to Ken Davenport, Tony Award winning Producer, life changed!  Ken is a self-appointed dream maker. He helps non-industry outsiders build the bridge to making the dream come true. Ken saw something, and he heard something special. Then he felt something resembling hope, passion, and a new way to connect the “Dream Dots.” He became our mentor and guided us to the right director, Justin Baldridge, Musical Director, Geraldine Anello, Casting Director, Michael Cassara, General Manager, Ryan Conway, Assistant GM, Robert Schneider, Graphic artist, Steve Gilewski and most of all, he believed in us.

My husband, sister and I gathered our resources together to launch the “29-Hour Equity Read-through” on October 19th in New York.

Your participation, however small or large will support this dream becoming reality since launching an Off Broadway show is costly. If you love musical theatre, and if you have a passion for personal transformation, and if you dearly want to believe that dreams still can become reality, then dig deep in your heart and your wallet and support this new genre being born. Won’t it be wonderful saying to the world, “I supported that show becoming a hit!”  Won’t you feel proud that you opened a door for people to start believing in the seemingly impossible?

Be a part of the dream! You make the difference! Help others discover how to breakthrough their obstacles as well! Your contribution will pay for the rental of the theatre, Our team: the musicians, our director, musical director, general manager, assistant general manager, casting director, our copyist, the graphic artist, our talented actors, the promotion, and the costumes.

Welcome to our Dream Team creating $75,000 to launch this production!

When you contribute to our campaign...

  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
When I was five years old I fell in love with the theatre.  From the time I could sit in a chair and focus, I attended every play, musical, or theatrical performance that was available. I sang with my family in piano bars, and I auditioned for every play that had any part that I might possibly be cast; and when nothing materialized I created my own productions. I dressed up, sang, scripted, danced, and performed. My nickname was Tallulah! Did you do that? Did you want to?
I was especially touched by the story The Wizard of Oz. In the story, Dorothy travels down the yellow brick road in search of home. On her journey she meets the scarecrow who shares that he wants a brain. Dorothy and the scarecrow team up and as they head down the road they run into the Tin man who yearns for a heart. The Tin man joins the other two and further down the road they stumble onto a lion. The lion more than anything wants what he lacks, which is courage. Each one is searching for some part of themselves that they believe is missing. They all admit their deficiencies to each other, extend support for their individual missions, and empathize with the challenge presented. They become a team of individuals who all yearn for something, and they hold the possibility that they might somehow actually get what they want.  As they travel down the yellow brick road they encounter adversity, challenges, and obstacles. Through their determination, teamwork, and commitment to get what each of them wants, they overcome all of the challenges and persevere to the end of their journey. They are all very different in appearance; their wishes are all quite diverse; and even though their capabilities vary greatly, they band together, capitalize on their strengths, focus on their common goal of getting to Oz, and support each other in getting their individual wishes fulfilled. This model for living implanted itself into my mind at a very young age. Perhaps The Wizard of Oz means something special to you as well!
In 1974 I set out to create a similar reality for people through our organization. Our Inner Negotiation Workshop came into existence because my subconscious mind held the possibility of diverse individuals aligning towards a common goal, supporting each other in finding the hidden answers to their puzzles.  That was the birth of the Inner Negotiation Workshop, an environment like the yellow brick road, with highly diverse people with various objectives, who through the group process everyone eventually gets what they wanted. My sister and I hand picked our favorite segments from our Inner Negotiation Workshop; we created scenarios that we witnessed and then wove it together like a patchwork quilt. Beautiful songs started to dance in my head. Characters started to sing when I awakened in the morning. Lyrics flowed, music manifested, and soon we knew that we absolutely had to produce this magical musical.
My self-doubt kept me holding back, arguing for my limitations. Producing this musical has been my workshop for many years. In between our MMS Coach Trainings and our Inner Negotiation Workshops around the world, we eeked out time to recruit talented musicians and singers who would help us record the songs we composed. Each person played their part and then moved on. When we were introduced to Ken Davenport, Tony Award winning Producer, life changed!  Ken is a self-appointed dream maker. He helps non-industry outsiders build the bridge to making the dream come true. Ken saw something, and he heard something special. Then he felt something resembling hope, passion, and a new way to connect the “Dream Dots.” He became our mentor and guided us to the right director, Justin Baldridge, Musical Director, Geraldine Anello, Casting Director, Michael Cassara, General Manager, Ryan Conway, Assistant GM, Robert Schneider, Graphic artist, Steve Gilewski and most of all, he believed in us.
My husband, sister and I gathered our resources together to launch the “29-Hour Equity Read-through” on October 19th in New York.
Your participation, however small or large will support this dream becoming reality since launching an Off Broadway show is costly. If you love musical theatre, and if you have a passion for personal transformation, and if you dearly want to believe that dreams still can become reality, then dig deep in your heart and your wallet and support this new genre being born. Won’t it be wonderful saying to the world, “I supported that show becoming a hit!”  Won’t you feel proud that you opened a door for people to start believing in the seemingly impossible?
Be a part of the dream! You make the difference! Help others discover how to breakthrough their obstacles as well! Your contribution will pay for the rental of the theatre, Our team: the musicians, our director, musical director, general manager, assistant general manager, casting director, our copyist, the graphic artist, our talented actors, the promotion, and the costumes.
Welcome to our Dream Team creating $75,000 to launch this production!
When you contribute to our campaign...

Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact
Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
Make it real for people and build trust.


Risks & Challenges

story:
Aviatrix uses record breaking pilot Amy Johnson’s international, borderless adventures as the backdrop for stories of migration, adventure and escape. Amy Johnson, born in 1903, was the first woman to fly solo from the UK to Australia.

Your support at this stage of the project will help us to secure the future of Aviatrix, both in Paris and, with any luck, in further opportunities internationally to share this remarkable show.

 

How much do we need and where will your money go?

We are aiming to raise £3,000 which will go towards covering some essential costs:

£  Travel to & from Paris - to get the company and all our set to/from Paris.

£ Artist fees: including time pre-rehearsals to re-edit and re-map the videos, workshop the script and make changes to the original set design. 

£ Rehearsal Space & Accommodation - we've got 10 days to re-work the show in Paris. We've secured the most affordable spaces possible but there is still, of course, a cost to it!

£ Set & Costume - to allow us to make the best possible show with props and costume that support our storytelling on stage

 

Other ways you can help

We appreciate that for many of you it won't be the right time to donate financially, but you can certainly still help us out! If you believe that the project is worth shouting about then please do... this is by far the most important thing you can do to help ensure that we reach our target...

Tweet about the campaign using #Aviatrix

Share it on Facebook and Instagram

Tell your parents, grandparents, friends and distant relatives about the project. Again, even if they don't have the means to support us, they might know someone who does...

Put us in touch with any contacts in the press and any friends who blog regularly.

Put us in touch with anyone you think might be able to help us.

Thank you to one and all who (in whatever way) help us to rework this show.

Our enormous thanks go to Ensemble52 & Dreams Before Dawn Festival for providing us with this indispensable opportunity to bring this story to a wider audience.

story:
Short Summary

Comedy writer/actor duo, Arggy Jenati and Dylan Archambault, are coming to the 2017 Vancouver Fringe Festival with their brand new two person satirical play, "A Night at the Rose Coloured Discotheque". In 2015 they were a hit at the Fringe Festival with their sketch comedy show, "Buy Me Dinner First": making waves and selling out the cultch on their final performance.

Dylan Archambault is the star of the CBC digital series "Coming In" and has numerous film and tv credits with the CW, Lifetime, and Hallmark. Arggy Jenati is a Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts alumni and recently performed in 'The Alice Munroe Stories' at the Belfry Theatre, in Victoria.

These two are set to bring you a bigger, funnier, better show this September from the 7th to the 17th at The Cultch Historic Theatre. However, they need your help. As a young creative duo of emerging artists they are doing it ALL ON THEIR OWN.  They are asking for your support with the production costs of this ambitious show! The goal is $1500+, and any amount is greatly appreciated. Luvs ya!

What We Need & What You Get

The $1500+ will be going directly to the production costs of the play. This includes:

  • Rehearsal Space
  • Costuming
  • Coaching/ Directing Time
  • The live DJ (DJ Trevor Pawson) and equipment that is incorporated into the show
  • A Stage Manager
  • Publicity/ Community Engagement

We want to make this show the very best it can be and any support helps. We do have some awesome perks for your contribution!

WHAT YOU GET:

  • Any contribution of $50 or more gets you two complimentary tickets to any of our six shows in the Fringe from September 7th to 17th. 
  • Any contribution of $120 or more gets you two complimentary tickets to any of our six shows and also a gift delivered to you directly by the two characters of the show Jorge and Toasty.

*NOTE: you will need a fringe membership with these tickets.*

The show takes place at the Cultch Historic Theatre. Show dates are as follows:

  • Thursday September 7th @8:45pm
  • Saturday September 9th @5:15pm
  • Sunday September 10th @9:30pm
  • Tuesday September 12th @5:00pm
  • Friday September 15th @5:35
  • Sunday September 17th @2:30

This is a great opportunity for you to support local artists and get an afternoon or night out to the theatre. Secure yourself a ticket to this fantastic show before they sell out. Select your desired perk level from the column on the right of this page!!

The Impact

Your contribution will go towards supporting a new, young voice. This show brings a fresh new perspective to the theatre community in Vancouver. As  creators Arggy and Dylan focus their comedy on portraying a social commentary on club culture and the harsh new realities of living as a millennial. Presenting a candid dialogue that defies the constraints of traditional theatre. A show that is unapologetically in the here and the now.

Help bring breath to this new voice. Any donation provides the opportunity for these two artists to bring their creation to the stage. THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR YOUR GENEROUS SUPPORT!!

Other Ways You Can Help

DONT HAVE THE CASH? No Prob! Share this campaign on any and all social media to get the word out about the show and help us reach our goal.

INSTA: @rosecoloureddisco

Thanks guys! Luvs ya!

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • We, the students of the bachelor Arts, Culture and Media from Rijksuniversiteit Groningen, come with a theatre production! It will display our interpretation of the play Duck Variations by David Mamet. Our interpretation of the absurdist play is on the current ecological crisis we are facing and sets a critical note on the relationship between men and nature. Theme’s of the Anthropocene, self-destruction, speciesism, and climate change will all pass by in this short play.
  • The Fundraiser is set up as the University has scraped any form of funding for this mandatory event, required for our bachelor. In the past years students have been able to solve this through ticket sales. During the current pandemic we would prefer to scrape this practice and make the  performance free to attend.

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • To realize this project we need 500 euros.* Please help us by donating. All funders automatically get access to the play on the 20th of May regardless of whether the goal is reached!
  • Our crew consists of a talented group of third year theatre students from the University of Groningen, a top 100 global university. Our team includes students from a variety of ethnicities, and beliefs.
  • If the goal is NOT met, the funds will still enter the production but the event will not be free of charge, except to those who already backed the project, a modest entry fee would be required from the wide public.

*The money will mainly be spent on hiring technical equipment, which is needed to realise the online format. Our marketing will mostly be online and the (minimal) offline marketing will be recycled! With regards to costumes, make-up and scenography we try to prevent buying new products as much as possible. The majority will be borrowed or bought second hand in order to minimise our footprint!

 

Risks & Challenges

  • The current corona restrictions applicable in the Netherlands
  • The filmic format of the theatre play

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Share us on Facebook and Instagram, you can find us as Duck Variations or click this link: https://www.facebook.com/search/top?q=Duck%20Variations!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
What We Stand For

One day, director Gary Jones was watching Isaac Li interact with his best friend Elliott Hedley, and he realized that their friendship was reminiscent of the story of George and Lennie from Of Mice and Men. Gary started dreaming up what this production would look like, and shared his idea with Isaac and Elliott. They were both on board immediately to make this dream project a living reality.

Promethean Theater, a local non-profit theater company, is excited to be producing this story, which is a collaboration between artists with disabilities with those without disabilities.

Last summer, Promethean Theater brought to life George Bernard Shaw's "Saint Joan". They took on this beast of a show for their inaugural production, because Isaac Li's friend, Emily Wheeler, always had the dream of playing this strong heroic historical figure. And this is what Promethean Theatre is about. Creating opportunities for local actors, and bringing quality theater to the community at affordable prices. 

Earlier this summer in June (2019), Promethean started a devised theatre initiative called OCEAN.NET, which showed at Havana Theatre. Centered around the condition of the environment and humanity's greedy nature, it brought forth discussion and pushed limits.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Via Indiegogo, we are fundraising for our total $5 000 budget.

All funds go towards Promethean Theater's production of Of Mice and Men.

Come Meet Us

Of Mice and Men runs August 9-10, 13-17, 20-24 at Stage Door Theatre (3102 Main Street, Vancouver). Support us by donating and/or coming to watch the show!

GARY JONES – DIRECTOR

Gary is a Jessie Award-winning playwright whose thirty-year career spans well over two decades! After joining Toronto’s fabled Second City Theatre, Gary moved to Vancouver and never looked back. (He did try but the Rockies blocked his view). He’s a Leo Award-nominated actor who’s worked with the likes of Nick Nolte, Katherine Hepburn and Andre the Seal, one of whom managed to eat an entire bucket of fish a day. He has trodden the boards and graced big and small screen including ten years as Chief Master Sergeant Walter Harriman on the sci-fi smash TV show, Stargate: SG1 while his comedy improv chops took him all the way to Redmond, Washington to perform in the home of Bill & Melinda Gates for them and 90 of their closest nerds. Gary has penned humour columns for Vancouver Magazine, BC Business and the Globe & Mail. He currently writes for CBC Radio’s ‘The Debaters’ as well as teaches at the Vancouver Film School. Gary is beyond chuffed to be directing such a classic play and working with such a stellar team. He lives happily in East Vancouver with Greta & Elliott Hedley who just happen to be helping bring this amazing production to life.

TRISHA LI - ASSISTANT DIRECTOR

An artistic associate and co-founder of Promethean Theatre, Trisha is a local Vancouver actor and graduate of SFU's Theatre program. Her most recent acting credits include Saint Joan (Promethean Theatre) and Life of Galileo (United Players). Trisha grew up in a home that fostered her creative and artistic gifts. Aside from acting, she grew up singing in choirs and taking piano and flute lessons. Other passions include reading, travelling, and learning new languages.

Of Mice and Men has been one of Trisha's favorite books since she was a youth, and she is elated to be able to bring this beautiful story to life on stage.

 

ISAAC LI - PRODUCER

An artistic associate and co-founder of Promethean Theatre, Isaac is a Burnaby-raised acting student at Studio 58 (graduating December 2019).  Directing credits include Saint Joan (Promethean), Chicken Wings & Jell-O Shots (Studio 58). Acting credits include Cabaret (Studio 58), Mortified (Studio 58), Cinderella: Panto (Metro), Love's Labour's Lost (Alchemy). When not anywhere near a theatre, Isaac can either be found with his two snakes, his three family, or his four friends.

 

THEO BELL - TECHNICAL DIRECTOR, LIGHTING & SOUND DESIGNER

Theo Bell is an up-and-coming Vancouver based scenographer(lighting, sound, set, and projection designer), technical director and Studio 58 graduate. He has designed with, and technically assisted, such companies as Zee Zee Theatre, A Stones Throw Production, The Solo Collective, Classic chic, Green Thumb Theatre, Chutzpah Fest, The Shameless Hussies, Peninsula Productions and of course Studio 58. “Being South London born, and East Vancouver raised, I’ve had a multitude of viewpoints into different economic and cultural sides of life. Having embraced the rebellious side of arts expressionism, through painting and music while also aligning with the forward-thinking nature of technology, though projection and lighting, I believe I have a wide range of experiences to draw from, for my designs."

 

GRETA HEDLEY - COSTUME DESIGNER

A graduate of London’s Wimbledon School of Fine Arts with a degree in Theatre Design, Greta’s thirty-year costume-design career has spanned theatre, film, television, commercials & print. Her creative muse has answered the call from such diverse clients as London’s ‘Queens Theatre’ to Vancouver’s ‘Tamanhous Theatre,’ as well musical icons Michael Bublé, Tom Jones and global super-group Oasis. She currently works with the Surrey School Board as an Expressive Arts Therapist helping refugee children gain access to their emotions that have been suppressed through the trauma of war and displacement. She is thrilled to be costume-designing for this labour of love and working with her lovely son, Elliott.

 

MARCUS VAILLANT - PROPS AND SET DESIGNER

Marcus is a Lower Mainland based, Set, Prop and Costume Designer. He is proud to be apart of such an exciting and meaningful show that allows such inclusivity and diversity.

Marcus Vaillant is a graduate of Studio 58

Previous credits include:

Production Crew Member at Bard on the Beach,Stage Manager for Looking for Tiger Lilly with Full Circle Theatre, Assistant to the Set Designer for “Mortified” with Studio 58, Stage Manager for “I Know What I Saw” with Studio 58, Production Designer for Romeo and Juliet with Place Des Arts, Set/Prop Designer/ Stage Manager for Saint Joan with Promethean Theatre, Stage Manager for FourPlay Program B 2018 with Studio 58

SHAYLYN HANEY - STAGE MANAGER

Shaylyn has two years of stage management and development, and is currently studying in Studio 58 for theatre production. She is very excited to work on Of Mice and Men with an amazing cast and crew.

DIYALLA MALIJIAN - ASSISTANT STAGE MANAGER

Diyalla is her name and passion is her game, whether it is food, the arts, travelling, history, Supernatural, family, or friends. Diyalla is currently completing her bachelor’s in psychology at Simon Fraser University. She also has her eyes set on attaining a minor in Greek history, especially after taking two courses in the study abroad program in Greece through SFU. In the future she hopes to work with youth and make a difference as well as balancing out time for exploring the world. Diyalla has been working as a child care and youth program leader since 2009. She loves working with kids and helping youth in her community. When she is not enriching her mind with knowledge at school or getting her dose of fulfilment at work, Diyalla can be found in her room, slaying dragons on her PS3. Don’t worry they are bad demonic dragons.
story_txt:
What We Stand ForOne day, director Gary Jones was watching Isaac Li interact with his best friend Elliott Hedley, and he realized that their friendship was reminiscent of the story of George and Lennie from Of Mice and Men. Gary started dreaming up what this production would look like, and shared his idea with Isaac and Elliott. They were both on board immediately to make this dream project a living reality.Promethean Theater, a local non-profit theater company, is excited to be producing this story, which is a collaboration between artists with disabilities with those without disabilities.Last summer, Promethean Theater brought to life George Bernard Shaw's "Saint Joan". They took on this beast of a show for their inaugural production, because Isaac Li's friend, Emily Wheeler, always had the dream of playing this strong heroic historical figure. And this is what Promethean Theatre is about. Creating opportunities for local actors, and bringing quality theater to the community at affordable prices. Earlier this summer in June (2019), Promethean started a devised theatre initiative called OCEAN.NET, which showed at Havana Theatre. Centered around the condition of the environment and humanity's greedy nature, it brought forth discussion and pushed limits.
 
What We Need & What You Get

Via Indiegogo, we are fundraising for our total $5 000 budget.
All funds go towards Promethean Theater's production of Of Mice and Men.

Come Meet Us
Of Mice and Men runs August 9-10, 13-17, 20-24 at Stage Door Theatre (3102 Main Street, Vancouver). Support us by donating and/or coming to watch the show!

GARY JONES – DIRECTOR
Gary is a Jessie Award-winning playwright whose thirty-year career spans well over two decades! After joining Toronto’s fabled Second City Theatre, Gary moved to Vancouver and never looked back. (He did try but the Rockies blocked his view). He’s a Leo Award-nominated actor who’s worked with the likes of Nick Nolte, Katherine Hepburn and Andre the Seal, one of whom managed to eat an entire bucket of fish a day. He has trodden the boards and graced big and small screen including ten years as Chief Master Sergeant Walter Harriman on the sci-fi smash TV show, Stargate: SG1 while his comedy improv chops took him all the way to Redmond, Washington to perform in the home of Bill & Melinda Gates for them and 90 of their closest nerds. Gary has penned humour columns for Vancouver Magazine, BC Business and the Globe & Mail. He currently writes for CBC Radio’s ‘The Debaters’ as well as teaches at the Vancouver Film School. Gary is beyond chuffed to be directing such a classic play and working with such a stellar team. He lives happily in East Vancouver with Greta & Elliott Hedley who just happen to be helping bring this amazing production to life.

TRISHA LI - ASSISTANT DIRECTOR
An artistic associate and co-founder of Promethean Theatre, Trisha is a local Vancouver actor and graduate of SFU's Theatre program. Her most recent acting credits include Saint Joan (Promethean Theatre) and Life of Galileo (United Players). Trisha grew up in a home that fostered her creative and artistic gifts. Aside from acting, she grew up singing in choirs and taking piano and flute lessons. Other passions include reading, travelling, and learning new languages.
Of Mice and Men has been one of Trisha's favorite books since she was a youth, and she is elated to be able to bring this beautiful story to life on stage.
 
ISAAC LI - PRODUCER
An artistic associate and co-founder of Promethean Theatre, Isaac is a Burnaby-raised acting student at Studio 58 (graduating December 2019).  Directing credits include Saint Joan (Promethean), Chicken Wings & Jell-O Shots (Studio 58). Acting credits include Cabaret (Studio 58), Mortified (Studio 58), Cinderella: Panto (Metro), Love's Labour's Lost (Alchemy). When not anywhere near a theatre, Isaac can either be found with his two snakes, his three family, or his four friends.
 
THEO BELL - TECHNICAL DIRECTOR, LIGHTING & SOUND DESIGNER
Theo Bell is an up-and-coming Vancouver based scenographer(lighting, sound, set, and projection designer), technical director and Studio 58 graduate. He has designed with, and technically assisted, such companies as Zee Zee Theatre, A Stones Throw Production, The Solo Collective, Classic chic, Green Thumb Theatre, Chutzpah Fest, The Shameless Hussies, Peninsula Productions and of course Studio 58. “Being South London born, and East Vancouver raised, I’ve had a multitude of viewpoints into different economic and cultural sides of life. Having embraced the rebellious side of arts expressionism, through painting and music while also aligning with the forward-thinking nature of technology, though projection and lighting, I believe I have a wide range of experiences to draw from, for my designs."
 
GRETA HEDLEY - COSTUME DESIGNER
A graduate of London’s Wimbledon School of Fine Arts with a degree in Theatre Design, Greta’s thirty-year costume-design career has spanned theatre, film, television, commercials & print. Her creative muse has answered the call from such diverse clients as London’s ‘Queens Theatre’ to Vancouver’s ‘Tamanhous Theatre,’ as well musical icons Michael Bublé, Tom Jones and global super-group Oasis. She currently works with the Surrey School Board as an Expressive Arts Therapist helping refugee children gain access to their emotions that have been suppressed through the trauma of war and displacement. She is thrilled to be costume-designing for this labour of love and working with her lovely son, Elliott.
 
MARCUS VAILLANT - PROPS AND SET DESIGNERMarcus is a Lower Mainland based, Set, Prop and Costume Designer. He is proud to be apart of such an exciting and meaningful show that allows such inclusivity and diversity.
Marcus Vaillant is a graduate of Studio 58Previous credits include:
Production Crew Member at Bard on the Beach,Stage Manager for Looking for Tiger Lilly with Full Circle Theatre, Assistant to the Set Designer for “Mortified” with Studio 58, Stage Manager for “I Know What I Saw” with Studio 58, Production Designer for Romeo and Juliet with Place Des Arts, Set/Prop Designer/ Stage Manager for Saint Joan with Promethean Theatre, Stage Manager for FourPlay Program B 2018 with Studio 58
SHAYLYN HANEY - STAGE MANAGER
Shaylyn has two years of stage management and development, and is currently studying in Studio 58 for theatre production. She is very excited to work on Of Mice and Men with an amazing cast and crew.
DIYALLA MALIJIAN - ASSISTANT STAGE MANAGER
Diyalla is her name and passion is her game, whether it is food, the arts, travelling, history, Supernatural, family, or friends. Diyalla is currently completing her bachelor’s in psychology at Simon Fraser University. She also has her eyes set on attaining a minor in Greek history, especially after taking two courses in the study abroad program in Greece through SFU. In the future she hopes to work with youth and make a difference as well as balancing out time for exploring the world. Diyalla has been working as a child care and youth program leader since 2009. She loves working with kids and helping youth in her community. When she is not enriching her mind with knowledge at school or getting her dose of fulfilment at work, Diyalla can be found in her room, slaying dragons on her PS3. Don’t worry they are bad demonic dragons.

story:
Sour Grapes Productions

As a female-owned theater, we do everything we can bring our voices to the stage. Between our two co-founders, we work about 5 jobs in order to pay NY rent AND do our theatrical productions. We've created our Shakesqueer collection, which adapts Shakespeare pieces into productions that include LGBTQ+ characters into the leading roles. We have a monthly mime show at The Tank. We do a yearly New Years Eve show. and a ton of other projects throughout the entire year. But the world is expensive, and in order to pay people properly AND make sure our shows are something our casts can be proud of, we need more money than we can ever find.

What We Need

While we know that we're not going to reach our full goal (theater people mostly know other theater people, and we're all starving artists out here), here's what our expenses usually are:

- $150-$250 tech PER PRODUCTION
- $300 costume budget per production
- $150 props budget per production
- $100 season-long stage makeup budget
- $300 season-long advertising budget
- $2500 performance rights (one show per season - rest are original pieces)
- $400 instrument rental, musicians, etc (one show per season)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, feel free to share! You can also reach out to find a way to buy tickets for our upcoming projects.

story:
Do you believe in ghosts?

Test your resolve with THE BROTHERS PARANORMAL, a new play by Prince Gomolvilas and directed by Mimi Katano.

Since 2007, Pork Filled Productions has guided audiences on larger than life adventures with Chinese American con artists, Shakespearean zombies, and steampunk heroes and villains. This fall, we’re piercing the veil between the world of the living and the world of ghosts with Prince Golmovilas’ THE BROTHERS PARANORMAL.

Max and Visarut, two Thai American brothers, have been struggling to make ends meet with their ghost-hunting business, and when Delia comes to them asking for help with an “Asian-looking ghost,” Max smells an opportunity. What began as a cash-grab soon becomes something much more serious and everyone’s notions of reality will soon be tested.

PFP has loved THE BROTHERS PARANORMAL ever since we partnered with Prince for a workshop reading in 2015. We’re excited to bring this to fruition as part of the play’s rolling world premiere.

THE BROTHERS PARANORMAL is a deeply intersectional play, as it brings together Thai and Black characters in the American Midwest, explores questions of immigration and displacement, and tackles the topic of mental illness and grief within communities of color -- all while telling a spooky story that will delight fans of THE GRUDGE and THE HAUNTING OF HILL HOUSE.

What do we need?

Our budget currently covers stipends for our actors and designers and all minimal production costs, but we would love to be able to do more. All funds raised through this IndieGogo campaign will be used directly for this production: approximately 70% will be added to the design budget, 20% will help offset rental fees, and 10% will go toward our marketing costs. Our main goal with this fundraiser is to give our designers more financial freedom to create fantastical props, sets, and costumes to give our audiences the most terrifying experience possible.

Meet the team.

Featuring (top row, left) Kathy Hsieh, Sean Nguyen, Van Lang Pham; (bottom row; left) Selena Whitaker-Paquiet, Margaret Luxamon Hotchkiss, and Ronnie Hill.

Written by Price Gomolvilas

Directed by Mimi Katano

Josh Valdez (Stage Manager), Alan Alabastro (PR Photographer), Kim Douthit (Dramaturge), Carolina Johnson (Lighting Designer), Janelle Kimbrough (Costume Designer), Troy Lund (Sound Designer), Robin Macartney (Set and Prop Designer), Merri Ann Osbourne (Community Consultant), Chanya Swartz (Cultural Consultant), Troy Tsukahara (Graphic Designer), Lydia Valentine (Cultural Consultant)

Not easy. But worth it.

Producing new work may not be as scary as encountering a ghost in your new home, but it certainly carries some risks with it. The PFP producers aren’t scared of the dark, though, and we’ve assembled a team of talented artists to help us out. Director Mimi Katano has a long track record of stellar work as Artistic Director of Youth Theatre Northwest. Moreover, as part of our commitment to producing thoughtful, well-informed, authentic work by artists of color, we’re working with dramaturgs and cultural consultants from Thailand, local Thai and African American communities, and Seattle’s horror fandom, who can bring their lived experience and subject matter expertise to the project. 

THE BROTHERS PARANORMAL is in many ways a new kind of play for Pork Filled Productions: we’ve dipped our toes into the horror genre before with Qui Nguyen’s Living Dead in Denmark, but this is our first time producing a ghost play. That comes with new special effects challenges. It’s also a kind of play that Seattle audiences don’t get a chance to see much: one that centers a cross-cultural cast of characters and supernatural elements to tell a rich, emotional, humorous story. That gives us the opportunity to tell a new kind of story to a new audience -- once we reach them. 

Part of Pork Filled Productions’ mission has always been to bring the best of genre theatre to mainstream audiences. We put a (literal) spotlight on how fantasy, horror, and sci-fi investigates big questions and deep truths. We’ve also always been dedicated to telling stories with and creating opportunities for artists of color; with this play we’re excited to be employing six talented actors of color onstage and a diverse production team of local theatre artists.

Special announcements

THE BROTHERS PARANORMALis supported by the Office of Arts & Culture Seattle and 4Culture. PFP is fiscally sponsored by Shunpike. Our community partners include the Mahogany Project and the Southeast Asia Center in the Jackson School for International Studies at the University of Washington. Shunpike is the 501(c)(3) non-profit agency that provides independent arts groups in Washington with the services, resources and opportunities they need to forge their own paths to sustainable success. Pork Filled Productions is a proud member of TeenTix. 

Stay connected.

For more info and updates, please visit our website: www.porkfilled.com

Like us on Facebook, or follow us on Twitter!
