story:
What's this?

Hello! My name is Nicole von Arx. I am a Swiss/British choreographer and performer. I create, direct and produce choreographic works under the name NVA & Guests. I am producing and premiering my very first evening-length piece SCARLET September 21st & 22nd at the historic Judson Memorial Church in New York City. This is by far the most exciting opportunity I have had as a choreographer. I hope you can make it to one of our shows!

I am extremely lucky to work with some of the most sought after dancers in New York City. Discover who they are below! I've also hired two brilliant designers who are creating costumes and headpieces for us this very instant. 

Your contributions big or small will help me pay for our costumes, rehearsal space, music, and our fees.

What is SCARLET?

In SCARLET, NVA & Guests will experiment with methods that implore audience members to question whether performers’ bodies have been objectified. We aim to ask the audience about their desires for their unique gender’s self-preservation in a world that asks us to each present a binary, gender-conforming self.

How your help will impact us?

In order to facilitate the first edition of this work, we are looking to raise $5000 to help cover the costs of the production.

These costs include:

  • Space Rental of Judson Memorial Church
  • Rehearsal Studio Rentals
  • Artist Fees for 5 dancers
  • Lighting Designer/Technician to create the lighting plan
  • Props and Costumes
  • Photographer/Videographer for documentation and promotion
  • Promotional Efforts

For your support, you will be rewarded with many perks including Social Media shout-outs, invitations to private rehearsals, private Pilates classes, special and personal gifts and even tickets to a performance of your choice during the run!!  

We hope you can support this exciting new adventure for Nicole von Arx / NVA & Guests!

Who's who?

Born in England and raised in both Switzerland and Hong Kong, Nicole von Arx (choreographer and dancer) is a freelance dancer and choreographer based between Brooklyn and Geneva (Switzerland). She studied at The Ailey School and San Francisco Conservatory of Dance. Her performance career led her to work with Jasmin Vardimon, Carte Blanche, Company XIV, Bryan Arias Company and Loni Landon Dance Projects. As a choreographer, she was invited to present her work in Europe at the BFM, TanzFest Winterthur 2018, La Fête de la Musique on the stage of l’ADC, and the Flux in Switzerland, and at Reykjavík Culture Night in Iceland. In the US, her choreography appeared at the Center for Performance Research (CPR), the Museum of Moving Image, Judson Church, Last Frontier, The Battery Dance Festival, The Wild Project, The 14th Street Y, the Ailey Citigroup Theatre and Sam Houston State University. She was awarded the 2018 STUFFED summer residency at Judson Church and the 2017 Dance Gallery Festival Level UP program. Nicole now creates work under the name NVA & Guests and teaches in New York at Gibney and Gallim’s company classes. (Photo by James Jin)

(www.nvonarx.com) | (ig @nicolevarx @nva.and.guests)

 

Claude “CJ” Johnson (dancer) hails from Chicago IL, where he began his formal dance training at the Chicago Academy for the Arts under the direction of Randy Duncan. He later on continued his dance training at Suny Purchase College where he received his BFA in theater performance and composition. He was awarded the Adopt-A-Dancer Scholarship. Cj’s has performed works by choreographers Johannes Weiland, Aszure Barton, Doug Varone, Kevin Wynn, Rosalind Newman, Alexandra Beller, and Stuart Loungway. Cj also attended intensive dance programs Hubbard Street Dance Chicago, Doug Varone summer intensive, Movement Invention Project, and Springboard Dance Montreal under the direction of Alexandra Wells where he performed work by Shannon Gillen and Elia Mrak. Cj is also a company member of "Abraham In Motion" under the Artistic Directorship of Kyle Abraham as of August of 2017.

(ig @cj4400)

 

At the age of five, Zachary Gonder (dancer) started dancing at The Dance Connection, a local studio in his hometown north of Chicago. He then trained at the Chicago Academy for the Arts High School under the tutelage of renowned choreographer Randy Duncan. He graduated from Juilliard in 2018 and performed works there by Austin McCormick, José Limón, Aszure Barton, Pam Tanowitz, Richard Alston, Gustavo Ramirez Sansano and Crystal Pite. Zachary has worked for BODYTRAFFIC in L.A. as well as the Barton Sisters’ Axis Connect Program. He performed in Pam Tanowitz’s ‘Four Quartets’ at Bard College and the Barbican Theatre in London. Currently he also dances for Brian Brooks Moving Company and Zvi Dance. Zachary is excited to be dancing with NVA & Guests. (Photo by Richard Corman for Axis Connect)

(ig @zag11)

 

Julia Discenza (dancer) was born and raised in Hartford, CT. In 2014, she earned her B.A. in Biology and Dance from Barnard College, Columbia University. She has studied contemporary dance in Paris, Berlin, and Italy, where she trained in Flying Low, Countertechnique and Gaga. Julia has performed with Colleen Thomas Dance, Trainor Dance, NathanTrice|RITUALS, Stefanie Nelson Dancegroup, Soluq Dance Theater, MICHIYAYA, Pilobolus, Gibney Dance Company, Bryan Arias, Gregory Dolbashian’s DASH Ensemble, NobleMotion Dance, and is a current collaborator with Nicole Von Arx and Guests. Also a professional photographer and filmmaker, Julia has choreographed, directed, shot, and edited dance films for the past several years. (Photo by Scott Shaw)

(ig @jdisc)

 

Christine Flores (dancer) is originally from Toronto, Ontario and graduated from New World School of the Arts (Miami) in 2015 with a BFA in Dance. She received additional training at Springboard Danse Montreal, the Contemporary Program at Jacob's Pillow, and Cunningham Fellowship workshops. She has worked with Peter Chu, Crossman Dans(c)e, Isodoc Dance Group, Emma Portner, Chase Brock Experience, and Tania Perez Salas Dance Company (Mexico). Christine is currently based out of New York City and is working with Pam Tanowitz Dance, Company XIV, Caleb Teicher & Company, and Shinsa Collective. She has taught numerous workshops in NY and Canada, such as Beyond Movement Intensive and at Sean Boutilier Academy of Dance, as well as masterclasses for Pam Tanowitz Dance. Christine is thrilled to be working with Nicole von Arx! (Photo by Stephanie Crousillat)

(ig @christinefl0res)

 

Tommy Cobau (Costume Designer) is a milliner and costume crafts artisan based in New York, NY. After graduating from the University of Cincinnati CCM, he has worked with many theatrical companies including the Santa Fe Opera, Lynne Mackey Studio, and Arnold S. Levine Inc. making headwear and accessories for Broadway and regional companies from coast to coast.

(https://www.tommycobau.com | ig @tommycobau)

Born and raised in the Poconos, Pennsylvania, Caitlin Taylor (Costume Designer) moved to New York City to attend Marymount Manhattan College where she graduated with a B.F.A. in Dance. In addition to her background in dance, Caitlin works in costume production. After graduation, she began working as a costume and wardrobe assistant for the Ailey School and Elena Comendador at Treehouse Productions, building for companies such as Shen Wei Dance Arts, Complexions, and American Ballet Theatre’s Make A Ballet. Caitlin has designed costumes for Marymount Manhattan College, Cirio Collective, Sidra Bell Dance New York, MADBOOTS, The Dash Ensemble, LoudHound Movement, and has also done costume reconstruction for Alexander Whitley Dance Company and the touring production of RENT. Caitlin has done wardrobe independently for Stephen Petronio Company, Shen Wei Dance Arts, The Juilliard School, Limón Dance Company, and Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Assisting designer Marc Eric Rodriguez, Caitlin recently worked on commissions for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Ailey II, 10HL, and Ballet X. (Photo by JJ Geiger)

(ig @caitlingtaylor)

Zachary has worked for BODYTRAFFIC in L.A. as well as the Barton Sisters’ Axis Connect Program. He performed in Pam Tanowitz’s ‘Four Quartets’ at Bard College and the Barbican Theatre in London. Currently he also dances for Brian Brooks Moving Company and Zvi Dance. Zachary is excited to be dancing with NVA & Guests. (Photo by Richard Corman for Axis Connect)(ig @zag11) Julia Discenza (dancer) was born and raised in Hartford, CT. In 2014, she earned her B.A. in Biology and Dance from Barnard College, Columbia University. She has studied contemporary dance in Paris, Berlin, and Italy, where she trained in Flying Low, Countertechnique and Gaga. Julia has performed with Colleen Thomas Dance, Trainor Dance, NathanTrice|RITUALS, Stefanie Nelson Dancegroup, Soluq Dance Theater, MICHIYAYA, Pilobolus, Gibney Dance Company, Bryan Arias, Gregory Dolbashian’s DASH Ensemble, NobleMotion Dance, and is a current collaborator with Nicole Von Arx and Guests. Also a professional photographer and filmmaker, Julia has choreographed, directed, shot, and edited dance films for the past several years. (Photo by Scott Shaw)(ig @jdisc) Christine Flores (dancer) is originally from Toronto, Ontario and graduated from New World School of the Arts (Miami) in 2015 with a BFA in Dance. She received additional training at Springboard Danse Montreal, the Contemporary Program at Jacob's Pillow, and Cunningham Fellowship workshops. She has worked with Peter Chu, Crossman Dans(c)e, Isodoc Dance Group, Emma Portner, Chase Brock Experience, and Tania Perez Salas Dance Company (Mexico). Christine is currently based out of New York City and is working with Pam Tanowitz Dance, Company XIV, Caleb Teicher & Company, and Shinsa Collective. She has taught numerous workshops in NY and Canada, such as Beyond Movement Intensive and at Sean Boutilier Academy of Dance, as well as masterclasses for Pam Tanowitz Dance. Christine is thrilled to be working with Nicole von Arx! (Photo by Stephanie Crousillat)(ig @christinefl0res) Tommy Cobau (Costume Designer) is a milliner and costume crafts artisan based in New York, NY. After graduating from the University of Cincinnati CCM, he has worked with many theatrical companies including the Santa Fe Opera, Lynne Mackey Studio, and Arnold S. Levine Inc. making headwear and accessories for Broadway and regional companies from coast to coast.(https://www.tommycobau.com | ig @tommycobau)Born and raised in the Poconos, Pennsylvania, Caitlin Taylor (Costume Designer) moved to New York City to attend Marymount Manhattan College where she graduated with a B.F.A. in Dance. In addition to her background in dance, Caitlin works in costume production. After graduation, she began working as a costume and wardrobe assistant for the Ailey School and Elena Comendador at Treehouse Productions, building for companies such as Shen Wei Dance Arts, Complexions, and American Ballet Theatre’s Make A Ballet. Caitlin has designed costumes for Marymount Manhattan College, Cirio Collective, Sidra Bell Dance New York, MADBOOTS, The Dash Ensemble, LoudHound Movement, and has also done costume reconstruction for Alexander Whitley Dance Company and the touring production of RENT. Caitlin has done wardrobe independently for Stephen Petronio Company, Shen Wei Dance Arts, The Juilliard School, Limón Dance Company, and Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. Assisting designer Marc Eric Rodriguez, Caitlin recently worked on commissions for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Ailey II, 10HL, and Ballet X. (Photo by JJ Geiger)(ig @caitlingtaylor)

story:
About the Writer

My name is Nyla Levy, I am an Actor and Playwright. I’m mixed race Pakistani and Canadian, with Muslim and Jewish heritage, born and raised in the UK. I have always gravitated towards stories that explore identity, race and culture.

As an actor, I’ve often played the role of ‘terrorist’s girlfriend’ or Jihadi bride, and felt that these roles were always supporting the male characters story and that the dialogue didn’t feel real. 

In 2016, whilst playing a Jihadi Bride in a Theatre In Education play, the students interviewed our characters, and often ended up getting to a point where they understood why the girl I was playing felt she had no other options, but to join ISIS. As a result the students felt they ‘learnt to make Muslims in my community feel more welcome”. Rather than demonising them, by understating the humanity of the person, we created a change in views. At that point I knew I wanted to write a play that explored this and exposed the humanity of a typically demonised character to bring light to reasons behind radicalisation.

The Creative Team 

The subject matter of the play centres around the lives of two young British Asian girls, therefore it is important for the team to have an understanding of the experience of growing up as a young person of colour in Britain today.  As a writer and producer, I am able to ensure that more job opportunities are provided to women and people of colour, whether that is written into the script or actively seeking other creatives to work with. 

What We Need & What You Get

£483 (Equity Minimum) Actor fee for 1 week. 

We have 3 Actors, so £483 x 3 actors = £1,449 

£483 (Equity Minimum) Director fee for 1 week

£500 stage manager fee for the week

£550 rehearsal space hire for the week

Total = £2,982

 

Perks!

£5 - Shout out & follow on social media

£20 - Listed on Tamasha's website as official supporter

£100 + - Listed on Tamasha's website as an official supporter, and credited on our free sheets which are given to all audience members at every performance. 

 

If we don’t reach our goal the funds will still go towards the rehearsal, depending how much we raise, we will pay for as much extra rehearsal time as possible.

 

The Impact

I have been developing Does My Bomb Look Big in This? since 2016,  and now more than ever it appears to now be such a relevant and timely piece.

In a world where black and white views are ever increasing, Does My Bomb Look Big in This? offers a multitude of view points within the story. 

As an actor I was researching this topic since 2014. When I received funding from Arts Council England in 2018, I was able to expand my research which included  interviews with Muslim Community leaders in Luton, who shared their experiences of Islamophobia, as well as with Tasnime Akunjee, Terrorism Defence Solicitor, and school children in London. 

AUDIENCE FEEDBACK:

“I want all my pupils to see this, those with parents in the EDL, and those at risk of radicalisation.” -Kim Head – Head at Avenue Centre Luton (education centre for excluded children)

“It was an incredibly accurate representation. Spot on. For me it was deeply moving” -Tasnime Akunjee – Terrorism Defence Solicitor

“Strong, very honest, disarming, real & fresh voice” - Lyric Hammersmith

“Raw and captivating.” - Redbridge Drama Centre

"Loved it! Very truthful and eye opening, tackles serious issues within society which need to be spoken about." Battersea Arts Centre

"A female self-confident...much needed piece" Battersea Arts Centre

 

WORKSHOPS 

We will be touring Does My Bomb Look Big in This? to rural venues across the UK. Alongside the performances we will be offering workshops to young people. Unpacking the themes of Lies, Truth, Power, and Manipulation, with reference to scenes from Does My Bomb Look Big in This?. Participants will explore these themes dramatically, with all participants given the chance to perform in improvisations or readings. Led by a professional Tamasha Developing Artist, or Nyla Levy, subject to availability. Workshop includes practical exercises for participants to generate their own characters, scenarios, giving a deeper understanding of how vulnerable young people are manipulated, and how to avoid dangerous people/situations.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Cash can be tight, and if you are unable to support financially but still want to help - please share this with your networks!

Any help will be hugely appreciated!

And in the wise words of Tesco: "Every little helps!"

Thank you!!!

story:
WHO ARE WE?

Less Theatre is a London based puppetry company, which prides itself on creating new and original theatre. Striving towards sustainable practice and inspired by the simple pleasures of the world, all aspects of our shows are created out of locally sourced, recycled and found materials. Our puppetry breathes new life into objects often overlooked to give them shape and character.  

Our debut show EDEN premiered at Edinburgh Fringe festival in 2016. The show received high public and industry reviews as well being named finalist for the Edinburgh Fringe Sustainable Practice Award 2016. It was during our time up in Edinburgh that we realised the potential of the company, and the true effect our puppets can have on audience members young and old!  

Less Theatre was established by Jess Aquilina in 2015. Jess is a recent graduate of the Guildford School of Acting and works as freelance actor, puppeteer and workshop facilitator. As an actor she has worked with companies such as Culture Clash Theatre (Under My Thumb, Greenwich Theatre), and Flabbergast Theatre (Macbeth, wilton's Music Hall) and as a Facilitator has worked for Create Arts, NCS and WestEnd In Schools.

For this show Less Theatre is joined by associate artist Megan Fitzpatrick. Megan is a graduate of Mountview Academy and works as a designer, performer and producer. Megan is the co-founder of ‘The Out of Work Collective’ and ‘EMPOWhER’; credits include ‘Ordinary Days’(The Rose & Crown), ‘Reagan Kelly’(Lion & Unicorn), ‘Pinot!’ (New Wimbledon Theatre Studios), ‘Time for women to take the lead’ and ‘And the award goes to…!’(The Water Rats).

 

WHAT’S THE PROJECT?

We believe that theatre can reflect the world as it is but more impressively can show the world as we want it to be and this is where our new show "The Adventure of Ari and the Disappearing Hand” fits in!

Our story follows Ari, a young boy who stumbles upon an adventure when he falls into the world of an old book. It doesn’t take long for Ari to notice that the characters he meets are in trouble, they are slowly starting to fade away and when Ari learns why- he know he wants to help! 

The story features characters based upon real women who are bold, brilliant and been breaking down barriers in their respective fields of work - each one of them imparting a little piece of their story onto Ari as they help him in his quest to save the book and characters. 

A bright and exciting family show with puppets, queens and world leaders to admire - The Adventures of Ari and the disappearing hand will be a celebration of women who have made history and those who follow it their footsteps - pushing boundaries and making waves - history is written by women too!

BUT WHY?

To quote one of the brilliant women featured in our show “I had no concept that a woman couldn’t or shouldn’t do anything … and I simply had the view ‘Why can’t I?’” That view, these women and their stories are so inspiring. Our show not only brings these characters to a new audience but also gives a group of performers chance to play some truly fantastic women. 


WE NEED YOUR HELP!

At Less Theatre we believe in equal and fair pay.  Even though a large cost for producing a show has been covered with free rehearsal space,  we still need help raising funds to pay for our creative team of six people for a week, covering the cost of their expenses and offering a contribution to their pay. The Equity minimum wage for a creative for just one week is £480, and we need to fundraise for six…..

ANY contribution you can offer, big or small, will be welcomed. If we don’t raise to our goal we will still go ahead with the project- because this is a story that needs to be told!

story:
The mission of the historic Complex Hollywood is to serve Los Angeles' intimate theatre community and its audiences by offering well appointed theaters in which magic is made. 

The Complex Hollywood is home to 5 theaters and 5 studios located in the heart of Hollywood’s Theatre Row on Santa Monica Boulevard. In a given year, we host more than:

  • 2,000 classes
  • 250 theatrical productions 
  • 50 film festivals 
  • dozens of workshops, comedy shows, films shoots, and screenings 
  • 30,000 artists of all disciplines

Wow!

Our spaces have been well-used and well-loved since the 1970s as part of a rich tradition of theatre in Hollywood. Today, we're turning to our community to ask you to invest in the future of Hollywood theatre by making a gift to our Indiegogo campaign.

It's time to make capital improvements at the Complex, but the affordable rental rates that make the Complex a haven for artists don’t leave much wiggle room for big updates. With your help, the Complex's highly skilled, dedicated staff of theatre artists can make technical and practical upgrades to our theaters and studios, while continuing to offer artists affordable spaces in which to create.

With funds from our Indiegogo campaign we will:

  • Replace outdated theatrical grids
  • Purchase energy efficient LED lighting instruments
  • Install sound-proof doors on the entrances to our spaces.

And if we surpass our goal, we'll continue making capital improvements, including updating stage walls and floors and replacing audience seating. 

Can you help us reach our goal? If the Complex has played a role in your artistic journey, now is the time to give back. Thank you for your support and for sharing our campaign with the art-lovers in your life. We can't wait to welcome you to the new and improved Complex Hollywood!

story:
Short Summary 

I am Carisa Carroll, Artistic Director of Palm Dance Collective(PDC). I am from Santa Barbara where I danced with State Street Ballet and Santa Barbara Dance Theater for the first 5 years of my professional career. In January 2017 I relocated to Los Angeles to start PDC and further my choreographic passion. 

PDC has been very fortunate to have had a very busy and successful beginning of our first season having performed at several festivals as well as 2 projected out-of-state summer tours and fall performances booked. We collaborate with highly trained professional dancers who work very hard to set a high standard for this company. We are needing funding to go on tour and pay these talented dancers and to be able to keep this company growing and to be able to full fill our desire to become a non-profit and give back to inspire the next generation. The arts will only be able to continue for generations to come if we all come together to make it happen. 

By contributing you will allow us to become a non-profit and be able to touch this next generation to hopefully impact them to want to move their bodies and spend less time on their phones and activate the creative parts of their brains. Your contribution will also allow those children to be able to have promising examples of hardworking, enthusiastic professional dancers who will be fully involved in our outreach program. By supporting PDC you will not only allow children within Los Angeles to be inspired by dance but also within the communities of the cities we tour to.

What we need 

To get us on tour, have 10 performances+, pay dancers a small performance stipend, host our own fall performance, collaborate with a violinist, have handmade and tailored costumes will cost us $7,000 that will get us through the whole rest of this year.

If we only receive a portion of this amount, what is received first will go toward tour and fabric costs, then dancer stipends and violinist payments which may need to be minimized if needed.

It costs $1,230+ to become a California Non-Profit. 

The break down:

Las Vegas hotel = $700

Gas on tour(Vegas and greater LA)= $250

Small dancer performance pay for the year =$4,650

Violinist =$200

Costumes= $700

Venue for fall show= $500

Sub total: $7,000

Company upgrades:

Dancer rehearsal rate- 10 dancers, $5/hr =$3,910 

5 hours/week/month in a big dance studio= $700/month ($35/hr)

NYC fall tour for White Wave Festival= flights/hotel for 2-3

Grand total= $11,610 + NYC prices

To give a tax deductible donation please go to the Dance Resource Center to give

https://drc.nationbuilder.com/palm_dance_collec...

 

What you get!!!

If you donate:

$25- we'll post on Instagram and Facebook a personal dance video just for you!

$50- Drink ticket to our fall show plus our pervious perks!

$100- Ticket to our show plus our previous perks!

$500- Private Dance Lesson plus all previous perks! 

Find out more information on all the perks when you donate!

****** By sharing that you donated either by social media or email, you'll receive recognition on our website. Don't forget to tag us or cc us in the email so we know you did!******

To give a tax deductible donation please go to the Dance Resource Center to give

https://drc.nationbuilder.com/palm_dance_collec...

 

Your impact

Your contribution will allow the arts to continue to thrive in society and effect the coming generations. PDC has been blessed with numerous performing opportunities within this first season and only continues to be getting accepted to performances and love from the community. Our track record will only continue to grow and spread through out the years. 

Long term goal-

Your support now will help this company get on it's feet to eventually reach our long term goal. Our vision for the future is to be able to have a space where anyone from the community can walk by and watch, listen, or voice their opinion and be apart of the creative space. Most often the public only sees art in it's finished product and don't see the hours and hard work and creative process to creating a finished work. We want to have a studio space where the glass doors are always open and couches are inviting the public to come and be apart of our art from. 

Another vision is to have a performance venue much like the famous Jacob's Pillow but right here on the west coast. We want to have a huge outdoor dance platform with a beautiful backdrop and benches for the audience to sit on in the grass. Performances would be free and for everyone!

We also want to be collaborating with more than just dancers. We want to bring in visual artists, designers, musicians, architects, actors, poets, set designers, etc. We want to transform the performance experience.

 

Risks & Challenges

I, Carisa, am very ambitious, optimistic and determined. This is what has brought us this far but I can only do so much before I break. Currently, I am working at a yoga studio and catering to try to pay for dancer performance stipends and to get us by with all the festival application fees. Without your help we will not be able to continue to perform because my income can only take us so far. Our risks are that I will burn out of working so much without any support and help and we will simply only be able to perform in small local shows without any dancer pay. Even if we receive a small amount of our goal it will help us along and encourage us to keep pursuing this company and our vision. Our fall show will also act as a fundraiser which will help our process along.

 It is also very challenging to look for grants and figure out how to become a non-profit. This is very exhausting and time consuming. We are hoping to have the funding provided for so that we can apply for grants to help us become the company of our vision.

 

Other ways you can help

SHARE!!! Please share this fundraiser on all your social media sites! Please spread the word! The only way we'll be able to do this is with the help of our friends and family spreading the word! Indiegogo has great sharing tools to use, please use them and it will be easier for you to share! Be sure to follow us on Instagram @pdcla and Facebook. Check our website for regular updates on performances and blog insights. 

Besides money we will gladly accept help in many other ways! We would love help in researching grants that would be applicable for us. We would gladly accept any help in writing the grants as well. Getting our outreach programs going consists of a lot of reaching out and research that we would love help with. We are about to be sewing beautiful costumes for our Vegas and fall performances and any locals with sewing experience would be very welcomed!

 

*Photos taken by Tanne Willow Photography

Don't forget to tag us or cc us in the email so we know you did!******To give a tax deductible donation please go to the Dance Resource Center to givehttps://drc.nationbuilder.com/palm_dance_collec... Your impactYour contribution will allow the arts to continue to thrive in society and effect the coming generations. PDC has been blessed with numerous performing opportunities within this first season and only continues to be getting accepted to performances and love from the community. Our track record will only continue to grow and spread through out the years. Long term goal-Your support now will help this company get on it's feet to eventually reach our long term goal. Our vision for the future is to be able to have a space where anyone from the community can walk by and watch, listen, or voice their opinion and be apart of the creative space. Most often the public only sees art in it's finished product and don't see the hours and hard work and creative process to creating a finished work. We want to have a studio space where the glass doors are always open and couches are inviting the public to come and be apart of our art from. Another vision is to have a performance venue much like the famous Jacob's Pillow but right here on the west coast. We want to have a huge outdoor dance platform with a beautiful backdrop and benches for the audience to sit on in the grass. Performances would be free and for everyone!We also want to be collaborating with more than just dancers. We want to bring in visual artists, designers, musicians, architects, actors, poets, set designers, etc. We want to transform the performance experience. Risks & ChallengesI, Carisa, am very ambitious, optimistic and determined. This is what has brought us this far but I can only do so much before I break. Currently, I am working at a yoga studio and catering to try to pay for dancer performance stipends and to get us by with all the festival application fees. Without your help we will not be able to continue to perform because my income can only take us so far. Our risks are that I will burn out of working so much without any support and help and we will simply only be able to perform in small local shows without any dancer pay. Even if we receive a small amount of our goal it will help us along and encourage us to keep pursuing this company and our vision. Our fall show will also act as a fundraiser which will help our process along. It is also very challenging to look for grants and figure out how to become a non-profit. This is very exhausting and time consuming. We are hoping to have the funding provided for so that we can apply for grants to help us become the company of our vision. Other ways you can helpSHARE!!! Please share this fundraiser on all your social media sites! Please spread the word! The only way we'll be able to do this is with the help of our friends and family spreading the word! Indiegogo has great sharing tools to use, please use them and it will be easier for you to share! Be sure to follow us on Instagram @pdcla and Facebook. Check our website for regular updates on performances and blog insights. Besides money we will gladly accept help in many other ways! We would love help in researching grants that would be applicable for us. We would gladly accept any help in writing the grants as well. Getting our outreach programs going consists of a lot of reaching out and research that we would love help with. We are about to be sewing beautiful costumes for our Vegas and fall performances and any locals with sewing experience would be very welcomed! *Photos taken by Tanne Willow Photography

story:
What’s All This Then?

Set in during Carnival, The Rover is definitely #notyourmamasrestorationplay.  The comedy  centers around two groups of people: three women, Hellena, Florinda and Valeria, live under the control and protection of a male relative, Pedro, who has very distinct ideas about their futures, romantic and otherwise.  Meanwhile, Belville (the forbidden love of Hellena) and his friends have descended upon Carnival for celebration and, perhaps, a little romance. Throw in a beautiful courtesan named Angelica, masks, mistaken identities, and a few surprises and you have the makings of a fast paced romp thru gender politics and the difference between temporary and permanent happiness.

Bring Your Own Theatre Productions began several years ago in the apartments of several Chicago creatives with the determination to create live theatre in 24 hours. Since then BYOT Productions has grown out of apartments and into a sprawling theatre company comprised of over 40 members and a growing cast of monthly players.  

The Rover by Aphra Behn, is BYOT Productions’ second annual full length production and will be going up at the end of July.  Rehearsals are underway, our designers are already creating the world of Carnivale...and we need your help!

What your support means:

Doing 24-hour theatre, we are used to scraping by with cardboard, gaff tape, and a lot of suspension of disbelief. Your support will directly help our designers see their vision come to life. We can go beyond hastily homemade props and secure production-quality materials, including:

Venue Rental - $1700
Rehearsal Space - $800
Costumes - We have 15 people to dress.    
Props - Swords, masks, confetti, beads, and so many other things.
Set - The expense that always seems to double, especially when it involves paint.
Honorariums for the cast and crew - Very modest at the moment, and we’d like to see it grow. We take pride in the people who are ready to commit their time and talent to our productions. It takes a village to raise a child and our village wants to see this baby raised right.  

Proceeds from this campaign that are not utilized in production costs will go towards the rest of BYOT Productions' upcoming season. 

What are our challenges with THE ROVER?

Money.

We know we can put on a good play with a limited budget.
We know we will be able to make magic out of curtains and PVC piping.
Our audience deserves more than “good”. They deserve great. YOU deserve great. It is our love for you that makes us want to put on the best show we possibly can. So please, help us do our best for you!

Our audience!

We want to get the word out as much as possible for this full-length play. We would hate for anyone to miss out. Which also leads us to...

Other Ways You Can Help!

BYOT relies on its players and audience to spread the good word of this wacky, beloved theatre company. We rely on YOU to share our story, and in doing so, make theatre that much more accessible to your loved ones <3 <3 <3.  We know that money is perpetually tight, so if you don't feel able to donate at this time, we would so appreciate you sharing our project.  


Find us on Facebook at BYOTProdutions
And on Instagram and Twitter @BYOTProductions

Thank you for taking the time to look into our campaign!  

***********

To our Master of the Revelers level donators: 

When you select the $100 Perk you have an opportunity to select one of these amazing offerings from some of our members and participants.  Each is first come first serve so don't wait!  Some of the perks are Chicago exclusive, some we can ship right over to you.  Keep checking back here for updates as we will continue to add awesome additions to this perk! 

Vocal Lessons or Personal Song courtesy of Devon Carson 
Personal Song courtesy of Mike Butler-Lundquist 
Photo Session courtesy of Vanessa Buholzer 
Framed Photograph courtesy of Nate Earnest 
Dramatic Reading courtesy of Vinny Greco  
Art courtesy of Zach Wziontka  
Hype Man courtesy of Dante Charlton 

If you select this Perk and decide to not go with the above, you can also choose our BYOT Goodie Pack that includes a Pint Glass, T-shirt, Signed Poster, Ticket to the show, and a personal thank you.

story:
"5toMidnight has created a platform to unite artists from diverse social and cultural backgrounds by working openly and inclusively. From their work with hearing-impaired actors in Indonesia to LGBTQ artists in Taiwan, the mission of 5toMidnight will continue to stand for humanism and social justice. I am excited to see the next works 5toMidnight will produce."

-Robert Wilson

The Vision

5toMidnight believes in establishing an ecosystem of actors, playwrights, and educators that consistently tour worldwide, allowing access to free theatre for the masses. 

The goal is to enable and empower actors and audiences alike through Intercultural exchanges to provide a diverse world view and expressions that enrich the stage with different forms of interpretation. Despite creed, race, or socio-political standing, 5toMidnight invites actors to come create and explore their craft with the constructive support from collaborative cultural collectives. 

The work we do stands as a communal point of communication from which we can understand and push societal boundaries by breaking down the sociocultural and political discourse through art.  

We wish to create an emancipation of both art and artist, and deliver this to the audience in the most honest and visceral way. Establishing a relationship between artist and audience opening these pieces of art for practically free. 

This campaign is to raise funds to support the large, multiracial cast and creative team, and to offer opportunities for you, the audience, to engage in the creative process. We believe in community engagement in the creation of the work, while keeping prices as low as possible, to support large-scale, yet relevant work. 

 

The Work 

With a body of work that spans Chekhov’s shared theatrical universe, exploring Samuel Beckett’s Waiting for Godot as a lost in translation love story in a living room, and an immersive graphic novel adaptation across 3 continents; 5toMidnight aims to create work that galvanises an audience towards building a harmonious global society through the Theatre of Hope. To think critically and act consciously in the society we live in.

In 2014, we created a local adaptation of Anton Chekhov's Ivanov on a rooftop carpark bar/restaurant in the heart of Chinatown.

We also paid homage to the father of Singaporean Theatre Kuo Pao Kun with a production of “The silly little girl and the funny old tree” in rural Indonesia as an analogy for the rapid urbanisation and loss of community culture. We created a 360 degree theatre-scape in an outdoor location, where the visual aural elements of the production were bolstered by audience involvement. 

These projects, and more, continue to be in development, to give our immense network of creatives what Robert Lepage calls “rendering time”. Which means, upon completion of this campaign, we are in a position hone the quality and dissemination of these works internationally.

 

For Actors - Education and Methodology  

The intercultural methodology of 5toMidnight creates a common language in the room that precedes both language and society. It breaks down the barriers of language through expression. Any art that comes out of this place of emotional truth and impulse is fed by ones’ humanity, cultural upbringing, perspective, and it manifests itself in a set of behaviours that is as honest and true to life as the “base creative state”. Emotion and sensation, to physicalise and not intellectualise the instinct of art. A chain reaction of expanding creativity by synthesizing movement, voice, and consciousness in the craft of experiencing. 


Particularly in today's world, we aim to fight against inequality, discrimination and ultimately violence through the beauty of theatre. With plans to expand to India, China, South Africa, Europe and the Americas, we look forward to having you join us on our mission to build more connected and empathetic global society.
 

Contributions

By contributing to this campaign, you will be supporting a diverse range of artists, offering them a fair wage and promoting a tightly involved culture of creating theatre that prioritises an audience's cultural context, and social situations. You will be promoting theatre in unconventional spaces, and challenging the definition of what is needed to create an immersive theatrical event.  

Your contributions will go directly to Travel costs, homestay funds, basic sustenance, institutional grant processing periods, and a buffer for advanced production payments (venue rental, production rights, props, and costuming).

Even after receiving basic funding to cover the overhead costs of the company, this campaign's contributions will go directly to the people who stand by the ethos, of providing and promoting free theatre and education to the world.

Whatever contributions we receive, big or small, will go directly to the actors (with exception of the crowdfunding platform fee).  

In addition to that, crowdfunding allows us to offer you opportunities to work hands- on with the company from training with the director on the play itself, to watching the show being built, and to thank you for your contributions towards the proceeds, a piece of memorabilia unique to the show you attend :)

Higher perks include Discounts, international workshops, and being a part of our rehearsals! If for whatever reason, you can't attend these, you can gift them to a friend locally or internationally!

                                     

Why Now? 

The international team working on towards the 5toMidnight vision come from a variety of backgrounds to train together as theatre makers to create a culture that is inclusive, and empathetic to each other’s' circumstances. 5toMidnight strives for true intercultural exchange between its various branches to fight ignorance, violence, and discrimination. 

Since the formation of 5toMidnight, we have embarked to Italy, Indonesia, Japan, and Taiwan to develop international collaborations and seed projects for the future. We have brought all these international compatriots together to work for international festivals, such as the Makassar International Writers' Festival (Indonesia), the Farm 2016 international residencies in Italy, and at Robert Wilson's Watermill Centre in New York. 

This is our first time embarking on such a massive undertaking of creating a culture where actors and audience alike can participate in art that is immediate, beautiful, useful, and indispensable. Harking back to times of ancient Greece where such art was freely dispensed to impart and regulate societal values. We wish that art can once again be free, in every measure of the word, to be a display, commentary and critique on society, in hopes of understanding and transcending the human condition. 
 

The Future and Stretch Goals

The future that 5toMidnight hopes for is to create a family of people working together on projects and productions that will bring the aspect of a creative community to a truly international level. Empowering and enabling people through education and experiential exchanges.

What we offer is an invitation.

An invitation, to you, the people to come join us along this journey of building an inclusive and progressive society.

Here is what we hope to achieve with our stretch goals and the proposed societal benefits.

$10,000

  • We’ll be able to provide stipends for all artists travelling overseas when developing work. This will cover their food and local travel.
     
  • In return, we’ll be able to invite local audiences to observe (and in some cases, participate) in the workshops and rehearsals.

$25,000

  • We’ll be able to pay artists a small honorarium for the work done on our overseas trips, on top of profit-shares from ticket sales of the work-in-progress presentations.
     
  • Therefore, we are able to subsidise ticket prices for work-in-progress presentations to a larger extent, meaning more audience members and students have access to our unique creation process on work which is in its developmental phase.

Go On 

By contributing to this campaign, even if you choose none of the rewards available, you will get a ticket to watch our shows, and we hope that that is enough of a gift from us to you for the time that you have spent clicking on the Facebook link, giving us your hard-earned money, coming to the venues, and partaking in a production that we've not only worked hard for, but thoroughly enjoyed creating for you. Thank you for coming this far with us, and Happy Holidays!

Please help us spread the word by:
Talking about us!
Sharing on Facebook!
https://www.facebook.com/5toMidnightInternational/
Tag us on instagram #5tomidnight @5tomidnightintl!
Email us at 5toMidnightintl@gmail.com for more information!


With lots of love,

story:
This work has already received support from Dance Development Centre as a part of their DDCreative residency. This has provided the space needed for creation, rehearsals and performance and has been a massive support for the project. Although there is still a lot needed to help this come to full fruition and that’s where your generous self comes in.

 

Any donations you’re able to make will go towards equipment needed for the creation and showing of the work such as costumes, set, sound equipment and lighting. It will also go towards the artists in residence to help support them over the creation period as many hours will be involved during the process.

 

The choreographer and dancer in the show is Nicholas Jachno. Nicholas is a Canberra based Contemporary Dancer. He studied a range of dance techniques at Dance Development Centre before attending The New Zealand School of Dance, Graduating with a Diploma in Dance Performance majoring in Contemporary. In 2018, Nicholas has been a part of Malia Johnston’s, Rushes, for the 2018 New Zealand Arts Festival, which received four Wellington Theatre Awards. He was also a dancer and collaborator in a design film project, Kinesis, that was displayed as part of the Lux Light Festival in Wellington and received a Bronze award at the Best Design Awards 2018. Nicholas also worked for Cadi McCarthy as a dancer in Catapult Dance Choreographic Hubs premiere Season of That Place in Between.  

 

The Composer and Sound Engineer for the score is Maluil Aleer Deng. Maluil is Canberra based Artist, Producer & Creative. He released his first EP titled DEMO in 2018 which gave us a glimpse into what this young creative powerhouse can & will do in the near future. Maluil brings a unique perspective into the creation of this work and has been involved not only with the sound elements but with the visuals components as well.   

 

There are bigger plans and ideas ahead for this show but to be able to create and present it in a studio setting will give it the opportunity to generate interest around it and allow a chance for feedback and discussion within the local community. If you're not able to give a donation you can still support by coming to the showing on the 24th of January.

There are bigger plans and ideas ahead for this show but to be able to create and present it in a studio setting will give it the opportunity to generate interest around it and allow a chance for feedback and discussion within the local community. If you're not able to give a donation you can still support by coming to the showing on the 24th of January.

story:
This production reclaims the centrality of women’s issues as a crucial component in the revival of a nation and liberation of its people from all types of oppression and colonization. The work reflects women in their universality as a human cause and as the core of all human existence. This journey documents several eminent stories in the liberation history of people and civilizations and propels it to the forefront of higher human values.

Forty years and 15 artistic dance and music productions later, the Troupe has reached a turning point and a new threshold. Having presented more than 1,500 performances in Palestine and the world, trained 1,000 children annually in underprivileged and marginalized areas and having established co-ed Debke groups in highly conservative areas, El-Funoun today prides itself in making remarkable achievements that cannot be disregarded.

Debke is considered one of the main components of the heritage and identity of the Palestinian people and of Greater Syria in general. The Troupe has 204 active volunteer members and a vision and ambition aimed at the liberation of its people. By taking inspiration from world heritage in general and Palestinian Arab folklore in particular, El-Funoun creates artistic productions that reflect the feelings and emotions of its creators, thus creating change at the human level and in society through the exercise of artistic expression.

Tallat ...2014

Images Remembered 2009

“A Letter To …” (RISALA ILA...), 2007

"Raqsit Shamis" ,2006

“Haifa, Beirut & Beyond",2003

“Zaghareed” (Ululations),1997

“Talla Wara Talla” (Tableaus),1994

“Marj Ibn 'Amer”(The Plains of Ibn 'Amer),1989

“Afrah Filastiniyah” (Palestinian Festivities),1987

“Mish’al” (Lantern),1986

“Wadi a-Tuffah” (The Valley of Apples), 1984

“Folkloric Scenes”, 1982

The new dance and music production, Ashira, has an estimated budget of US$180,000 including costs of music composition, choreography, scenography, dramaturgy, and artistic direction as well as the premier performances. Several individuals, companies and foundations have already contributed to covering these costs. The remaining deficit is US$75,000. The audience has always been an integral part of the identity and work of El Funoun, which is why the Troupe decided to target US$ 31,000 to be raised through crowd-funding.

The funds collected through this campaign will partially cover the costs of the music production that 10 Arab and Palestinian young musicians are currently working on. It will cover the cost of music recording, composition, arrangement, and recording. This constitutes 35% of the cost of the music production which also constitutes an income for these young and upcoming musicians.

The production, Ashira, will be premiered in mid-March 2019 followed by a series of performances. These will target audiences from areas that lack the technical requirements for such performances and which are only available in Ramallah, at the Ramallah Cultural Palace in particular. Over 5,000 people will be invited and buses will be provided to transport audiences to and from Ramallah over the course of seven days. An Arab and international performance tour will follow in 2020 and 2021 in addition to other tours in Palestine.

El-Funoun chose crowd funding knowing there are many people who are willing and able to contribute to the advancement of the performing arts scene in Palestine and who are looking for channels for this support. This is where our belief and trust in you, our audience, comes; our audience who appreciates art, our audience who has supported us all these years. Your financial contribution is not only a monetary one, but is an expression of your dedication to the arts in particular and overall, to Palestine.

story:
Our Project:

Stripped Scripts® in association with LIC-A present Stupid Fucking Bird by Aaron Posner. Directed by Adam Knight and presented at the Plaxall Gallery in Long Island City. An exhibit themed to the show, titled Yours and Always Only Yours will be held in conjunction with the show and serve as the set backdrop. Featuring works by LIC-A artists and a solo show by Paola Marintez Fiterre, curated by Sharon Taylor and Tana Sirois.

The cast features: Olivier Renaud, Jay Thomas, Mary Ruth Baggott, Tana Sirois, Daivd Leeper, Allison Threadgold and Donal Brophy. Design team includes: Eric Goodman - lighting design; Didi Marrero - stage manager & Marissa Riggs - assistant stage manager.

This production, written by Aaron Posner, takes us deep into Chekov's Cathartic Love Quadrangle  as it attempts to discover, with meta-thearicallity, what it means to  be an artist and what it truly means to love.

How Your Contribution Helps:

We need your help to fund this exciting project to help -

  • Rights to the play
  • Cast and crew stipends for travel expenses
  • Costuming
  • Advertising & Printed Materials
  • Help fund future arts endeavors

The Impact:

Stripped Scripts® & LIC-A both strive to create an environment for artists to showcase their talents and to develop an environment for creatives to network and develop new works that they may not otherwise have the opportunity or funds to explore. Your donations help us keep this model alive.

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand that some of you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Buying tickets to our show at  strippedscripts.com
  • Helping us spread the word about the show via social media: like & follow us here: facebook.com/strippedscripts   and   facebook.com/stupidfckingbird/                 instagram.com/strippedscripts   and  instagram.com/stupidfckingbird/                    facebook.com/Long-Island-City-Artists-39439873574/                                                                               

Thank you in advance for all your incredible support. We cannot do this without you! So Thanks!!!

story:
The Story

When I was 13 years old, “perfect” was all I aspired to be. This sentiment remained with me as I turned 16, then 21, then 25. I wanted to be the coolest girl at the party who also got straight A’s and had great hair that didn’t explode at the slightest hint of humidity. I wanted to be chill but passionate, effortlessly best dressed, funny without trying too hard.

By the time I entered my mid-twenties, I felt exhausted.

One morning, in the name of research for a satirical news column I write, I sent out a massive group text to my female friends:  “What’s one thing you’re a little neurotic about?”

Over the next hour, hordes of texts filled my phone: “I feel like magazines are always telling me I can be improved,” one girlfriend said. And so it went: “I’m always worrying about what other women think of me;” “I’ve been judged for missing an eyebrow wax;” “I think if I got a boob job, my career would improve.”

Suddenly, I had a bigger story to tell. I wrote “Serving Brûlée” in 2 weeks, through late nights filled with Red Bull and self-reckoning. Through every step of this play, I thought - If my friends and I feel this way, there must also be hundreds of other women who feel the same. They, too, must crave some sort of release. “Serving Brûlée” is for them.

And for my 13-year-old self, the quiet girl who sat in class outlining all the ways she ached to be better – the premiere of “Serving Brûlée” is a dream realized. 

What We Need

"Serving Brûlée" will have 5 performances throughout the course of New York City's Fringe Festival this October. October is only 2 short months away and we need your support!

FringeNYC is one of the largest multi-arts events in North America and we want to put on the best show possible for our audiences. However, producing a show in New York City is incredibly expensive.

Here’s what your contribution will go towards:

Crew

My co-producer, Meredith Yannuzzi, and I are in the process of assembling a crew that’s just as passionate as we are.  This includes:

  • Director
  • Stage Manager
  • Lighting Designer
  • Board Operators

Production

  • Set and props
  • Insurance for cast and crew
  • Rehearsal spaces

Marketing

  • Promotional materials and publicity

The Impact (this October!)

Each contribution will bring us one step closer to making "Serving Brûlée" the best show possible. Let’s face it, don’t we owe ourselves a little catharsis in 2018?

"Serving Brûlée" presents an opportunity to bring women (and men) together to laugh at – and examine – ourselves as we answer society’s eternal questions: “Are you being your best self? Have you achieved your Inner Brûlée?”

We want to make this a show you remember fondly as you straighten your hair in the mirror the next morning.  

Other Ways You Can help

Can’t financially contribute? That’s ok! Does this story resonate with you? Yes? Great! Help us get the word out and share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and that family group chat that’s blowing up your phone.

story:
Welcome back, Y'all. Allow me to reintroduce myself: My name is Roderick (Ricky) Woodruff. I was born and raised on the eastside of Detroit. I am a graduate of Southern Methodist University (SMU) with a Bachelors of Fine Arts in Acting. Prior to pandemic, I was on track to debut my four years of hard work, my baby, A Boy's Room at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. Like everyone else, I discovered that life doesn't always work out the way we want. The universe had other plans. Theatre doors were closed and the faith of A Boy's Room seemed to hang on on by a thread. I was ready to let go, but God had other plans. God showed me with a little faith, the world would began to open up to me-- keep faith and all will be well. I had no choice but to answer the call...

So, we are back; theatre is back; A Boys Room is back! And this time, you WILL get the chance to see just why God has told us to KEEP FAITH. Rejoin my revolution: the New York premier of “A Boy’s Room.”

A Boy’s Room is a multimedia memory play that follows little Ricky in his bedroom, attempting to put on a one-of-a-kind performance inspired by  Beyoncé’s Formation World Tour. During his flamboyant pop performance, he is steadily interrupted by his inner demons, who constantly beg him to conform. At its core, A Boy’s Room is meant to disrupt, deconstruct, and ultimately dismantle toxic-masculinity that is generationally imposed on black boys. Through the use of a short film, creative storytelling, original music and choreography, A Boy’s Room serves as my call to action- educating the world [particularly black men] on the importance of embracing one’s whole self.

As a poor, black and gay man I have experienced public humiliation, doubt and self hate. I have spent most of my life in search of wholeness and self worth. More often than not, I had found myself resenting the circumstances of which I’d been placed. More so, I resented those whom I felt had placed me there. I had become insecure, to say the least. I quickly learned to wear masks to conceal the shame I felt in everyday things; my mom’s beat up 1990’s Subaru, the ebonics I grew up speaking and the Beyonce song lumped in my throat. Being a poor, black and gay boy from Detroit was a Death sentence to me. I worked hard to prove myself to my community by excelling artistically at the internationally acclaimed Mosaic Youth Theatre of Detroit, academically at Cass Technical High School and even beyond Detroit at Southern Methodist University and Dallas Theatre Center. I truly believed the only way to escape my circumstances was through assimilation. I yearned to be seen as a distinguished man, though it would amount to a complete loss of self identity. By senior year at SMU, I had realized that my acting techniques were great, but my work was lacking the brutal honesty that is required to make real art. It was lacking my truth. It was lacking the poor, black, gay boy I tried to erase. I began to question myself and my work. How could I be this revolutionary, transformative and inspirational artist who influences the next generation, while living a lie? The answer was simple: I couldn’t.

So, I wrote A Boy’s Room, not only to reconcile my relationship with self, but to also ensure that no little black boy ever thinks that assimilation is his only way out.

After realizing its potential, I workshopped and staged the first production in April of 2019. Despite the conservative culture at SMU, the production was well received. Each night, the show’s occupancy was at maximum capacity. The audience members were transcended. It was as if we had experienced a spiritual gathering together. It was here that I understood the potential for truly engaging, transforming and inspiring the world. I then teamed up with producer Kaylyn Buckley (SMU ‘17) and director Brandi Nicole Mcleain (SMU ‘19) to begin laying the ground work for both a New York and 2020 Edinburgh Fringe Festival debut. And though the 2020 productions did not happen, we preserved-- ensuring we remained ready for the NYC arts resurgence-- and was gifted a platform from a leading NYC theatre.

During a time when theatre seems to be revamping, it is important for us to reevaluate which stories are being told. I am tired of not seeing myself on Broadway stages. I am tired of feeling like I have no chance of ever making it. A Boy's Room is for the boys who don't feel enough. It is for the boys who conform because they do not know if they can survive being themselves. I want them to those boys to see themselves. I want them to hear a story that may be closer to theirs. It is time. We will not hide in shadows anymore. We deserve to have easy access to our stories. Due to the nature of most theatre right now, we will virtually stream the production which allows audiences to remain active by posting and tweeting--assisting us in promoting our narrative--and also ensures that the show’s targeted audience have easy access to the performance. 

Today, I ask you to join our movement.  A Boy's Room is a lifestyle; a relationship to a truth that is greater than just a play. It is a voice for countless young black men who cannot (or refuse) to speak his truth. It is my way of protecting, engaging, inspiring and transforming the generation that succeeds me. It is a safe space where theatre meets community and vice versa. With your help, A Boy’s Room can change lives. I am asking you to join our movement and to partner with us in saving the little Black gay boy who feels inadequate and ashamed. To produce A Boy’s Room successfully, we need to raise at least $2,000. Easy, right? This money will be used for lighting and sound equipment, pay for our invaluable creatives, costumes, transportation, and other crucial production expenses. If you’d like to make a substantial donation that is tax-deductible, please follow this link so you can donate through our fiscal sponsorship and receive your tax write-off: 

https://fundraising.fracturedatlas.org/a-boy-s-...

Together we can protect, engage, inspire and transform the culture.

story:
Dear Friends and Fans,

Welcome to the official Indiegogo campaign for Gunnar Montana Productions 2021 production, Motel Montana!

Our cast and crew are so excited to welcome you back to a live, in-person Gunnar Montana immersive experience.  Rehearsals are already underway and we can't wait to share this amazing show with you!

Motel Montana will be a colorful explosion from start to finish and depicts the flamboyant, lavish, fabulous-ness that only comes out when no one is looking, and people are free to be their authentic selves. 

Tickets to Motel Montana are already on-sale, but you can enhance your experience, support our work, and get some great swag by making a fully tax-deductible contribution here.  

Thank you for your ongoing love and friendship.  We can't do this without you, and we are grateful for your support.

See you in September!... and October!... and BEYOND!

XOXO,

Gunnar Montana Productions

story:
The Play

" Let me tell you something , You don't get rainbows without rain!' -  2 years of eternal joy                

 After a young woman is diagnosed with cancer, she and her fiancé find their relationship tested by the hidden resentments the illness brings out in her family.   Joy and Jah are hit with the devastating news that Joy has ovarian cancer.  When breaking the news to family and friends everyone’s love, or lack thereof, is revealed and tested.  Joy’s mother, Shanice, wants to take care of her and hold off her marriage to Jah.  Joy’s father, George, wants Jah to convince Joy to slowed.  Out of resentment Rudy, Joy’s sister, tells Joy sister is completely unsupportive. When the couple decides that they want to go through unifying their life and love the family become distraught and unsupportive.  Yet through the trials and tribulations of sickness and family Joy and Jah’s love grows strong and becomes the healing everyone needs.                              

 

Ok, That Sounds Interesting !? Where can I see it ?

2 Years of Eternal Joy has been chosen to appear in Broadway Bound Theater festival. The festival is geared towards introducing up and coming Playwright to the New York stage.  Sherod D. Lee has been charged with task to present 3 the full runs on his production on stage. However, this is no easy feat.  We are asking you to "Join our Journey" to Broadway Bound Theater Festival ! 

How do I Join The Journey !?

So you are ready to take this crazy ride with us ? Welcome ! We are so excited to go through this experience with you by our side.  Here is what we need. It really takes a village to put on a play. Below is a break down of our budget of the things we need to a to acquire to bring "2 years of Eternal Joy" Life. 

Rehearsal Space :$432

Travel Expense: $300

Housing: $1,800

Emergency Money: $300

Props: $300

YOU CAN INVEST AS LOWER AS $5!  IT GOES A LONG WAY!

 

F@*K CANCER 

Cancer is a terrible disease. The number of new cases of cancer is 454.8 per 100,000 men and women per year. The number of cancer deaths  is 171.2 per 100,000 men and women per year. So we would like to help. Cancer not only affects the body; it affects the mind and spirit. We are donating 25% of our proceeds to Cancer Care. Cancers Care provides counselling , support groups, education and financial assistance  to cancer patients. If you want to find out more about Cancer Cares click the link below.  

https://www.cancercare.org

Other to Join the Journey!

There are other way to Join the Journey!  You can head over to our social media accounts and MAKE SOME NOISE!!!!! Like, share, comment so we know you are with us. 

Follow us on Instagram: @eternaljoynyc and on Twitter: @eternaljoy_nyc

Like us at https://www.facebook.com/EternalJoyNYC/?fref=nf

We also would love to see your beautiful faces in our audience. 

The Broadway Bound Theater Festival will be held from August 18th to August 20th. "2 Years of Eternal Joy" will be performed on: 
Friday, August 18th at 12:30 p.m
Saturday, August 19th at 10:30 p.m
Sunday, August 20th at 6:30 p.m

You can purchase tickets at https://www.broadwayboundfestival.com/book-online

story:
Short Summary

Hello. I'm Lenny Gatto (Executive Producer, Playwright & Composer),  born and raised in New Jersey. I began studying music at the age of 12 and subsequently served in the U.S. Navy (Vietnam Veteran) for 20 years. I lived in Italy many and observed many life situations which I now bring to life in this story.  Never has there been an original music about the lives and customs of ordinary Italians and I felt it was about time one was presented that has absolutely nothing to do with organized crime or wiseguys. I am passionate about this project because it is completely based on actual events. The music is original and many of the love ballads were written as far back as 1972. The show is a love story to be sure that is fit for the entire family.

Anyone with least one drop of Italian blood (or even if not), should see this show! It will make you smile, laugh, shed a tear or two, and even spark a distant or present memory. By the way, I love shows with happy endings. The show is respectfully dedicated to my late wife, Rosa, and my fantastic lyricist and best friend, the late Tom Jansing.

I am extremely proud that "They Call it Gravy; WE Call It SAUCE! is a 2017 Perry Award Nominee for the category of Outstanding Original Musical.

Today, Community Theater. Tomorrow, Broadway!

Since the show is original, we need sets, props and I want to be able to pay my extremely talented actors who will travel from NYC to New Jersey for numerous rehearsals and performances...and of course, I have to rent the venue and services.

I offer the following rewards for contributors: Shoutouts on social media, tee shirts, coffee mugs, Soundtrack CD.

Contributors can see more information on the Music Jar Productions Facebook Page.

I ask that you spread the word and please use Indiegogo share tools!

Grazie mille!

story:
Ciao!

La nostra associazione ha avuto un anno complicato come tante realtà che si occupano di cultura, arte, sport e benessere. Siamo una piccola comunità che ama danzare insieme, e appena è stato possibile abbiamo organizzato le riprese del nostro saggio di fine anno, presso la splendida location del Museo di Arte Moderna Ca' LA Ghironda, in provincia di Bologna.

#Breathe, così si chiama la nostra performance, è il risultato del lavoro dei nostri allievi, dei nostri insegnanti e della fiducia e dell'amore delle famiglie che ci hanno accompagnato in questo periodo difficile.

La scuola ha sostenuto i costi per le riprese e il montaggio del video ed ora ti chiediamo se hai voglia di condividerle con noi, e darci una mano ad attraversare altri giorni con il respiro profondo e il passo leggero della danza, insieme.

Tutto quanto sarà raccolto in più rispetto ai costi sostenuti, sarà utilizzato per finanziare borse di studio per i nostri corsi per piccoli e grandi danzatori.

“Respirare l’aria, che delizia!

Parlare, passeggiare, afferrare qualcosa con la mano!

Essere questo incredibile Dio che io sono!

O meraviglia delle cose,

anche delle più piccole particelle!

O spiritualità delle cose!

Io canto il sole all’alba e nel meriggio,

o come ora nel tramonto:

tremo commosso della saggezza

e della bellezza della terra

e di tutte le cose che crescono

sulla terra.

E credo che una foglia d’erba

non sia meno di un giorno di lavoro delle stelle.

E dico che la Natura è eterna,

la gloria è eterna.

Lodo con voce inebriata

perchè non vedo un’imperfezione nell’universo,

non vedo una causa o un risultato che,

alla fine,

sia male.”

(W. Whitman)

story:
What is this?

  • Over the past few months David Stobbe, Abigail Phelps, and Kyle Howard Hamlin have been workshopping a production of An Apology For The Course And Outcome Of Certain Events As Delivered By Doctor John Faustus On This His Final Evening, throughout the basements and livingrooms of their friends apartments.
    Now we've been offered the opportunity to do a short run at The Chopin Theater following Mickle Maher's newest show Jim Lehrer and The Theater And Its Double and Jim Lehrer's Double.
  • We need your help to raise money to pay rent on our theater space. $500 to be precise. That's it. That's all we need from you. Simple right?
  • Any donated amount wil help us put on this show that has meant so much to us and show the Chicago Theater Community what we have to offer.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Each performance costs us $125 to do, and we need $375 to do our full 3 show run.
  • The other $125 will go towards purchasing props and minor costume pieces.
  • And if we raise more?? Additional performances may be added, the quality of our production will be improved, and we may even be able to pay our performers for their time and effort.
  • We have a host of perks from thank you cards to ten minute play just for you to dinner with one of our performers in exchange for your donations.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? Thanks okay!
You can still help by sharing this page on social media, coming to the performances, and telling your friends about the show. The more people that see this the better so share, share, SHARE!

story:
Reality:Check Productions

Reality:Check Productions are committed within their programme to rediscovering and reimaging contemporary classics for a new audience. We aim to reinterpret these plays through the physicality of the characters and to give the audience a visceral experience of the plays.

Reality:Check are a young company, with both founderers in their early 20’s. We  believe that this is an important factor as we really believe in young people using their own unique voice. We aim to give other young artist the chance to do this where they may not have the means for example our upcoming collaboration with Colin Barrett and our new  partnership with The Dolemen Theatre to present nights of New Writing.

We treat all of our projects, workshops and rehearsal room as a safe, creative, devising ensemble, where everyone involves is of equal standing and has the chacne to use their own unique voice as a part of a bigger picture.

We also have the craic

Colin Barrett

Born in 1982, Barrett grew up in County Mayo and worked for a mobile phone company in Dublin before returning to college to study creative writing. His stories began appearing in the Irish literary journal The Stinging Fly in 2009, with the magazine bringing out a collection four years later as Barrett signed with Jonathan Cape in the UK and Grove in the US.

Young Skins, Colin Barrett’s debut work, has won the Guardian First Book Award, The Frank O’Connor International Short Story Prize, the Rooney Prize for Irish Literature and was longlisted for the Folio Prize. It has just been published in the United States to a rave review in the New York Times 

The collection is set for the most part in the fictional town of Glanbeigh, a nowheresville hard by the “gnarled jawbone” of Ireland’s Atlantic coastline with a roundabout, an industrial estate, a five-screen Cineplex and “a century of pubs packed inside the square mile of the town’s limits”. A cast of petrol pump attendants, recovering addicts, drug dealers and bouncers weaves around this constricted world from night club to fast-foodery, from river bank to concrete picnic area, the city far enough away that it might well as be on the moon. Violence hangs in the air – violence which can be swerved, or pushed aside to offer some unexpected transcendence, but is always there, hovering like the “thickets and thickets” of midges in the evening.

Where your money goes

As We are a completely unfunded company, we rely on fundraising in order to produce our work. We, along with the fantastic artists we work with, give up our time for almost nothing in order to bring our artistic visions to life. That being said there are some administrative costs that we need to cover in order to make this show happen.

These include, paying a Graphic Designer, Lighting Designer and paying for print, rehearsal space and lots more. Ideally we want our entire team to make as much as possible for this project, as it is crucial we pay artists for their work. So the more of these admin costs we can cover early the better position we are in for our artists.

Reality:Check Productions pays all profit made from its shows directly to the team involved.

 

Anything you can give would make a HUGE difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Share this campaign to your friends and family!
  • Come and see the show!
  • Follow us on Twitter and Facebook. 
  • https://twitter.com/Reality_Check_1
  • https://www.facebook.com/RealityCheckProduction/

story:
Short Summary

Welcome to Ozark Living Newspaper Theatre's Art of Change campaign. OLN grew out of a collective interest among Central Arkansas artists and activists to develop a theatre company that used puppetry, mask, movement, and spoken word to generate dialogue and action about community problems, both local and global. Established as a 501(c)(3) tax-exempt organization in 2017, OLN has spent its first year building partnerships with educational institutions, other arts organizations, and local charities.

In building toward our inaugural season of full production in 2018-2019, we have conducted workshops on nonprofit organizing, grant writing for arts and social justice, and the #MeToo movement as it impacts working artists. In the past year, OLN has used large parade puppets to raise funds for Louisiana flood relief, to make Central Arkansans aware of proposed campus concealed carry legislation, to support juvenile justice arts projects, and to raise funds for local women's shelters. Like the "Living Newspapers" developed under the Federal Theatre Project during the Great Depression, OLN exists to get Americans thinking and talking about the issues that affect them on an everyday basis - and to take action to bring positive change to their communities. 

What We Need & What You Get

The Art of Change campaign focuses on three goals:

-Paying for rehearsal and performance venues for our Unfringed Fests in support of local charities and for our 2018-2019 season. 

-Raising funds to pay workshop leaders and venue costs for our juvenile court theatre partnerships with Faulkner County Juvenile Court.

-Raising funds to partially cover production costs for our 2018-2019 season:  "Waiting for Lefty" by Clifford Odets, an original, devised piece based on the #MeToo movement, and "Flex" by Candrice Jones. 

Contributors to the Art of Change campaign will receive the following benefits: 

Up to $10:  One free ticket to any OLN production.

$25-$50 range:  Fees waived for one OLN-sponsored workshop or two tickets to any OLN production.

$50-$100:  Fees waived for up to two participants in an OLN-sponsored workshop or four tickets to any OLN production.

$100 or above: Fees waived for up to four participants in an OLN-sponsored workshop or six tickets to any OLN production. 

The Impact

OLN's Board and artistic collective is committed to the idea that great theatre happens in two ways:  First, through committed, talented artists engaging in passionate performance. And second, through motivating people who do not normally do theatre to use it as a tool for positive social change, to address community problems, and to engage in action for social justice. 

Risks & Challenges

Most new theatre companies fail within their first couple of years. OLN is no more immune to the risk of failure than any other company. Our challenge is to engage the proverbial "little guy." We're less interested in mega-donations than we are in small donations from a wide swath of community members who feel disenfranchised, disengaged, and discombobulated by the current political climate. Yes, OLN will apply for grants to enable its partnerships and pursue its artistic goals, but our "bread and butter" can and should be from small donors (yes, $10 counts), workshop participants, and audience members. We believe the work we do is exciting, necessary, and worth paying for. We believe in paying artists for their work and consider that a main goal. And we believe that the best litmus test for the vitality of a theatre of action is support from the people least able to give large donations. 

Other Ways You Can Help

OLN would like to work with you to create stories about your community's history and challenges. If you think you "qualify," organize a community meeting and invite us to make a presentation. We'll tell you how we will work with your community to engage in theatre-based problem solving.
